author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi lucky5, The right supraclavicular lymph node is located on the right side in the hollow above the clavicle, just lateral to where it joins the sternum. It drains the mediastinum, lungs, esophagus. Common causes of enlargement include lung, retroperitoneal or gastrointestinal cancer. The left supraclavicular lymph node is located on the left side in the hollow above the clavicle, just lateral to where it joins the sternum. It drains the thorax, abdomen via thoracic duct. Common causes of enlargement include lymphoma, thoracic or retroperitoneal cancer, bacterial or fungal infection.Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2]. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Certain areas of lymph node enlargement are more disconcerting than others. This would be the reasoning for your physician wanting an evaluation with diagnostic studies. The results should provide direction into the causative factor for your symptoms. We hope all is well and best wishes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN   References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

content: had HD in 1998 (neck only) relapsed in 2002 stage IIIB. all nodes approx. 1-1.5 cm. (never bulky) Felt great up until a few months ago. fatigue, fevers, little weight loss. Recent ct of neck showed numerous small nodes in the internal jugular, anterior carotid, posterior neck. increased since scan of 9/05. all approx. 7-10 mm. Now my question, my onc.saids they are too small to biopsy, but my pri.dr wants me to go to a new onc. all other blood tests for other diseases and infections are negative. He said I should get a petscan (last one was done in May 2005). I was told last year that I would need a stemcell transplant, but that was put off because the nodes didnt grow(only had 1 small posterior neck lymph node then.. In 2002 I went throught the same thing, the lymphoma spread into my chest, ab, and pelvis. Can a petscan detect cancer in these small lymph nodes? I also have the same pain by my left kidney (spleen removed have acessory one that has changed) have severe back pain and right leg pain. Get fevers of 100. Im afraid they will not grow like last time and spread into my chest and ab. Recent ctscan of chest revealed no major lymphadenopathy but some pleural thickening and scarring. can small nodes like these in the neck be biopsied? thank you for you help.

content: Hi goatlady, If your primary physician is suggesting a PET Scan and this diagnostic test is both accessible and available to you then I would suggest that you follow your primary physicians advice. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Mary Beth, My apologies for the delayed reply. Here is my opinion on the matter. You, above anyone, know your own body. The experience that you have had with cancer in the past, the symptoms that presented, would make you more alert and aware when something is array. Sometimes people (any profession) are straight or closed minded, not willing to LISTEN, accept, or be receptive to intervention or what they would consider "interference" by another. This is not to say they are right or wrong, just narrow minded (if that makes sense). Now to my view, your primary physician seems concerned about your health and in all honesty, also seems to be listening to you. If a PET Scan is warranted in his/her opinion based on symptoms you are experiencing, then there should not be a matter regarding a professional becoming angry, it's a matter of what's best for the patient. I do not see anything wrong with concern for a patient, a physician ordering what he or she deems medically necessary, nor anything wrong with a second opinion. As for the Lactate Dehydrogenase levels, elevations are seen in conditions aside from, for example lymphoma, therefore they may be nonspecific in the initial diagnosis, however, this test is used monitoring diagnosed disease and elevations may give an indication of suspected recurrence. I hope you will consider posting updates as your time permits. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,   There are three distinct clinicopathologic entities of marginal zone B cell lymphomas:  1. Extranodal lymphomas of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT). They most commonly involve the GI tract, salivary glands, thyroid, orbit, or lung. 2. Node-based monocytoid B-cell lymphomas.  3. A third involves the spleen (splenic marginal zone lymphomas).   Marginal zone lymphomas usually have a slow indolent course. You would want to ask about the type of treatment that is suitable for your liver condition given the fact that many anti-cancer drugs are hepatotoxic.  What are the manifestations of your autoimmune disease? Are you taking any medications for it?  Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Sun Feb 05, 2006 5:49 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Patients with nodal marginal zone lymphoma (monocytoid B-cell lymphoma) are treated with watchful waiting or therapies as described for follicular lymphoma, which generally include less aggressive regimens than those used to treat aggressive forms of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.  I am not clear on something you said. Is your hepatitis auto-immune or is it related to a viral infection such as HCV. Some types of indolent lymphomas are HCV related. Among these patients, the majority attain a complete or partial remission after loss of detectable HCV RNA with treatment using interferon alfa with or without ribavirin.  Best regards.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I hope your wheezing is better. Please call your doctors and inform them of your breathing problem as they will be better at assessing the situation than I am.  I wouldn't expect your lymph nodes to change, your disease is actually an indolent one (slowly progressive). Some physicians advocate the use of a watch and wait policy. Which essentially means that you will not need to receive any treatment, just observation.  I am sure you will be referred to the oncologist in time.  You should discuss the link between HCV and marginal zone lymphomas with your doctor. Let him tell you could benefit from the treatment plan I briefly mentioned above (interferon alfa with or without ribavirin). It may or may not apply to your case. It is for him to decide.  On the other hand, to answer your question about autoimmune disease and lymphoma treatment: many of the drugs used to treat your condition may actually benefit your autoimmune disease as well. Your doctor will want to look at your liver profile and make sure that you are in good shape before initiating any form of treatment.  I know the lack of knowledge can be scary but let me reassure you that according to your description things look like they will turn out very well for you.  Best regards.

title: [no title]
content: Happy one,  There is no need to get frustrated. Really, if you had been referred to the oncologist he would have had to wait for a CT scan. Its one of the basic requirements for disease staging.   Only when your doctor knows accurately the extent of your disease can he consider the appropriate treatment plan. Its also a chance for you to know about the extent of your disease.  Like I said before, your disease commonly takes a very indolent course. If it were a problem, don't you think I would have rushed you off for a second opinion? Is the node size stable? When is the CT scan scheduled for?  Best regards.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi pennygaile, Lymph node enlargement typically related to an infectious process tend to decrease in size over a short period of time. Lymph node enlargement that persists or does not decrease in size over a short period of time, despite a course of antibiotic therapy would of course raise concern about the pathology or causative factor regarding enlargement. Regardless, notify your physician that you are continuing to experience symptoms. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi reggietoga, The submandibular lymph nodes are located along the underside of the jaw on either side. They drain the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. Common causes of enlargement include infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx.  Pain/Tenderness. When a lymph node rapidly increases in size, its capsule stretches and causes pain. Pain is usually the result of an inflammatory process or suppuration, but pain may also result from hemorrhage into the necrotic center of a malignant node. The presence or absence of tenderness does not reliably differentiate benign from malignant nodes.[1]  Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses.  Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections.  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened. The fact that the area enlarges and then decreases in size even though it has been repeated in the same area would be more indicative of an underlying infection in one of the above stated areas of "common causes of enlargemnent". I am glad however that further diagnostics have been completed and I hope that all has turned out well. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN    References: ========= 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi katmouse, There are many causes of generalized lymphadenopathy of which the mononucleosis type syndromes are the most common. They usually present with fatigue, malaise, fever and atypical lymphocytosis on examination of the blood picture. Splenomegaly may be present in 50% of patients due to Epstein-Barr virus infection. These cases can be diagnosed using the monospot test, IgM EA or VCA. There would be reason for concern if excessive intensity and duration of the following constitutional symptoms are present such as,fatigue, malaise, fever, abdominal pain (especially on the left side), "flu-like" illness, rash, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, arthritis, renal, neurologic, hematologic disorders, bruising, conjunctivitis, sweat, shortness of breath and cough. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. If your physician is unwilling to evaluate these areas by physical exam so that a period of 3-4 weeks of observation is done to evaluate whether these areas are continuing to enlarge then I would suggest a second opinion to identify the causative factor. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi katmouse, If by stating svc syndrome you are inquiring about superior vena cava syndrome then I can give you some information. The superior vena cava is the large vein that carries blood to the heart. When compression of this vessel exists, regardless of whether it is caused by a benign or malignant origin, it produces symptoms of face and neck swelling, possibly including the arm. Persistent shortness of breath, cough, etc., may also be present. Treatment of course depends on the etiology. As I stated previously, benign (nonmalignant) conditions may cause this syndrome but without doubt a malignant disease process needs ruled out. I hope this is somewhat helpful. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  l am sorry to hear about your complaints.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].   Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. However, in one series [3] of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2. These studies were performed in referral centers, and conclusions may not apply in primary care settings.  In children, lymph nodes larger than 2 cm in diameter (along with an abnormal chest radiograph and the absence of ear, nose and throat symptoms) were predictive of granulomatous diseases (ie, tuberculosis, cat-scratch disease or sarcoidosis) or cancer (predominantly lymphomas) [4].  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.  Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses.   PET scans are very helpful in the diagnosis of cancer. I suggest you discuss the above information with your doctor. He is the best judge of the situation.  References: ========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58. 2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9. 3. Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82.  4. Slap GB, Brooks JS, Schwartz JS. When to perform biopsies of enlarged peripheral lymph nodes in young patients. JAMA 1984;252:1321-6.

title: Painful, swollen lymph node in neck for over 6 months.

It seems to enlarge and become more painful with the flares of fibro.  Sometimes it is so swollen and painful that it hurts  to turn my head.  I have used moist heat periodically and that seems to help some.  Sometimes the pain radiates up into my ear.  Is this just another horrible thing that goes along with fibro/cfs or could it be an even more horrible thing, like lymphoma.  I have been to my md twice.  I just received an antibiotic to take and he said he will send me to a surgeon if the antibiotic does not clear it up - so, I would like another opinion.  Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by deb » Thu Jun 29, 2006 12:27 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi deb, There has been documented research on the correlation of Fibromyalgia and enlarged lymph nodes. The enlarged lymph node may wax and wane during flare ups. However there are other causes of lymph node enlargement related to bacterial/viral etiologies and well as malignancies. The purpose for the antibiotic is if the enlargement is related to an infectious origin then the lymph node will decrease in size. Lymph nodes that continue to enlarge upon serial examinations, despite antibiotic treatment warrants some diagnostic studies, ie., labwork, CT Scan etc., Taking into consideration the location of involvement, a referral to a specialist (ENT) would be suggested. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: mystery lump, please help!
content: Hi!  I am frightened to death about what may be happening to me.  I hope someone can give me some advice.  I am a 29 year old mother of 3 (5, 2 and 5 months).  Almost 2 weeks ago I had a tiny little knot in my hair that I was using my fingernails to undo, and I realized a hard spot kind of right where the top of my neck and base of my skull meet right along the hairline on the left toward my left ear.  Upon further self exam I realized that it was a lump, about the size of a large marble just under my skin, not painful or tender, and not moveable at all.  I went to the doctor and they told me to wait a week to see if it changed and come back, which I did.  They said we needed to have it looked at so they wrote me an order for an ultrasound.  I went to the ultrasound yesterday and they found and measured the lump but also found another area on the screen right next to the lump which was also circular in shape, they measured that one also.  I cannot feel the 2nd thing that they measured from the outside.  After she measured the 2nd area she asked me if I had been feeling ill at all, I said not, just exhausted and she said it was a good thing that I had not been feeling sick.  So I don't know if she saw something that prompted her to feel that I shouldn't be feeling well or was just asking out of context.  She told me that she would have the radiologist look at the picutres and if it's anything urgent they will call my doctor but if not it will be at least 5 business days until my doctor gets the results in the mail.  I am freaking out and crying every day thinking that I have lymphoma or another tumor of some sort.  I have not had any other infections that I am aware of that could be causing swelling in my lymphnodes and know that the fact that my lumps are not painful or tender could point to cancer.  I am just wondering if a nurse or doctor could give me their opinion (not a diagnosis I realize, just a personal opinion) or if anyone else has gone through an ultrasound for something like this if you could share what the outcome would be that would be nice to hear since I'm really in the dark and have no idea what could be awaiting me and my family.  Thank you sooooo very much!

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi hilyanne, I'm sure that you are already aware that lymph nodes may enlarge during a bacterial/viral infection (even seemingly mild ones) because the lymphatic system is the defense system of the body. Generally speaking, lymph node enlargement located at the base of the skull (occipital) or behind the ear (post auricular) are often commonly related to inflammatory/infectious disorders of the scalp. This is not to imply that other disorders don't ever present in these locations. There are different forms of Lymphoma, but when symptoms arise, they may present with unexplainable fevers, fatigue, night sweats, weight loss, persistent lymph node enlargement generally located in the neck, axilla, etc., itching etc.  I am glad to hear that your physician is being cautious. Did you have labwork as well? Are the areas continuing to enlarge? I hope that when your time permits that you will consider posting a follow up. Sincerely, Rntdj

The lump is seeming to grow a little bit, in two weeks I would say it's increased in size perhaps an 8th of an inch or so.  I am hoping you are right in that it could be from an infection.  My doctor seems to think because there is no pain or tenderness that it isn't from an infection though which is why he ordered the ultrasound, but hopefully you are right and he is just being extra cautious (which is a good thing I suppose)!  My doctor actually kind of blew off my question about if it could be from an infection, instead just opting right away for the ultrasound.....the reason I knew about the infection relationship to swollen nodes is because a few of our good friends have had swollen nodes from infections, one had a swollen node in his shoulder from a sinus infection and my best friend had 3 swollen nodes in her underarm area due to a cold also. I didn't notice any kind of infection or anything but maybe it could be related (right now of course I would rather have it be that than anything else)!    The main thing that concerns me now after the ultrasound is the 2nd area that they found and measured, it's not something I can feel from the outside but it's almost right next to the lump that I can feel. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi hilyanne, Attempting to keep up with 3 children would certainly cause an abundance of fatigue in itself  The lymph nodes, I already know are nontender. The description of "fixed" or not "movable" is more concerning. Can you describe the texture, when you say "hard" do you mean rock hard/ rubbery, or would you describe them as something else? Although labwork alone, is certainly not definative in diagnosing lymphoma, it is an indicator of how the body is functioning and I would certainly inquire about this being completed. It is common for more than one lymph node to enlarge even in an infection or inflammatory disorder. I am  concerned over the fact that you are having night sweats (drenching?) and I would be somewhat hesitant to relate this symptom to discontinuation of breast feeding. When lymph nodes enlarge related to an infectious disorder they generally decrease in size over a period of time even though often they may not return to their pre-infectious state. It is somewhat disconcerting that these areas are enlarging rather than decreasing in size. Have you had any fever? My best wishes to you and I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: Hi hilyanne, Your description is reason for concern. However, keep in mind that there is no benefit to jumping to conclusions about malignancy. Sometimes the worst thing about any illness or contemplation of, is waiting and wondering.....actually this is sometimes worse than the actual illness. When one knows exactly what they are dealing with, the situation can be confronted head on. You should have a report of the ultrasound by midweek and that would be an acceptable time to inquire about labwork. I would very much appreciate an update. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi hilyanne, Thank you for updating your post. Please don't apologize for asking questions. Generally speaking, when lymph nodes enlarge due to an infection, after the infection subsides there is usually a consistent decrease in size even though they may not return to their pre-infectious state. Although the areas of enlargement you are experiencing are not increasing in size at this time, they aren't decreasing either which is a reason for concern......The CBC should indicate how your body is generally functioning and if there is an indication if an infection, etc., present. Although CBC is a useful diagnostic tool, and is a good indicator of disease states, and can indicate that "something is wrong" it is not definative in diagnosing or ruling out lymphoma. I would suggest also inquiring about a  LDH level, as well as a CT Scan. If a biopsy of the areas is suggested, please do no hesitate in having this completed. It is my hope that you will continue updating with your results. Keeping you in my thoughts and prayers....... Sincerely, Rntdj

content: Hi!  Well, the doctor called me first things this morning to my surprise and he already had the blood test results back that I just did yesterday morning.  The good news is that my blood cell counts seem to be normal so I'm hoping that that means no cancer!!  The bad news is that he says my liver enzyme levels are very high which means my liver isn't breaking things down and he mentioned something about the kidneys (also my triclycerides are up, etc so I think the "new mom diet" probably isn't helping there)!  He said something about gout but I don't even know what gout is, I have heard of it but he says I'm probably too young for that.  He now wants me to take more blood tests to test for Hepatitis of any kind as we aren't sure what is causing the liver to act strangely as I don't drink at all and never have and he asked me if I take a lot of pain killer (Tylenol, etc) which I take occasionally but not a ton of....he was thinking one of those would be the main culprit but since I don't have either in my system we will do the testing for hepatitis and go from there, he also said it could be from a fatty liver which I guess could be from my poor diet, I don't eat a lot of fried food or anything but do drink a lot of Coke which I know is not good for me.  So, back to the lymph node, I asked him if he thinks that it could be swollen from the liver and he said he wasn't quite sure but possibly, or that it could be swollen from a problem going on within that individual lymph node and said we may just want to biopsy it after a while anyway if it's still swollen.  I'm very curious to see your opinion if you think the lymph node could be swollen from this liver problem or if not, what steps you think I should take for further investigation into the lymph node since my blood coutns were ok.  Do you think I should have a CT scan for the node or maybe just take his suggestion and wait a few weeks to see if it goes down and if not then to a biopsy?  I feel thankful that it isn't looking like lymphoma, but am still scared about the cause of the swelling and now about what's causing a problem with my liver.  It seems like my body is falling apart!  Thanks again for your constant support and help, it means the world to me.  Look forward to hearing your views on these results!!  Take care!

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi hilyanne, I am glad to hear that at least part of your labwork came back normal. A hepatits screen should identify if this is the culprit of the elevated liver enzymes. Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease may be caused by a number of reasons. For example, Hepatitis, certain medications, high triglicerides, obesity, diabetes, etc. Triglycerides are also elevated by a number of reasons, diet related, diabetes, heredity, etc. Gout is a form of arthritis usually characterized by sudden severe attacks of pain, redness and tenderness in the joints, typically the great toe. Uric acid levels aren't excreted properly and essentially uric crystals deposit in the joints causing the pain. If the hepatits screen results are negative, an abdominal ultrasound should help to identify if you indeed have a fatty liver. Have the labwork, inquire about the ultrasound. If there is no reduction in size of the lymph nodes over the next couple of weeks I would certainly be inclined to still suggest the CT scan and biopsy because there may be connection to the elevated levels........ Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi hilyanne, Good news about the hepatitis screen! I am happy to hear this information. Lymph nodes - If the enlarged lymph nodes were located in your pelvis or groin region then it would be possible to attribute it to the IUD. However, given the location, I would be more inclined to consider that this is not related. Now in regards to it affecting your liver......I have not accessed any literature or research that link a Paragard copper IUD to elevated liver enzymes. This is not to say that it doesn't exist but again, I have not found any research linking one to the other. The amount of Tylenol did not exceed the recommended dosage so unless liver disease was present before, this probably could not be the culprit either. Inquire about the scans, the ultrasound of the liver and the CT scan as well. I will watch for your updates. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi hilyanne, My apologies in the delay in answering your post. In my opinion I still think the lymph node needs evaluated. Sometimes it's difficult to determine the exact cause of a fatty liver. Numerous things may contribute to a fatty liver, obesity, elevated triglycerides, diabetes, insulin resistance, etc. Eating fatty foods alone would most likely not cause a fatty liver. It may be to your benefit to also be evaluated by an Endocrinologist, to evaluate for any metabolic disorders......As for your weight and pregnancy, it may take the same amount of time to reduce it as it did to acquire it, and that amount of time has not yet been exceeded. The liver problems may be connected to the enlarged spleen. Some disorders that may cause spleen enlargement are certain infections, autoimmune disorders, blood disorders, myeloproliferative disorders, hemolytic anemia's, etc. Now, I have a question for you, have you had any problems with low blood sugar that you are aware of? Symptoms of nausea, tremors, sweating, etc., that improve with intake of food? If so then I would have to be inclined to consider for example, a glycogen storage disease.....My opinion, have the evaluation by the Gastroenterologist, inquire about an Endocrinologist, and have the CT Scan. I will await a follow up post from you. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi A77angel, It's perfectly fine that you added your post here :) A CT Scan is a very useful diagnostic tool but not the only tool used in assessment or evaluation of lymph nodes. Can you tell me when you had this test completed? Have you had a referral to a Surgeon for a 2nd opinion regarding whether or not the lymph nodes appear suspicious? An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2]. The jugular lymph nodes lie both on top of and beneath the sternocleidomastoid muscles (SCM) on either side of the neck, from the angle of the jaw to the top of the clavicle. They drain the tongue, tonsil, pinna, parotid. Common causes of enlargement include pharyngitis organisms, rubella. Consistency of nodes are important findings. Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin. Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time. Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. If constitutional symptoms are present this would also raise concerns.  If lymph node enlargement persists after a period of observation (generally 3-4 weeks) increases in size rather than decreases despite treatment, you should seek medical attention for further investigations using ultrasonography and FNAC or an excisional biopsy. Ultrasound is a useful imaging modality in assessment of cervical lymph nodes. Distribution of nodes, grey scale and power Doppler sonographic features are useful to identify the cause of cervical lymphadenopathy. Useful grey scale features include size, shape, status of echogenic hilus, echogenicity, micronodular appearance, intranodal necrosis and calcification. Adjacent soft tissue edema and matting are particularly useful to identify tuberculosis. Useful power Doppler features include vascular pattern and displacement of vascularity. Ultrasonography can be combined with fine needle aspiration cytology in which a sample of cells from the lymph node is aspirated using a needle and examined under the microscope.  Ultrasound is a useful imaging modality in evaluation of cervical lymphadenopathy because of its high sensitivity (98%) and specificity (95%) when combined with fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC).[3] I would strongly suggest discussing the above with your physician. I hope this has been somewhat helpful. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.  3.Baatenburg de Jong RJ, Rongen RJ, Verwoerd CD, van Overhagen H, Lameris JS, Knegt P. Ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of neck nodes. Arch Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg 1991;117:402-4.

title: Enlarged lymph nodes in neck PLEASE HELP ME
content: Hi, I am a 28 year old female, no past surgeries. Diagnosed with fibromyalgia last year, and recently had a baby 6 months ago not on any medication and not much on family history other then Empazyma and I do beleive there was some kind of "womanly cancer" on my father's side somewhere.  Here is my problem, About 2 weeks ago I started having pain in both shoulders, fatique and general achy joints which I beleived was due to the fibro. Well 1 night last week I was rubbing my shoulders and I noticed a lump right near my left collar bone.. I looked it up on the net and of course I see nothing but CANCER.. Apparently this is one of the worst places to have a swollen lymph? I went to GP, who felt this was nothing to be concerned about I requested blood work anyway and I referral to a specialist, he sent me to an ENT.. who felt the same way he did.. no concern.. but because I was so upset he agreed to send me for an MRI with contrast...  Doc said blood work came back fine, and the report of the scan says...... 2 small lesions were found in the supraclavical area, these lesion are totally non-specific most likely 2 tiny lymph nodes, they measure 4-5 mm and he had also said that simiulair nodes were found on the other side as well as in my neck. Now these other nodes I can not feel. (ont he right side) The one I can feel is only felt when I rub it, it rolls up on top of the collar bone and then once I move my finger it will roll right back down. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi jaime4297, I can certainly understand your concern. Keep in mind that lymph node enlargement has also been associated with Fibromyalgia.  Size: An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2]. Clinical features:  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. Location: although the area that you have indicated is disconcerting, lymph node enlargement may also be due to infection related causes as stated above. The left supraclavicular lymph node is located on the left side in the hollow above the clavicle, just lateral to where it joins the sternum. It drains the thorax, abdomen via thoracic duct. Common causes of enlargement include lymphoma, thoracic or retroperitoneal cancer, bacterial or fungal infection.  Again, an increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. If your diagnostic studies and evaluations have not been alarming to your physicians at this point I would not be overly concerned.  Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi jaime4297,  As posted previously, sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm). Keep in mind that 4-5 mm is smaller than 1 cm. Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue). Lymph nodes enlarge as a result of even apparently insignificant bacterial/viral infections and indicate a normal body response that the immune system is functioning appropriately. I would not be overly concerned at this point. Best wishes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The axillary lymph nodes are located in the axillae (arm pits). They drain the arm, thoracic wall, breast. Common causes of enlargement include infections, cat-scratch disease, lymphoma, breast cancer, silicone implants, brucellosis, melanoma.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter.[1]  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.  In primary care settings, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer (whether indolent or not) versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40.[2]  Low grade lymphoma is a disease of the older population.  All in all it seems that clinical suspicion that you have low grade lymphoma is rather low.  Ultrasound is a useful imaging modality in assessment of lymph nodes. Distribution of nodes, grey scale and power doppler sonographic features are useful to identify the cause of lymphadenopathy.   Useful grey scale features include size, shape, status of echogenic hilus, echogenicity, micronodular appearance, intranodal necrosis and calcification. Adjacent soft tissue edema and matting are particularly useful to identify tuberculosis. Useful power doppler features include vascular pattern and displacement of vascularity.  Best regards.  References: ========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58. 2. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Congratulations! It seems that after being examined by several doctors and an oncologist that your current risk of have cancerous lymph nodes is likely zero!  Cancer (or lymphoma) of the lymph nodes is actually quite a rare event when compared with inflammation.  To answer your question concerning the mode of progression of lymphoma it tends to do both. It progresses within a lymph node and spreads to neighboring lymph nodes.  Regarding the use of antiperspirants they are not linked with cancer according to the literature and will not cause enlargement of the lymph nodes on their own. They may be irritant if there is an infection of the skin in the arm pits due to another cause (such as from shaving), this may help cause an enlarged benign lymph node.  The normal size of enlarged lymph nodes in the inguinal region can reach 1.5 cm (as opposed to 1cm in most other regions). So there is nothing to worry about there either.  Just keep an eye on your lymph node size and number. Be patient and wait until you are sure there is a significant increase in size or number. Should you witness a definite progression or new symptoms arise you should contact your physician for follow up.  Best regards.

author: jypsy_rose_lee  Guest Posts: 17 Joined: Sat Jan 14, 2006 9:47 pm Location: Missouri
title: Question concerning stemcell transplant:
content: Which is a more servere type of transplant an Allogeneic or an Autologous transplant? Is your chances of dieing from an infection greater when using a doner's stemcells? Thanks for the information.                 Mary
posted_time: Post  by jypsy_rose_lee » Thu May 04, 2006 10:14 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi jypsy_rose_lee, The essential difference between Autologous bone marrow transplantation and Allogeneic bone marrow transplantation is Autologous involves hematopoietic stem cells from your own body which may be treated to remove any lingering cancer cells, and frozen for storage until after the chemotherapy/radiation treatments are complete and then returned to the body.  Allogeneic transplant are healthy cells from a suitably matched donor that are introduced into the body after chemotherapy/radiation treatments are completed. As a general rule autologous transplant may be associated with fewer serious side effects than an allogenic transplant because the cells come from your own body. The physician makes the determination of which type of transplant to use based on many factors, ie, age, overall health, availability of a suitable donor, and cancer type. However, it's important to keep in mind that in some cases an autologous transplant may be less effective than an allogeneic transplant in treating certain kinds of cancer and again is based on the determination of the physician and above factors. I hope this has been somewhat helpful. Best wishes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi katsusand, Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2]. Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. The body has approximately 600 lymph nodes, but only those in the submandibular, axillary or inguinal regions may normally be palpable in healthy people [3]. Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" again, refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. Night sweats, the description I can give, is waking up in the middle of the night with your clothes or bedding soaked. Of course an evaluation by your physician is warranted if you are still experiencing symptoms. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is a significant finding. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9. 3. Goroll AH, May LA, Mulley AG Jr. Primary care medicine: office evaluation and management of the adult patient. 2d ed. Philadelphia: Lippincott, 1987.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I hope your therapy is going well.  NHL could lead to several abnormalities in a chest x-ray. You may see round opacities in the center of the midline of the x-ray which could be due to hilar lymph node enlargement or a mediastinal mass.  It can also cause patches in the periphery of the lung fields which would be due to infiltration.   Some cases have bright white patches in the lower lung fields tapering upwards and this denotes fluid in the pleural sac (pleural effusion).  There may be other more rare presentations.  Best regards.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello BUSCHCLUB, I am sorry to hear that you have been through so much. Sometimes cases are like that, though. They present with significant symptoms, you do all the tests and they come back normal. The policy in such cases is to wait and see. To put the patient under observation so that as soon as the underlying disease presents itself with a clinically significant finding you can catch and treat it. In your case that means your lymph node swelling. If it is indeed as large as you describe it to be that is clinically significant. A lymph node biopsy may give us a definitive diagnosis which will enable your doctors to treat you.  It is difficult to tell for sure what the possible diagnosis is. Your question is if this could be a lymphoma. Its possible but not so likely. You do not present with any other lymph node enlargements (although this is more common in Hodgkin's disease). You also do not have constitutional symptoms such fever, night sweats and weight loss. It is still possible that it may turn out to be lymphoma. Apart from lymphomas some cancers of GI tract may spread to the supraclavicular lymph node (above the collar bone). Based on the pathology obtained from your lymph node your doctors may request further evaluation of the GI tract or another CT scan, tumor markers or repeat the colonoscopy. Its even difficult to tell for sure if this is a malignancy or not. Being of young age certainly decreases the likelihood of malignant disease. It could turn out to be a condition that is unrelated to your GI problems such as an infection or granulomatous diseases (ie, tuberculosis or sarcoidosis). You have waited long enough, I think its best not to jump to any conclusions and wait a little longer to find out what this really is. Please keep us posted. Best regards,

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi altinure, When you state submental are you referring to under the chin? The submental lymph node is located just below the chin. It drains the lower lip, floor of mouth, teeth, submental salivary gland, tip of tongue, skin of cheek. Common causes of enlargement include mononucleosis syndromes, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, dental pathology such as periodontitis. The posterior cervical lymph nodes extend in a line posterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscles but in front of the trapezius, from the level of the mastoid bone to the clavicle (on the side of the neck near the back). They drain the scalp and neck, skin of arms and pectorals, thorax, cervical and axillary nodes. Common causes of enlargement include tuberculosis, lymphoma, head and neck malignancy. Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin. Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. Regarding your wisdom teeth, your orthodontist would be in the best position to identify if there was available space for your teeth to come in without difficulty. As you can see from the above information, yes, lymph node enlargement may be associated with dental disorders etc.  If in a period of observation (3-4 weeks) including treatment with a course of antibiotics is ineffective and lymph nodes continue to enlarge, this would warrant other diagnostic studies. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. I hope you find this information helpful. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello jenny2, Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2]. Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. However, in one series [3] of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2. These studies were performed in referral centers, and conclusions may not apply in primary care settings.   To answer your question about the rate of growth in lymphoma is difficult. This is because there are indolent (slowly growing) lymphomas and aggressive (rapidly growing) lymphomas. The point is that in your case the lymph nodes do not seem to be growing at all. You do not seem to be complaining of any other symptoms either. My impression is that you do not have to worry about a thing. Have a great Xmas!  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.  3. Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. Node size is used as a clinical alert that more accurate investigations need to be performed. In your case they were performed.   A FNAC is not definitive and a CT scan is not definitive for lymphoma; a biopsy is. However, the combination of both a CT and FNAC are very accurate. CT does not only report the size of the lymph nodes there are other characteristics that would help define a benign from a malignant lymph node.  Benign lymph tissue is not the same as reactive hyperplasia. Benign lymph tissue means what it says, that there is nothing abnormal seen. This would be the case after benign hyperplasia has had a chance to resolve for example.  At this stage, I would advise you not to worry. Keep an eye on your lymph node and if anything new should arise inform your doctor. Nothing more needs to be done.  Best regards.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi stacylin, Please confirm the nature of your finding by direct clinical examination by your physician. It is probably a lymph node it occurs in a lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by your physician. Palpation is the first step to confirm the presence of a lymph node enalrgement, followed by ultrasonography and CT scan. PET scans have been reported in some studies to yield better results than CT scan but they are very expensive and not always available. The postauricular lymph nodes are located behind the ears. They drain the external auditory meatus, pinna, scalp. Common causes of enlargement include local infection. Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders). Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened. Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time. Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses. Sometimes, following infection (even seemingly mild ones) lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. I would suggest an evaluation by your physician. He/she may elect to observe the area in question over a three to four week period. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations would be a significant finding. If after a period of observation, the area remains questionable, other diagnostics are warranted. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi stacylin, I am glad to hear you went in for an evaluation :) The purpose for the antibiotic therapy is, if there happens to be an underlying or unidentified infection causing the lymph node enlargement the course of antibiotics should decrease th size of the lymph node. The purpose for the follow up in two weeks is to evaluate the effectiveness of the antibiotics and to also evaluate for any changes, appearance, size, consistency, etc. of the lymph node (serial examinations). The application of warmth if the enlargement is due to an inflammatory process may decrease the current size. I hope this makes some sense and is somewhat helpful. I also hope that you will post an update when your time permits. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi stacylin, Bloodwork is certainly a useful study but it can't actually diagnose Lymphoma, but essentially reveals that "something" is abnormal. A standard CBC will identify if there are abnormal cells or unusual counts present. Also a test, LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase) may also become elevated with cancer activity but is elevated for other reasons as well. The true way to diagnose lymphoma is by performing a biopsy. This will be examined by a pathologist. When you go in to the office for a follow up, just ask your physician what lab tests are done for indications for abnormalities. If you let her know that you would like to make informed decisions and would appreciate any information she can provide, I'm sure that will be tactful enough not to cause any offense. In my opinion, if there is enough concern by her to refer you to an ENT, I am sure that she will provide you with the requested information as well as most likely order standard lab tests. I hope you continue to post updates as your time permits. Thank you by the way for the very kind comments. They are very sincerely appreciated. Oddly enough we are nearly neighbors! Best wishes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

content: Hi stacylin, A CBC is helpful in evaluating essentially over all health. It reveals abnormalities that may indicate an infectious origin, some disease states, abnormalities in red blood cells or levels of hemoglobin, indicating anemia, iron deficiency, etc. An ENT is a specialist of the ears, nose and throat. Taking into consideration, where the lymph node enlargement is located, and conditons they are familiar with (both benign and malignant) if a surgical procedure is indicated for removal that would be the specialist you would want to do a procedure in that area (if that makes sense) simply because it's their specialty area. Essentially what I am saying, is you wouldn't want a plumber working on your car. Specialist physicians are experts in specific areas. Please keep us posted :) Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi mleydeck, Generally speaking, lymph nodes that fluctuate in size typically indicate an inflammatory or infections process. The jugular lymph nodes lie both on top of and beneath the sternocleidomastoid muscles (SCM) on either side of the neck, from the angle of the jaw to the top of the clavicle. They drain the tongue, tonsil, pinna, parotid. Common causes of enlargement include pharyngitis organisms, rubella. The postauricular lymph nodes are located behind the ears. They drain the external auditory meatus, pinna, scalp. Common causes of enlargement include local infection. The suboccipital lymph node is located at the junction between the back of the head and neck. It drains the scalp and head. Common causes of enlargement also include local infection. Consistency of lymph nodes are important. Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Again suppurant nodes may be fluctuant (waver in size). The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Essentially, if lymph nodes continue to enlarge despite treatment with antibiotic therapy or present with continued enlargement upon serial examinations this would be a significant finding. The cardiologist should be able to determine chest pressure, shortness of breath, and dizziness are of a cardiac origin or related to the use of the birth control medication. I hope this information is helpful. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  It would be highly unlikely if your doctor suspected something serious that he would leave you without further investigations.   As far as I could tell you were describing the inguinal lymph nodes.   The inguinal lymph nodes are situated in the crease between the leg and pelvis (more on the outside of that crease, ie, laterally). They drain the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal. Common causes of enlargement include infections of the leg or foot, STDs (eg, herpes simplex virus, gonococcal infection, syphilis, chancroid, granuloma inguinale, lymphogranuloma venereum), lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].  I don't think there's any reason for concern.  Best regards.  References: ========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58. 2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

author: fxtrader  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Feb 24, 2006 1:27 pm
title: persistent, slightly swollen neck glands, nearly 2 years
content: Hello, I am a 29 year old male.  About 2 years ago, a couple of weeks after returning from a trip overseas (not sure if that's relevant), I noticed the glands on the side of my neck  (under jaw) were swollen.  I could not see them when holding my head in a normal positions, but I could see them when I turned my head to the side and especially when I cocked my head to the side and back (first noticed them while shaving my neck one day).  They pulsate with my heartbeat, visibly.  I had absolutely no other symptoms or ailments (and still haven't).  No other nodes in my body are swollen.  They are completely painless, firm, moveable, and seem to cause me very little problem other than I am so worried because I don't know what it could be.  About 1 month after noticing them, I went to a general practicioner.  He basically said it was nothing to worry about, noting that they were only slightly enlarged (he said the size of a "pea" but to me it seems more like the size of a marble), and he said he could move them.  He guessed it was a localized infection and prescribed amoxicillin (spelling?) antibiotic.  They did not help at all - no change.  About two months later (about 3.5 months after I first noticed them), I went back again.  Again he told me not to worry, but I talked him into doing blood count test.  The count was normal across the board, nothing unordinary.  Since then, I've tried not to worry, but the lumps have remained unchanged.   I did not go back to the GP after that because I had dental work that I had been putting off, and I thought perhaps that may have been the cause.  I had a root canal performed and a temporary filling put in about 3 or 4 months before noticing the lumps.  I was supposed to go back to get a permant crown, but I put it off until 1.5 months ago.  They had to redo the filling (they said it had cracks in it) and then they put on the crown.  After that, I did notice the lumps go down just a tiny fraction for about a week, but they've since returned to the previous size...thus, I ruled out that this tooth had caused the lumps.  I smoke, and the doctor told me that this may cause the nodes to swell, but I smoked a long time before and never had enlarged nodes.  My concern is also one of timing, because I noticed them after returning from overseas.  So, to my way of thinking, it seemed I may have contracted something overseas...or maybe the timing is coincidental.  The only other thing I did not note is that I recently checked my blood pressure and it was high )aroudn 144 over 92).  Please help.  I desperately need some direction.  Thanks. Les

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi fxtrader, In your post you stated the enlarged lymph nodes were located under the jaw. Did you mean directly under the jaw or located farther down the neck? Here are two of the locations and some information regarding each of them. The submandibular lymph nodes are located along the underside of the jaw on either side. They drain the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. Common causes of enlargement include infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx. The jugular lymph nodes lie both on top of and beneath the sternocleidomastoid muscles (SCM) on either side of the neck, from the angle of the jaw to the top of the clavicle. They drain the tongue, tonsil, pinna, parotid. Common causes of enlargement include pharyngitis organisms, rubella. There are particular causes of enlargement of lymph nodes related to traveling to specific areas but typically there are other symptoms related as well. Consistency of a lymph node is also important. Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant (wavering). The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses. It is also important to remember that sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Taking into consideration that there has been minimal changes over an extended amount of time and the areas in question have not consistently shown enlargement and continued doing so would be much less cause for concern and indicate most likely a benign nature. I hope you find this information helpful. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Madeepooh, A physician can evaluate the texture or consistency of a lymph node and discern whether it feels related to a benign or malignant process. Lymph nodes related to an infectious or inflammatory process may wax and wane and not return to the size of a pre-infectious state. Essentially, sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. Lymph nodes that do not decrease in size and continue to enlarge despite treatment with anitbiotics etc., are more suspicious in nature. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. If your child has had evaluations, no constitutional symptoms, ie, significant weight loss, night sweats, fatigue, etc., are present, with the above mentioned waxing and waning in size, verses consistent enlargement, in my opinion, I would be inclined to consider that the symptom is most likely related to the recurrent infections and is a benign process. Keep in mind that the lymphatic system is designed as a filter for bacterial/viral infections and mild enlargement typically means that the body is functioning appropriately. If you remain concerned however, have a physician's evaluation. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Andilous, As for the cream you are using for eczema, there are  preparations which you should be using for this condition, not an anti-fungal preparation since it apparently is not caused by a fungus or this symptoms would have disappeared long before now. The back pain and neck stiffness may be related to the weight lifting and you should decrease the weight as it appears to be too strenuous. Sometimes people make the error of lifting to much to soon causing muscle strains. Re-injury occurs because the weight isn't reduced to a more tolerable level. Now for the "lump". Please confirm the nature of your finding by direct clinical examination by your physician. It is probably a lymph node it occurs in a lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by your physician. The posterior cervical lymph nodes extend in a line posterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscles but in front of the trapezius, from the level of the mastoid bone to the clavicle (on the side of the neck near the back). They drain the scalp and neck, skin of arms and pectorals, thorax, cervical and axillary nodes. Common causes of enlargement include tuberculosis, lymphoma, head and neck malignancy. Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time. However, keep in mind that sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. If you have had a recent infection, treated with antibiotic therapy, and the "lump" has not decreased in size, and continues to enlarge, I would suggest that you have a re-evaluation by your physician to rule out any disorder aside from infection. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: I believe I have lymphoma
content: Hello, I am a 25 year old female with a few problems.  In November 2004 I went to see my P.A., due to a enlarged node in my neck.  She ordered CBC w/Diff, and Z-pack.  When I went back I had 3 additional nodes,(Right side of neck there are 2 nodes "stuck" together, feels like a peanut shell) no change to first (1 behind ear,3 on neck).  Blood work was fine.  Referred to ENT.  ENT confirmed nodes, and I also have Vocal cord nodules.  I also was experiencing extreme fatige, weakness, and shortness of breath.  11 months later she scheduled a CT w/ Contrast.  Results:  I have multiple enlarged nodes.  Wanted to perform biopsy, but after a thorough review of my sypmtoms she wants me to go to a new doctor for a physical.  I now have another enlarged node supraclavical area.  (I don't have medical and I cannot find any doctor which will work off payment plans.)  My S.O.B. is growing worse.  I cannot walk 10 feet w/o becoming short of breath, and I have to yawn to feel as though I am getting enough oxygen.  After all this I picked up my medical records and compared my blood work form 2002, and 2004 and the change was my lymphocyte count.  21.7% 2002, 47.3% 2004.  That seems like a pretty big difference.  I am getting extremely worried, as I know something is definitely wrong.  Any help or information would be greatly appreciated.  (All nodes are fixed, non tender.  This has now been going on for 15 months.)  If this were only a reuslt of a past infection would I  be developing more for no apparent reason?  And wouldn't the antibiotics stop the swelling of the other 3 before the developed if they were due to an infection?

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  You certainly need a proper evaulation to rule out the possibility of lymphoma. I cannot think of anything to suggest regarding your financial problems. I will forward this to my colleagues for any suggestions they may have.  You could discuss this problem your P.A. and insist on getting the biopsy done since any other options are not available at the moment.  Regarding your lymphocyte count I wouldn't worry too much about that if your absolute lymphocyte count is not elevated. According to your results there is a minor increase in your current lymphocyte percentage. This condition could be what is known as relative lymphocytosis.   Absolute lymphocytosis may be defined as an increase in blood lymphocytes above 4,000/mm3. Relative lymphocytosis occurs when there is an increased percentage of circulating lymphocytes, but the absolute number does not exceed 4,000/mm3.   Relative, rather than absolute, leukocytosis occurs in a number of clinical situations, such as infancy, viral infections, connective tissue diseases, thyrotoxicosis and Addison's disease. Splenomegaly causes relative lymphocytosis as a result of splenic sequestration of granulocytes.   Best regards.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The inguinal lymph nodes are situated in the crease between the leg and pelvis (more on the outside of that crease, ie, laterally). They drain the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal. Common causes of enlargement include infections of the leg or foot, STDs (eg, herpes simplex virus, gonococcal infection, syphilis, chancroid, granuloma inguinale, lymphogranuloma venereum), lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].  Concerning your night sweats, they are clinically significant when they are drenching in nature.  A borderline ANA test is of little significance alone.   To diagnose lupus the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) has issued a list of 11 criteria for the diagnosis of this disease. These include malar rash (rash over the cheeks), discoid rash (red raised patches), photosensitivity, oral ulcers, nonerosive arthritis (two or more peripheral joints), serositis (pleuritis or pericarditis), renal disorder, neurologic disorder (seizures (convulsions) and/or psychosis), hematologic disorder (hemolytic anemia or leukopenia or lymphopenia or thrombocytopenia), antinuclear antibody positivity, immunologic disorder (positive anti-double stranded anti-DNA test, positive anti-Sm test, positive antiphospholipid antibody such as anticardiolipin, or false positive VDRL syphilis test).  A person should have four or more of these symptoms to suspect lupus. The symptoms do not all have to occur at the same time.  Given the limitations of the internet as a diagnostic tool, I urge you to refer to your doctor for a proper clinical evaluation.  Best regards.  References: ========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58. 2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

title: small lump in groin

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Chemotherapy has become curative for many patients with advanced stages of Hodgkin’s disease.  A doxorubicin-containing regimen, such as ABVD or ABVD alternating with MOPP, is the treatment of choice for patients presenting with stage III or IV disease, as demonstrated by a randomized phase III trial undertaken by the Cancer and Leukemia Group B (CALGB).  ABVD: doxorubicin + bleomycin + vinblastine + dacarbazine.  MOPP: mechlorethamine + vincristine + procarbazine + prednisone.  This trial showed higher complete response rates with ABVD and ABVD/MOPP (82% and 83%, respectively) than with MOPP alone (65%).  Up to one-third of patients with stage III or IV disease will relapse, usually within the first 3 years after therapy.  For patients who experience a relapse after initial combination chemotherapy, prognosis is determined more by the duration of the first remission than by the specific induction or salvage combination chemotherapy regimen.    Patients whose initial remission after chemotherapy was longer than 1 year (late relapse) have long-term survivals with salvage chemotherapy of 22% to 71%.   Patients whose initial remission after chemotherapy was shorter than 1 year (early relapse) do much worse and have long-term survivals of 11% to 46%.  In addition to duration after remission, resistant disease (see below), the presence B symptoms at relapse and extranodal disease are significant prognostic factors.  A variety of treatment regimens have been used for patients with relapsed Hodgkin’s disease. In addition to MOPP or ABVD in patients who received the opposite regimen initially, a number of other treatments have been used:   BEACOPP: bleomycin + etoposide + doxorubicin + cyclophosphamide + vincristine + procarbazine + prednisone.  COPP/ABVD: cyclophosphamide + vincristine + procarbazine + prednisone/doxorubicin + bleomycin + vinblastine + dacarbazine.  Stanford V: doxorubicin + vinblastine + mechlorethamine + etoposide + vincristine + bleomycin + prednisone.  MINE: mitoxantrone + ifosfamide + etoposide.  Best regards.
