author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The submental lymph node is located just below the chin. It drains the lower lip, floor of mouth, teeth, submental salivary gland, tip of tongue, skin of cheek. Common causes of enlargement include mononucleosis syndromes, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, dental pathology such as periodontitis.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.  If your nodes remain less than 1cm in size and no other symptoms arise you are safe. If you are concerned or anything new should arise you should contact your physician.  Best regards.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Lucy24, The inguinal lymph nodes are situated in the crease between the leg and pelvis (more on the outside of that crease, i.e. laterally). They drain the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal. Common causes of enlargement include infections of the leg or foot, STDs (e.g., herpes simplex virus, gonococcal infection, syphilis, chancroid, granuloma inguinale, lymphogranuloma venereum), lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague. Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant (meaning enlarge then decrease in size). The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses. Lymph nodes that continue to enlarge upon serial examinations would be significant, or enlargement that would persist despite antibiotic therapy. Taking into consideration that the areas are 1 cm or less in size and have decreased in size over a period of time rather than continuing to enlarge in size, would in my opinion most likely be related to a nonmalignant process. Since these areas have been evaluated by your physician, labwork has been normal, and you are experiencing no constitutional symptoms, I would not be overly concerned at this point. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The left supraclavicular lymph node is located on the left side in the hollow above the clavicle, just lateral to where it joins the sternum. It drains the thorax, abdomen via thoracic duct. Common causes of enlargement include lymphoma, thoracic or retroperitoneal cancer, bacterial or fungal infection.  You are right about a supraclavicular lymph node enlargement being more of a concern especially in those older than 40 years of age. However, this refers to a clinically significant lymph node enlargement. Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter.[1,2] Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  If you are still concerned why don't you discuss with your doctor the possibility of getting a CT scan or a biopsy.  References: ========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The submandibular lymph nodes are located along the underside of the jaw on either side. They drain the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. Common causes of enlargement include infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx.  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  In primary care settings, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40.[1]  Given the limitations of the internet in clinical evaluation, you are advised to seek medical attention. If after evaluation the lymph node enlargement is unexplained, then your doctor may choose to put you under observation for 3 to 4 weeks and then re-evaluate these nodes. The doctor may also recommend a course of antibiotics based on his evaluation.  References: ========== 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Lymphomatoid Papulosis is a lymphoproliferative disease that manifests itself by recurrent papular erruptions on the skin. There has been debate about whether it should be categorized as a malignancy or not since it does not have the potential to spread and can undergo spontaneous resolution (cure).  The only thing that should be of concern is that there have been reports of a rare association between Lymphomatoid Papulosis and lymphoma. Again its a sufficiently rare disease that no conclusions about this association can be confirmed.  Very few people if any have died as a result of this disease.  Best regards.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi ontariogirl, There are indications as to what causes lymph node enlargement that a physician may identify based on the location, how a lymph node feels (consistency), and constitutional symptoms, etc.. For example, the suboccipital lymph node is located at the junction between the back of the head and neck. It drains the scalp and head. Common causes of enlargement include local infection. The axillary lymph nodes are located in the axillae (arm pits). They drain the arm, thoracic wall, breast. Common causes of enlargement include infections, cat-scratch disease, lymphoma, breast cancer, silicone implants, brucellosis, melanoma. Due to the possibility of an infectious etiology (and to rule this possibility out) is most likely the reason for assessing for scratches, cuts, etc.  Consistency-Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. The fact that you are having constitutional symptoms, weight loss and fatigue are reasons for concern and would raise suspicion and certainly warrant further diagnostic studies. I hope that when your time permits you will consider posting an update. Best wishes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi ontariogirl, Lymph nodes that decrease in size are typically related to an infectious process. A lymph node that continues to enlarge, is fixed, and stone hard are suspicious and that is most likely the reason a biopsy is suggested as this should provide a definitive answer to the causative factor. The constitutional symptoms that are present are certainly concerning. You may want to call your physicians office back and if no sooner appointment for the biopsy is currently available then request that if there is a cancellation you would appreciate being moved into there slot. A period of 3-4 weeks of observation of a lymph node to identify if there is enlargement upon serial examinations is a general practice so keep in mind that this is the same amount of time until your currently schedule biopsy. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

content: Hello,  You are right it would be impossible to assess your condition properly over the internet. However, I think from your description it could represent an enlarged axillary lymph node.   Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  I think you should get it checked as soon as possible and not wait for a whole week if it is indeed as inflammed as you describe. Hopefully it will not turn out to be an abscess.  Best regards.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The submandibular lymph nodes are located along the underside of the jaw on either side. They drain the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. Common causes of enlargement include infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  If its not larger than 1cm and not increasing in size and there are no new symptoms then its probably nothing to worry about. Otherwise you should inform your doctor right away.  Best regards.

title: persistent enlarged nodes - very worried
content: Hi, I am 33 years old, generally healthy except for asthma and recurring sinus/bronchitis infections (3-4 times a year). For the past several  months (since May 2005), I have been under follow-up for persistently enlarged lymph nodes in my neck and underarms. The largest neck node is currently 2 cm x 1 cm (upper Left anterior triangle, right under the jaw towards the back) and in may was 19 x .8 cm, i.e. not much smaller. The largest axillary nodes are 1.4x.6 on the left side and 1.4x.6 on the right side, and while they haven't significantly increased in size since may, there do seem to be more enlarged ones than there were previously. I also have a few palpable supraclavicular nodes on both sides, which have not changed in size over the months, and are still no greater than .9 cm. I have had repeat blood tests, including c reactive protein and esr (all normal)  as well as repeat ultrasounds to follow the nodes, all of which stated they appeared non-malignant. I also had an abdominal ultrasound which was normal.  I am supposed to go back to the surgeon on tuesday with my recent ultrasound results, and am really really scared. I don't know whether I should push for biopsy, and I don't know what to think.   I have read all the stuff on the net, and my understanding is that palpable supraclavicular nodes are suspect and should be biopsied, even if they are less than 1 cm.   Please help!

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi littlebugs, An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes' and feel much like "buckshot" under the skin. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy has the highest risk of malignancy, estimated as 90 percent in patients older than 40 years and 25 percent in those younger than age 40 [1]. This refers to a clinically significant lymph node enlargement. Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size.  However, nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter [2,3].  It's good to hear that to present your lab studies have been normal and the ultrasound report does not indicate malignancy. The surgeon, based on your symptoms, and the information provided in the reports will decide if a biopsy is warranted.  Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN  References: ========= 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6. 2. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  3. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

author: John L  Guest Posts: 8 Joined: Sat Dec 10, 2005 7:33 pm Location: Florida
title: Lymph node concern and question
content: I am a male, 58 years of age and in top physical condition.  6'1" 178 pounds.  I walk 10 miles a day and run about 15 miles a week.  I do weight training 1/2 hour each day.  During my annual physical in late August, my GP (his second year in practice) said my blood work indicated anemia and he felt what he thought was a swollen lymph node in my groin.  The CT scan was negative (unremarkable).  He sent me to a Hematologist/Oncologist who said everything was negative and all was okay including the slightly low red count and low hematocrit because of the athletics.  He said the he felt a "shotty" mass in my left groin but felt it was actually the inguinal ligament.  The oncologist was puzzled by my GP's referral.  That was August/Sept/ Oct. This is probably totally unrelated ( I hope) In November, I began hearing a pop in my right ear, behind the drum quite frequently.  In late December I presented with slight sinus drainage, slight pain on right side of jaw and ear and swollen gland under right side of chin.  GP said that although he could not see anything,  its an infection and prescribed Augmentin for seven days.  He said the entire lymph chain on the right side is enlarged.   The seven days have passed.  Nothing has changed or improved. The gland is still swollen and slightly tender.  There is still some slight pain on right side of jaw and ear and ear still pops.  There is slightly more pain when I press in the area of the ramus of the mandible.  I have an ever so slight sore throat on the right side, and some very mild pain on occasion up the right side of my face to the front of the ear. The symptoms seem to become more noticable as the day progresses.  I feel wonderful when I wake up in the morning.  As I think about it, I begin to notice the smptoms.    I have called my GP twice in the past two days for an appointment, but he, on both occasions said I should not see him, that it can take up to a month of the swelling to go down after an infection.  He said on both occasions that if, after a month, it is still swollen, he will CT and send me to an ENT.  I have no loss of weight or appetite.  No night sweats, no pallor, no fever or chills.  There is absolutely no history of cancer in any member of my family on either side.  Not even a suspicious mole.  I have never had my wisdom teeth removed.  A dentist told me several years ago that, "someday, you may have a problem."  Man oh man, I hate to wait a month.  This is really bothering me, physiologically, specially after the first scare.  To be honest, I am fearful because of his reaction back in August.  Any thoughts, PLEASE.  I know this is complicated but would really appreciate some additional medical thinking.  JL

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi John, I see no reason for concern at all. What doctors are concerned about is unexplained lymph node enlargement as opposed to a lymph node enlargement that appears to have a clear clinical cause.  The lymph node you described is called the submandibular lymph node. It is responsible for draining the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae and is commonly enlarged as a result of infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx (much more commonly than cancer).  Regarding size: An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].   Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be:  Firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (I. e. stuck to each other), fixed (I. e. not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.   Following infection, however, Lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  I understand your anxiety about your doctor, but if anything he was being over-cautious and not negligents. My impression, like his impression is that there is nothing to to it; however, given the limitations of the internet as a diagnostic tool and your anxiety about the efficiency of your doctor you may want to get checked out by another doctor.  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Dear John L, First of all congratulations! The CT results and the fact that the swelling is decreasing in size rules out anything serious in the lymph nodes.  I understand your concern about the subcutaneous bleeding. I am in no position to estimate the severity of this but if it is increasing in intesity and frequency you should have someone check it out. As for your question regarding leukemia. As I am sure you know leukemia is a disease of the blood and it manifests itself by producing various changes in the blood film. So a CBC that does not show any of the criteria for leukemia is definitive. I would suggest that you do a follow up CBC and consult your hematologist again. When you do meet your hematologist focus on only one problem which is the subcutaneous bleeding, ask him for an explanation and his assessment of the situation.  Keep us posted.

These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes', which is probably what you are experiencing.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].   An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.  Given that your condition does not progress and you do not develop new symptoms, have it looked at by your doctor during your next visit.  References: ========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

title: swollen lymph nodes under ears
content: Hello,  In July, I went to Venezuela and my third day there I noticed that I had some swollen glands in my neck. They didn't hurt. After a week, they didn't change so I went to see a doctor, who told me I had a throat infection, and she gave me antibiotics telling me the glands would disappear in about two weeks. I took the antibiotics (aumentín, in Spanish), but the nodes didn't go away. About a month later (middle of August), I was back home in Montreal, so I went to see my physician there. She said my lymph nodes were still a bit swollen and my throat infection wasn't completely gone. So she prescribed me another kind of antibiotics.  A week later, I moved to Los Angeles (for school), I noticed my glands were a but smaller, but still not gone,  so I went to consult a physician who referred me to an Ear Nose Throat specialist. He said I have a thyroglossal duct cyst under my chin, and the other nodes were caused by a cat scratch, and that I shouldn't worry about them, they will go away, and it didn't look at all like cancer or anything else, that blood tests weren't necessary, neither was a biopsy.  The nodes disappeared during fall, but now, since about two weeks, they came back but this time they hurt, and I have had other symptoms such as lightheadedness and slight nosebleeding. I also think I might have anemia, because I was diagnosed with low iron in my blood last year.  What should I do? The three doctors I've consulted didn't seem too worried, so I didn't do much about it. Should I go see a doctor soon? Or should I wait and see if it goes away?  Thank you.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello Christie321, Although very rare, there is a clinical entity called vertebral pseudotumor. Its not a real tumor but appears to be so in both the clinical and radiological settings.  Vertebral pseudotumors may be classified into those of vertebral origin and those of disk-space origin. Those of vertebral origin, as cited in the literature, include those related to spinal tuberculosis; synovitis, hyperostosis, and osteitis (SAPHO) syndrome; fibrous dysplasia; and osteoporotic vertebral collapse [1].  Tuberculous pseudotumors can present as destructive vertebral masses that may not radiographically appear to be of infectious origin.  The SAPHO syndrome may mimic vertebral tumors (eg, sclerotic bone tumors) because of the erosive changes with adjacent sclerosis and the hyperostosis that can appear similar to blastic vertebral metastasis [1]. In cases of SAPHO, additional lesions can be identified with conventional radiography, bone scintigraphy, CT, or MR imaging. Again, the findings may be suggestive of metastatic disease when this disease process is actually benign.  Space-occupying masses are seen in fibrous dysplasia. In such cases, T1-weighted MR images may show decreased signal intensity, and T2-weighted images may show variable signal intensity, depending on the degree of lesion ossification. Chordoma, a mass that arises from a remnant of the notochord, can also appear as a disk-space mass. These tumors occur chiefly in the occipital-cervical and sacrococcygeal regions, and they less frequently appear in the lumbar, cervical, and thoracic regions [2].   References: =========== 1. Laredo JD, Quessar AE, Bossard P, et al. Vertebral tumors and pseudotumors. Radiologic Clinics of North America 2001; 39 :137 –163. 2. Bjornsson J, Wold LE, Ebersold MJ, et al. Chordoma of the mobile spine: a clinicopathologic analysis of 40 patients. Cancer 1993; 71 :735 –740.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi christie321, Thank you for your kind words. Its more than likely that its not related to the thyroid cancer. That's my impression. First, although papillary cancer of the thyroid is an indolent disease it commonly spreads to the lymph nodes and distant spread (to lungs or bones) is very uncommon.  If suspicious the doctor could order a thyroglobulin test, although I do not really see the merit in doing this.  Second this is not a common site of metastasis in the vertebra whether be it from thyroid cancer or any other cancer. The cervical spine is the least often involved by spinal metastases (10%), followed by the lumbar spine (20%), and the thoracic spine (70%).[1] I think the excisional biopsy will be more definitive and I strongly suspect one of the pseudotumors above (including chordoma).  Please keep us posted. Best regards,  References:  ===========  1. Atanasiu JP, Badatcheff F, Pidhorz L: Metastatic lesions of the cervical spine. A retrospective analysis of 20 cases. Spine 18: 1279-1284, 1993.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello HydragonWarrior, Sometimes a lymph node enlargement is considered normal, while at other times it is not. The basis of differentiation between what is considered normal and what is not, rests on the clinical significance of the finding. Let me review a few points to clarify what is considered a clinically significant lymph node enlargement.   An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].   Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. However, in one series [3] of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2. These studies were performed in referral centers, and conclusions may not apply in primary care settings.  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Findings from a Dutch study revealed that only 10 percent of patients with unexplained adenopathy required referral to a subspecialist, 3 percent required a biopsy and only 1 percent had a malignancy.[4]  In primary care settings, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40.[4]  Given the limitations of the internet in clinical evaluation, you are advised to seek medical attention. In your case the most probable outcome of your evaluation would be to put you under observation for 3 to 4 weeks and then re-evaluate these nodes. The doctor may also recommend a course of antibiotics based on his evaluation.  If it persists after a period of observation then the patient should seek medical attention for further investigations using ultrasonography and FNAC or an excisional biopsy.  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.  3. Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82.  4. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi lsmith0517, Please confirm the nature of your finding by direct clinical examination by your physician.Palpation is the first step to confirm the presence of a lymph node enalrgement, followed by ultrasonography and CT scan. PET scans have been reported in some studies to yield better results than CT scan but they are very expensive and not always available. Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. The submandibular lymph nodes are located along the underside of the jaw on either side. They drain the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. Common causes of enlargement include infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. Your physician may want to evaluate and observe the area over a period of 3-4 weeks or prescribe a course of antibiotics if he/she feels this enlargement iis related to an infection. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Have an evaluation by your physician to identify the causative factor. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello copper_blue, Thank you for using The Doctors Lounge. Let me discuss a few points related to your question.  The right supraclavicular node drains the area of the mediastinum, lungs, esophagus and are a cause of concern since they may harbor cells from lung, retroperitoneal or gastrointestinal cancer.  Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy has the highest risk of malignancy, estimated as 90 percent in patients older than 40 years and 25 percent in those younger than age 40. [1]  Regarding size: Size: An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [2, 3]. Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. However, in one series [4] of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 (1 cm 3 1 cm) had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 (1 cm 3 1 cm to 1.5 cm 3 1.5 cm) in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2 (1.5 cm 3 1.5 cm). These studies were performed in referral centers, and conclusions may not apply in primary care settings.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (I. e. stuck to each other), fixed (I. e. not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.   Infected Lymph nodes, however, tend to be:  Firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.   Following infection, however, Lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  This last condition is probably what your doctor suspects you have.  Given your discription of further lymph node enlargement and the appearance of new suspected lymph nodes, I recommend that you contact your physician as soon as possible. The picture you describe is consistent with a shotty lymph nodes however, to rule out more serious disease a clinical examination should be repeated.  References: 1- Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6. 2- Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  3- Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.  4- Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Please let me emphasize that the 25% risk of cancer is associated with a clinically significant lymph node enlargement. That's really what you should focus on. The enlargement you describe (which I haven't seen) seems to be in the range of 1 cm. It  also seems that your doctor is not worried by any of its features on examination. If this is the case none of these statistics apply to you. I was only discussing the age factor with you earlier.  What your doctor is presuming and what I have also noted above is these nodes are probably a result of a previous viral infection. A viral infection can be accompanied by flu-like symptoms.  The fact that the lymph node has not changed in size is a good sign (again given the size of your node). For example, a supraclavicular lymph node of 2.5 cm that does not grow in size is still worriesome.   The appearance of several other lymph nodes and the absence of any other symptoms are also in favor of a benign condition.   As I said earlier, the right supraclavicular lymph node is more commonly involved in the following cancers : lung cancer, retroperitoneal or gastrointestinal cancer.   I'm sure everything will be alright. Please let me know what your doctor says.

title: [no title]
content: Dear copper_blue, Your doctor is in a better position to judge the necessity of the biopsy and since she has given you the O.K. then I think you should go for it. There are no risks as far as I know associated with the biopsy procedure. Please ask the surgeon that question as well. Also remember to get all the info you need about the size, location of the incision and if it will leave a scar or not. I should stress that this procedure is a very simple one and does not have any complications but you should get that info from your surgeon first hand. Go over all the details with him until you feel satisfied.   Best regards and let us know how it turns out.

title: Posterior cervical lymph node
content: Hi, just had a quick few questions. To start of I am a 24 year old male physically fit. I have no symptoms really beside having a small lump on my neck in the spot where the posterior cervical nodes are. It's only on my left hand side a little under my ear/hair line. The node is approx 1.2 cm long by .7 cm wide (i am guessing). I noticed it when I was using two mirrors to shave. I turned my head one way and it popped out a little. The node seems to move under the skin, is a little hard but has a little give to it. As for how long it has been there, I sort of remeber feeling it there as long as 2 years ago or more but can't be certain.  Should I be concerned?  If it was cancer, how long would it stay there before enlarging or me getting other symptoms?
posted_time: Post  by brian871 » Sat Jan 07, 2006 7:57 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello Brian871, The posterior cervical lymph nodes extend in a line posterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscles but in front of the trapezius, from the level of the mastoid bone to the clavicle (on the side of the neck near the back). They drain the scalp and neck, skin of arms and pectorals, thorax, cervical and axillary nodes.  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).   Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.   Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.   Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (usually less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Findings from a Dutch study revealed that only 10 percent of patients with unexplained adenopathy required referral to a subspecialist, 3 percent required a biopsy and only 1 percent had a malignancy.[1]  Also in the same study, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40.[1]  As you can see the overall incidence of cancer of the lymph nodes in your age group is very small.   To answer your question regarding the rate of progression, it is variable and depends mainly on the pathology of the disease. Some cancer have a very slow and indolent course while most others will develop dramatically within a period of 6 months.  Please understand that I am unable to give you a final verdict on this given the restrictions of the internet. However, my impression is its nothing to worry about. I recommend that you share your concerns with your doctor. If its worrying he could have it tested or even removed.  References: ========== 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello guymanny,  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).   Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.   Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.   Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  The first lymph node you described is probably the submandibular lymph node. The submandibular lymph nodes are located along the underside of the jaw on either side. They drain the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. Common causes of enlargement include infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx.  The suboccipital lymph node is located at the junction between the back of the head and neck. It drains the scalp and head. Common causes of enlargement include local infection.  The inguinal lymph nodes are situated in the crease between the leg and pelvis (more on the outside of that crease, ie, laterally). They drain the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal. Common causes of enlargement include infections of the leg or foot, STDs (e.g., herpes simplex virus, gonococcal infection, syphilis, chancroid, granuloma inguinale, lymphogranuloma venereum), lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].   Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. However, in one series [3] of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2. These studies were performed in referral centers, and conclusions may not apply in primary care settings.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant.  As I mentioned in another post, lymph nodes that turn out to be harboring cancer tend to be rare. Findings from a Dutch study revealed that only 10 percent of patients with unexplained adenopathy required referral to a subspecialist, 3 percent required a biopsy and only 1 percent had a malignancy.[4]  I hope you will find this information helpful.  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.  3. Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82. 4. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi hedgel, The left supraclavicular lymph node is located on the left side in the hollow above the clavicle, just lateral to where it joins the sternum. It drains the thorax, abdomen via thoracic duct. Common causes of enlargement include lymphoma, thoracic or retroperitoneal cancer, bacterial or fungal infection. Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy has the highest risk of malignancy, estimated as 90 percent in patients older than 40 years and 25 percent in those younger than age 40 [1]. This refers to a clinically significant lymph node enlargement. Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size.  However, nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter [2,3]. Generally speaking, it would be considered appropriate to observe a particular lymph node for a period of 3-4 weeks to monitor for any increase in size. Upon your physician's evaluation a course of antibiotics may be indicated as well if there are any suspicions of an underlying infection.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Keep in mind that even after an infection subsides, an enlarged lymph node related to this (even if it's trivial) may not return to it's pre-infectious state. If it persists after a period of observation then I would suggest that you  seek medical attention for further investigations by using diagnostic studies, for example, ultrasonography, FNAC or an excisional biopsy, etc. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN  References: ========= 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6. 2. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  3. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Inferno, Let me start by saying that there is not one post on this forum any more important than another and posts are answered to the best of everyone's ability by people who "volunteer" their time on this forum. With that being said, I will proceed in trying to answer your question. One of the reasons lymph nodes commonly enlarge is as a result of bacterial/viral infections because the lymphatic system is the bodies defense in fighting infection. Lymph nodes may not return to their pre-infectious size after an infection subsides. So essentially, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. A biopsy is a very definitive  procedure in determining whether a lymph node is malignant or benign in nature as is is evaluated by a specialist (Pathologist). Taking into consideration that the other lymph nodes are decreasing in size verses enlarging, in my opinion, the most likely causative factor would be viral/bacterial infection related. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: [no title]
content: Hi Inferno, It is not necessary to apologize. I just wanted you to understand that although everyone may be anxious from time to time and of course wanting their questions answered, it sometimes is very difficult to do so. If you are not experiencing constitutional symptoms such as  fatigue, malaise, fever, abdominal pain (especially on the left side), "flu-like" illness, rash, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, arthritis, renal, neurologic, hematologic disorders, bruising, conjunctivitis, sweat, shortness of breath and cough I would not be overly concerned, especially if during the period of observation of 3-4 weeks the lymph node has gone unchanged (not become larger, etc.). Call your physician's office for a re-evaluation to alleviate your fears and to assure that all is with in normal. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello LEJ1445, Thank you for your kind words. I am glad that you had it looked at. I trust that their evaluation; however, I understand your worry. Let me address a few points in your second question: As regards incidence findings from a Dutch study revealed that only 10 percent of patients with unexplained adenopathy required referral to a subspecialist, 3 percent required a biopsy and only 1 percent had a malignancy.[1] This means that cancer is actually a rare cause of lymph node enlargement.  As regards age in primary care settings, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40.[1] Meaning that this is an even rarer possibility given your age.  As regards the accuracy of the clinical examination in one study examining the presence of supraclavicular lymph node enlargement in nonsmall cell lung cancer patients - Nodes had to have a diameter of 22.3 mm or greater to be palpated in 50% of cases.[2] CT scans can detect the presence of enlarged lymph nodes in the neck with a short-axis diameter of 5 mm or greater.  The sensitivities of ultrasonography and CT did not differ significantly in detecting the presence of a lymph node enlargement.[2]  I do not think that there is a high possibility of there being cancer in your case; however if you are still worried about the node you can discuss the possibility of getting a CT scan done to confirm the nature of the finding.   References: ========= 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.  2. Hans van Overhagen, MD, PhD, Koen Brakel, MD, PhD, Mark W. Heijenbrok, MD, Jan H. L. M. van Kasteren, MD, Cees N. F. van de Moosdijk, MD, Albert C. Roldaan, MD, PhD, Ad P. van Gils, MD, PhD and Bettina E. Hansen, MSc. Metastases in Supraclavicular Lymph Nodes in Lung Cancer: Assessment with Palpation, US, and CT. Radiology 2004;232:75-80.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi majo, The axillary lymph nodes are located in the axillae (arm pits). They drain the arm, thoracic wall, breast. Common causes of enlargement include infections, cat-scratch disease, lymphoma, breast cancer, silicone implants, brucellosis, melanoma.  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Age does affect the incidence of the various causes mentioned above.  In primary care settings, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40.[1]  References: ========= 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].  Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. However, in one series [3] of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2. These studies were performed in referral centers, and conclusions may not apply in primary care settings.   Given that you do not have any risks for malignancy or any other serious condition, your doctor's decision to treat the most likely condition (infection) with anti-inflammatory drugs and antibiotics for three weeks is standard.  There are reasons for that. Findings from a Dutch study revealed that only 10 percent of patients with unexplained adenopathy required referral to a subspecialist, 3 percent required a biopsy and only 1 percent had a malignancy, the rest being attributable mostly to infection.[4]  Should any new symptoms arise, such as new lymph nodes or constitutional symptoms such as fever or rash, you should contact him/her immediately.  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.  3. Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82.  4. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Khay, The suboccipital lymph node is located at the junction between the back of the head and neck. It drains the scalp and head. Common causes of enlargement include local infection which may also include dandruff.  When a lymph node rapidly increases in size, its capsule stretches and causes pain. Pain is usually the result of an inflammatory process or suppuration, but pain may also result from hemorrhage into the necrotic center of a malignant node. The presence or absence of tenderness does not reliably differentiate benign from malignant nodes.[1]  However, constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could also suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. If you have not had an evaluation by your physician I would suggest you have this completed to identify the causative factor. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN  References: ========= 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Tinkerbell9999, The inguinal lymph nodes are situated in the crease between the leg and pelvis (more on the outside of that crease, i.e. laterally). They drain the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal. Common causes of enlargement include infections of the leg or foot, STDs (e.g., herpes simplex virus, gonococcal infection, syphilis, chancroid, granuloma inguinale, lymphogranuloma venereum), lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague.  There are many causes of generalized lymphadenopathy of which the mononucleosis type syndromes are the most common. They usually present with fatigue, malaise, fever and atypical lymphocytosis on examination of the blood picture. Splenomegaly may be present in 50% of patients due to Epstein-Barr virus infection. These cases can be diagnosed using the monospot test, IgM EA or VCA. So in answer to your question, the previous infection with "mono" may very well be resposible for lymph node enlargement in the inguinal region. Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time. Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Lymph nodes that continue to enlarge despite treatment with a course of antibiotics warrants re-evaluation, etc. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: sore lymph node related to surgery?
content: I have what I think is a sore lymph node on the left side of my neck for about a week, about the middle right next to my esophagus.  It isn't excruciatingly painful, but enough to be annoying.  It bothers me more when I turn my head to the right.   It doesn't really seem to be swollen too much but it does feel hard.    I guess I'm a little paranoid considering my husband's brother in law was just diagnosed with cancer that's spread to his lymph nodes and he's relatively young and I just want to find out if it's likely or not likely cancer.  I read that cancerous nodes usually aren't painful, so that makes me feel a bit more comfortable.  However, I can't come up with a possible cause for why it would be swollen.  I feel fine, no sore throat and I don't have any signs of an infection, cold, or flu.  The only thing I can think of is that I had my gallbladder removed due to gallstones on August 31st, almost a month ago.  Could that be related in some way?  The surgery and recovery went fine with no complications at all.     This is really worrying me due to recent events in my husband's family and I just would like to set my mind at ease a bit and find out if it's something I really need to go running to my doctor about.   It's also kind of baffling me because I don't seem to have a sign of any infection that usually causes swollen and/or sore lymph nodes.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi pj523, One of the common reasons for lymph node enlargement is bacterial/viral infections (even seemingly unapparent one's) because the lymphatic system is the bodies defense for fighting infections. This essentially means the body is functioning properly. Please confirm the nature of your finding by direct clinical examination by your physician. It is probably a lymph node it occurs in a lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by your physician.  Palpation is the first step to confirm the presence of a lymph node enalrgement, followed by ultrasonography and CT scan. PET scans have been reported in some studies to yield better results than CT scan but they are very expensive and not always available. Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Although it's not an impossibility for this enlargement to be connected to your surgery but in my opinion I would most likely relate it to another cause. Have an evaluation by your physician to identify if there is reason for concern. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Nicfrillo  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Sep 30, 2005 10:26 am Location: Moncton, NB, Canada
title: strange headaches and enlarged lymph node on left side of ne
content: I am  experiencing strange headaches that feel like muscular pain whenever I move my head and when I stand up my head throbs severly. My neck also feels very stiff at times. I have had a low grade fever and the other morning I woke up and had a very swollen lymph node on the left side of my neck. I went to see the doctor who put me on antibiotics (clindamycin) even though my WBC count was normal and told me to expect the lymph node to go down in 2 to 3 days. I am Type One diabetic and have Graves disease. I am concerned because the lymph node is swollen only on the left side, I have no evidence there is an infection, the node is not painful, I cannot move it, and it feels rubbery. I have no sore throat but have been feeling very fatigued for the past few days and have a decreased appetite. Should I be concerned?
posted_time: Post  by Nicfrillo » Fri Sep 30, 2005 10:37 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Nicfrillo, Have you had a re-evaluation regarding the lymph node enlargement since your treatment with the course of antibiotics was completed? Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin, as found in the cervical nodes of children with viral illnesses. A group of nodes that feels connected and seems to move as a unit is said to be "matted." Nodes that are matted can be either benign (e.g., tuberculosis, sarcoidosis or lymphogranuloma venereum) or malignant (e.g., metastatic carcinoma or lymphomas). The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. However, constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could also suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy. Keep in mind that lymph nodes that become enlarged due to bacterial/viral infection may not return to their pre-infectious size after the infection subsides. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. If you have had no improvement of symptoms or they have continued to worsen over a period of time I would suggest that you notify your physician for an evaluation. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello Kristen, Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Findings from a Dutch study revealed that only 10 percent of patients with unexplained adenopathy required referral to a subspecialist, 3 percent required a biopsy and only 1 percent had a malignancy.[1]  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [2,3].  Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. However, in one series [4] of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2. These studies were performed in referral centers, and conclusions may not apply in primary care settings.   Surgical dissection of the neck for a biopsy is not recommended even when the likelihood of cancer is high. The reason being it distorts the plains and may have bad effects on further management if it turns out that it is a result of cancer.  As you can see from the above information that the likelihood of cancer is not so high. If still concerned, however, and since your question relates more to the 'character of the lymph nodes', I would suggest that you seek a second clinical examination by another doctor. If they both find that the clinical features of your lymph nodes not alarming then you forget about the whole thing.   References: ========= 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6. 2. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  3. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.  4. Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82.

author: squidahoy  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Thu Sep 29, 2005 8:17 am Location: DC
title: left supraclavicle node & lump on rib cage
content: I don't really feel sick...no night sweats, fever, or fatigue, but at this point, have become frustrated with  the doctors available to me.  So, y'all are my last line of defense.  In mid-April/early May, I noticed I have a fair-sized mass on my (left) rib cage that is about 2.5-3 cm in length/1cm wide.  It started out tender but is now only very intermittently sore. It's also pretty moveable. Went to about 3 different doctors, & my bloodwork came back fine: normal white & red cell counts.  Got a chest x-ray: that came back clear, too.  Although it was still sore, they convinced me to ignore it as a lipoma.    Through August & September, things seemed to be on the road to getting better...the soreness went away although the lump stayed.  It's not grown noticeably, but hasn't gotten smaller, either. However...  Last night I found a supraclavicular lymphnode.  It's only pea-sized, and is also very mobile... but the location makes me worry.   That side of my neck & shoulder have been sore, but I really thought it was from a rather nasty flare-up of TMJD.  The node itself isn't particularly tender. I guess you could call it rubbery-feeling...not stone hard, not squishy/soft, but like, for lack of a better description, a small, dry pea.    So, should I go to the doctors again? The chest thing took about 4 visits before they'd do an x-ray.  When that came back clear, they basically dismissed me as depressive ('cause I was still worried about the lump), and shooed me out the door with some Wellbutrin.  With the new bump, should I go back again & have them look for something more serious?  Thanks so much for your advice!
posted_time: Post  by squidahoy » Thu Sep 29, 2005 8:58 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi squidahoy, Lipomas are benign fatty tumors in the subcutaneous area of the skin. These commonly are present for an extended period of time before a person actually realizes they are there. Some may grow quite large and can occur anywhere on the body. Most lipomas don't cause any symptoms but occasionally when they become large enough to interfere with adjacent muscles or encompass small blood vessels they may become tender/painful. When this occurs they can be surgically removed. Lymph node enlargement: Following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be:  Firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Although enlargement of lymph nodes in the supraclavicular area can be somewhat disconcerting, lymph nodes less than 1 cm in size are often typically of benign causes. I would suggest that if you remain concerned about the "lipoma" as well as the appearance of the supraclavicular lymph node request a referral to a surgeon for evaluation. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: tintin  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Oct 03, 2005 12:01 pm Location: Ohio
title: Puzzling symptoms for 11 months
content: My husband has been ill for almost a year now. Last November he went to the emergency room complaining of right-side pain. In the months that followed, they ruled out appendicities, crohn's disease, colon cancer (and a variety of other abdominal diseases as he had CT scans, small bowel followthroughs, and colonoscopy). They did, however, see some gall bladder enlargement and removed it in March. The symptoms, which include right-side pain (located between groin and lower rib), swollen glands only on the right side (both groin and throat and jaw), numbness in right hand and leg, right leg paralysis, extreme fatigue, and night sweats have continued and indeed appear to be getting worse by the day. He also had a series electrical tests to check nerve problems -- this too was fine. His blood work has all looked good. The last time he went to his doctor, he became concerned about the fact that the lymph glands were so big (and so big for such a long time) and raised the spectre of lymphoma. Instead of referring him to an oncologist, he is sending him to an infectious disease specialist. My questions are: 1) what would be the rationale for sending him to an infectious disease specialist, instead of an oncologist?  2) what might they be looking for? 3) does this set of symptoms seem stereotypical of anything, including lymphoma?  4) is the negative bloodwork rule out the possibility of a lymphoma diagnosis?   Any help or advice would be so wonderful. He's been bounced from doctor to doctor and they are just "baffled" but unfortunately this confusion has not seemed to create a desire to pursue his case and instead they each in turn just throw up their hands and tell him to go away. He's getting worse and worse and as the months go on, I worry more and more about the diagnosis they are unable to make.  thank you, eah [/b]
posted_time: Post  by tintin » Mon Oct 03, 2005 12:11 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi tintin, An Infectious Disease Specialist for a variety of infections, for example, recurrent respiratory infections, pneumonia, tuberculosis, mycobacterial infections. Skin and soft tissue infections, for instance, (MRSA). Infections related to immunosuppresion (transplant related) or immunodeficiency (HIV). Other blood infections (Hepatitis), etc. etc. So in answer to your question, the physician would most likely want to rule out one of the above disorders. If infectious diseases are ruled out as a causative factor of his generalized lymphadenopathy, night sweats, and fatigue, then I would suggest a referral to an Oncologist to identify the cause of the symptoms. Negative blood work alone may not completely exclude Lymphoma or any other disease for that matter. Although, specific tests may indicate if disease is present, it is used as a guide to evaluate for a persons general health. The "whole picture" so to speak, is evaluated (physical exam, labwork, symptoms, diagnostic studies, biopsy). Again, I would suggest if infectious diseases have been ruled out, an evaluation by an Oncologist is warranted. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi sophia lauren Inguinal lymph node enlargement These are situated in the crease between the leg and pelvis (more on the outside of that crease, i.e. laterally). It drains the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal. Common causes of enlargement include infections of the leg or foot, STDs (e.g., herpes simplex virus, gonococcal infection, syphilis, chancroid, granuloma inguinale, lymphogranuloma venereum), lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague. Following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. I would recommend an evaluation by your physician as he/she may not only want to evaluate the areas over a short period of time (3-4 weeks) as well as a course of antibiotic therapy. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: squidahoy  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Thu Sep 29, 2005 8:17 am Location: DC
title: Swollen supraclavicular lymph node: please help?
content: Hi,  I've had a swollen supraclavicular lymph node for approximately 2.5 weeks.  It is firm (a little rubbery) but also pretty mobile, most of the time. It seems to be a little firmer & less mobile in the mornings, and seems to become a little less swollen/more mobile during the day before swelling up again at night.     When one says a lymph node/ bump is moveable, how much is it supposed to move?  Mine will wiggle & move around a perceptible bit, but always stays anchored to what I assume is the rest of the lymphatic duct at the top.   I haven't had any other negative symptoms-- no fatigue, night sweats, weight loss, itchiness, or appetite changes. My neck (to my shoulder) was pretty sore when I discovered that my lymph node was swollen, & the site will still become tender on occasion  although the node itself isn't really tender.   What concerns me is that it hasn't gone away yet.  I've also  had 2 moveable lumps on my rib cage since April. The rib lumps started in much the same way as the neck lymph node--generalized pain and tenderness in the area that eventually (after 2 or 3 months) reduced to only the bumps, and now (after > 6 months) only comes back  after doing something strenuous. (Still have the lumps all the time, though).   Have gone to the doctors' (like 5 times) and, after a significant amount of persuasion on my part, convinced them to do a chest x-ray, since my mother died of lung cancer and I've taken the "don't wait around with lumps" approach.  The chest x-ray was done in May and came back clear. Also, had a white cell/red cell count about 5 months ago that came back completely normal.    Is there something that might not have shown up on the blood work or x-ray that might be causing these problems? Of course, my first concern is some type of cancer. But, could toxoplasmosis (cat scratch fever) or another infection stay in my system for more than 6 months without ever causing a fever greater than 100 degrees?  I am so confused...  I'm asking here because I don't believe I'd be welcomed back at my doctor's office...last time I went in (for the rib lumps, after the x-ray came back clear, but when they were still very painful), the doctor told me that she had had >8 years of medical training, had never seen anything like this, no, cancer doesn't just appear on one's rib cage, and that my problems must be because I was still depressed from my mother's death 2 years ago [a load of hooey: my mother was sick for 5 years before she passed away, I had plenty of time to make my peace, and wouldn't have been depressed if I hadn't been in physical pain for 4 months straight].    So, any advice would be appreciated,  so I can go in armed with the proper vocabulary and the  tests I should ask for.  Thanks so much!
