author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi squidahoy, Has your doctor confirmed the presence of a supraclavicular lymph node enlargement? I understand that your primary concern is that its cancer, so lets assume that it is a lymph node and discuss the possibilities. Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2]. Little information exists to suggest that a specific diagnosis can be based on node size. However, in one series [3] of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2. In children, lymph nodes larger than 2 cm in diameter (along with an abnormal chest radiograph and the absence of ear, nose and throat symptoms) were predictive of granulomatous diseases (i.e., tuberculosis, cat-scratch disease or sarcoidosis) or cancer (predominantly lymphomas) [4]. These studies were performed in referral centers, and conclusions may not apply in primary care settings. Also please note that an increase in size on serial examination is very significant.  Regarding age: In primary care settings, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40.[5]  Regarding consistency: Stony-hard nodes are typically a sign of cancer, usually metastatic. Very firm, rubbery nodes suggest lymphoma. Softer nodes are the result of infections or inflammatory conditions. Suppurant nodes may be fluctuant. The term "shotty" refers to small nodes that feel like buckshot under the skin. What happens is that following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Regarding location, the right supraclavicular node drains the mediastinum, lungs, esophagus and can harbor infection or cancer from the lung, retroperitoneal or gastrointestinal tract. The left supraclavicular node drains the thorax, abdomen via thoracic duct and can enlarge as a result of lymphoma, thoracic or retroperitoneal cancer, bacterial or fungal infection. It could be due to many other causes if it is not the only lymph node that is enlarged.  Regarding mobility, an enlarged lymph node that is mobile has a rather limited degree of mobility and usually recoils to its original position when tugged at by rolling the fingers over it.  I must insist that in your case you should confirm your case by referring to your doctor. There is no such thing as not being welcome by your doctor. This is especially the case if your lymph node is of significant size or increasing in size.  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.  3. Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82.  4. Slap GB, Brooks JS, Schwartz JS. When to perform biopsies of enlarged peripheral lymph nodes in young patients. JAMA 1984;252:1321-6.  5. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, I am not sure where exactly you mean. One of the clinical features that help identifying a lymph node is its location. There is the suboccipital lymp node which is located at the junction between the back of the head and neck. There is also the posterior cervical chain of lymph nodes which is located on the side of the neck near to the back. There is also the postauricular lymph node which is located behind the ears. I suggest that you get it examined if you haven't done so already. By clinical examination it should be relatively easy to identify whether it is a lymph node or a muscle spasm. Best regards,

author: asap1  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Nov 15, 2005 6:07 pm Location: chicago, il
title: Every month - new lymph node swelling
content: Hi, I am a 25 year old male who has been frustrated with lymph node swellings.  Every month I seem to get new and more swellings.  In June of this year, I noticed my 1st lymph node swelling  on the left side of my neck with a cold/flu that I experienced.  The cold went away after a few days, but the lymph node still stayed.  A few days later another swelling on the same side one came up.  I decided to wait it out until my neck started aching, and I felt an intense ache on the back of my head on the left side.  I went to a doctor in late July.  He tested for mono and it came out negative multiple times.  The CBC report didn't indicate anything.  He took chest xrays and they were negative for TB.  We finally decided to do a biopsy of the deep cervical lymph node- the biopsy came back saying no evidence of lymphoma or malignancy...that was great news.  But since July, I have gotten new lymph node swellings, and the old ones have not gone away.  Every month since then to be exact new ones appear.  Just recently the right side of my neck and under my jaw have all swollen lymph nodes.  At first I felt fine, but now I'm feeling like I have low grade fevers.  My neck and the back of my neck is still aching, and I feel crappy everyday.  I was tested again for mono, EBV, AIDs...you name it they gave it to me but it all came back negative or normal.  I don't understand what is going on?? I live a healthy lifestyle, but I haven't been diagnosed.  Can someone give me some insight...at this rate, all my lymph nodes will be swelling up sooner or later.  I can only think of lymphoma again....I have a total of 11 swollen lymph nodes, the doctors (4) don't know whats going on.  Please help  Thanks, Sean

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello asap1, Your case is indeed very perplexing. At this stage I do not know if I can give you any advice by going through an extensive list of symptoms to be on the look out for. There are many causes for generalized lymph node enlargement. All we can do for now is to wait and observe if what is causing your lymphadenopathy will manifest itself with another symptom. Chronic symptoms to be on the look out for are: Fatigue, malaise, fever, abdominal pain (especially on the left side), "flu-like" illness, rash,  nausea, vomiting, jaundice, arthritis, renal, neurologic, hematologic disorders, bruising, conjunctivitis, excessive sweat, dyspnea and cough. It should be emphasized that these symptoms are a cause for concern if they are excessive in intensity or duration. Any of these symptoms can cause the doctor to suspect a specific disease entity.  More usefully I would like to go through a list of environmental and pharmacological causes for lymph node enlargement. Environmental risks include: tick bites, tuberculosis, recent blood transfusion or transplant, high-risk sexual behavior, intravenous drug use.  Occupational risks: Hunters, trappers, fishermen, fishmongers, slaughterhouse workers have a higher risk for certain diseases that cause lymph node enlargement.  Travel related risks: Recent travel to any of the following geographical areas; Arizona, southern California, New Mexico, western Texas, Southwestern United States, Southeastern or central United States, Southeast Asia, India, northern Australia, Central or west Africa, Central or South America, East Africa, Mediterranean, China, Latin America, Mexico, Peru, Chile, India, Pakistan, Egypt, Indonesia. Some medications are known to specifically cause lymphadenopathy (e.g., phenytoin [Dilantin]), while others, such as cephalosporins, penicillins or sulfonamides, are more likely to cause a serum sickness-like syndrome with fever, arthralgias and rash in addition to lymphadenopathy.  A more extensive list of medications causing lymph node enlargement includes:   Allopurinol (Zyloprim)  Atenolol (Tenormin)  Captopril (Capozide)  Carbamazepine (Tegretol)  Cephalosporins  Gold  Hydralazine (Apresoline)  Penicillin  Phenytoin (Dilantin)  Primidone (Mysoline)  Pyrimethamine (Daraprim)  Quinidine  Sulfonamides  Sulindac (Clinoril)    Well I hope this list is useful, if any of the above relates to you then we could have a starting point. Let me know how things go.  Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, The submandibular lymph node drains the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. It can thus be enlarged due to infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx. These are the most common causes, cancer being much less common. From your description it appears that none of your lymph nodes are larger than 1cm in size. If they do not enlarge in size and no new lymph nodes appear and you do not develop symptoms such as hoarseness of vioce unexplained lymph node enlargement in cases that are not suspected of being at high risk of developing cancer are observed for 3 to 4 weeks.  Given the limitations of the internet, I am unable to rule out anything. I can only give you a very general impression which may infact be misleading. Under these circumstances I urge to seek medical attention as soon as possible.  Best regards,

title: [no title]
content: Hello sammy1, Thank you for your kind words. Manual irritation is not one of the causes of lymph node enlargement. As for your second question: One of the criteria used to diagnose a lymph node enlargement is if a swelling occurs in a lymph node region. This is then easily confirmed by palpation.  Sometimes the situation is not so easy especially when it is present in a region where it can be confused with other structures (e.g. the supraclavicular lymph node - above the collar bone).  In your case there are very few structures in that region to confuse it with, so its more than likely that these are lymph nodes. Again, confirmation by clinical examination is warranted. Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Ultrasound is a useful imaging modality in assessment of cervical lymph nodes. Distribution of nodes, grey scale and power Doppler sonographic features are useful to identify the cause of cervical lymphadenopathy. Useful grey scale features include size, shape, status of echogenic hilus, echogenicity, micronodular appearance, intranodal necrosis and calcification. Adjacent soft tissue edema and matting are particularly useful to identify tuberculosis. Useful power Doppler features include vascular pattern and displacement of vascularity. Ultrasonography can be combined with fine needle aspiration cytology in which a sample of cells from the lymph node is aspirated using a needle and examined under the microscope.  In the case of neck lymph nodes, ultrasound is a useful imaging modality in evaluation of cervical lymphadenopathy because of its high sensitivity (98%) and specificity (95%) when combined with fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC).[1]  I think you can safely put it all behind you now.   References =========== 1. Baatenburg de Jong RJ, Rongen RJ, Verwoerd CD, van Overhagen H, Lameris JS, Knegt P. Ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of neck nodes. Arch Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg 1991;117:402-4.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello *Momof3*, Let me start off by reminding you that there is no way that I can exclude lymphoma or malignancy over the internet. If you have an enlarged lymph node you are urged to get examined by a qualified physician. There is no replacement for that, unfortunately.  You should know that not all lymph node enlargements are due to lymphoma or cancer. A very small proportion actually. The body has approximately 600 lymph nodes, but only those in the submandibular, axillary or inguinal regions may normally be palpable in healthy people.[1] Findings from a Dutch study revealed that only 10 percent of patients with unexplained adenopathy required referral to a subspecialist, 3 percent required a biopsy and only 1 percent had a malignancy.[2] Lymph nodes can enlarge due to infections more commonly than due to malignancy. In some cases, following infection, lymph nodes may remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. To answer your question: Any cancer if left untreated will progress in size and stage and may spread to new areas. That's why an increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. In your case this is quite the opposite as one of your lymph nodes appears to be decreasing in size.  1. Goroll AH, May LA, Mulley AG Jr. Primary care medicine: office evaluation and management of the adult patient. 2d ed. Philadelphia: Lippincott, 1987.  2. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

content: Hi jennapooh, Ultrasound is a useful imaging modality in assessment of neck lymph nodes. Distribution of nodes, grey scale and power Doppler sonographic features are useful to identify the cause of cervical lymphadenopathy. Useful grey scale features include size, shape, status of echogenic hilus, echogenicity, micronodular appearance, intranodal necrosis and calcification. Adjacent soft tissue edema and matting are particularly useful to identify tuberculosis. Useful power Doppler features include vascular pattern and displacement of vascularity.  Ultrasonography can be combined with fine needle aspiration cytology in which a sample of cells from the lymph node is aspirated using a needle and examined under the microscope.  In short, hopefully the ultrasound will indicate what the cause of this lymph node enlargement is. The doctor does this when he wants to rule out serious disease such as lymphoma, cancer or TB based on his clinical evaluation.  Hardness of a lymph node that is greater than 1cm always warrants further investigations.  Hopefully, it will all turn out fine. Please let us know how everything goes for your son.

My dr told me that if the mass persisted to contact him for a follow up that would probably accompany a referral to a surgeon for a biopsy.  Ive had no abnormal symptoms, and am a little worried about the probable biopsy/diagnosis.  Could it still be something pathological even though the CT was fine?  Could what Im feeling just be a normal anatomical structur/muscle?  Am I automatically doomed because of the masses location?  Please help!   -Thanks

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello premed3341, Thank you for using The Doctors Lounge.  As you already know an enlarged supraclavicular lymph node is always an indication that your doctor must exclude malignancy by all possible means. So I will focus my discussion mainly on excluding cancer.  I am assuming your Dr. has already determined by examination that this indeed a lymph node enlargement, or is he still confused about its nature. Did your CT involve the supraclavicular area as well or was it only performed on the head and neck? This would confirm the presence of a lymph node and may indicate if it is abnormal or not. More easily, an ultrasound scan would also be able to detect a supraclavicular lymph gland enlargement. It may show cortical necrosis which is an indication fo possible malignancy.  Once the presence of a lymph node enlargement is established then many things are taken into consideration: your age (incidence of cancer increases with age especially above 40 years), history of malignant disease, the size of the lymph node (>1cm) and the presence or absence of constitutional symptoms among other things.  Given the presence of risk factors, your doctor may consider observation for a period of time and then decide on further investigation. This may include a fine needle aspiration which usually does not yield significant information. On the other hand a biopsy may be warranted in persistant cases.  Please do not consider yourself doomed. If your doctor was sure you had cancer he would not have waited to give you therapy. Trust in your doctor's judgement as he appears to care about you.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello premed3341, Obviously I am in no position to challenge your doctor's opinion as he has the advantage of being able to examine you. If I was examining a patient and could feel a supraclavicular mass I would be worried even if the CT scan turned out negative. However, let me give you a few thoughts.  Palpation of lymph nodes is known to be much less sensitive in detecting lymph node enlargement. Both the sensitivity and specificity are in the range of 60-70%, depending on the tumor studied. This means that there is a rather high possibility of false negative and false positive results (as in your case). A false positive result means that the doctor feels an enlarged lymph node when in reality there is none. Nodes had to have a diameter of 22.3 mm or greater to be palpated in 50% of cases in one study (van Overhagen et al, 2004).  In that study, the sensitivity of ultrasonography was triple that of palpation for the detection of metastases in supraclavicular lymph nodes and CT scans were found to be as sensitive as ultrasonography. Ultrasonography can be combined with fine needle aspiration cytology which gives more conclusive results. PET scans have been reported to be more sensitive than CT scans in the detection of malignant disease in lymph nodes. However, PET scans are expensive and not always available.  Let me also add that in another study, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40 (Fijten et al, 1988).  Given the high probability of false positives by palpation and the results of your CT scan and your age, the surgeon may opt to perform any of the other methods of diagnosis above. If he decides that a biopsy is warranted he will dissect a very small opening in the skin remove any masses he can see and analyze them.  I have given you a list of different modalities which are used to diagnose lymph node enlargement which you can discuss with your doctor. Keep us updated.  References: --------------- Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.  Hans van Overhagen, MD, PhD, Koen Brakel, MD, PhD, Mark W. Heijenbrok, MD, Jan H. L. M. van Kasteren, MD, Cees N. F. van de Moosdijk, MD, Albert C. Roldaan, MD, PhD, Ad P. van Gils, MD, PhD and Bettina E. Hansen, MSc. Metastases in Supraclavicular Lymph Nodes in Lung Cancer: Assessment with Palpation, US, and CT. Radiology 2004;232:75-80.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Wed Nov 30, 2005 3:39 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello premed3341, Unfortunately, there are no blood tests that are specific to a particular cancer. Even tumor markers have a low sensitivity and specificity when it comes to diagnosing cancer (except in prostate cancer and choriocarcinoma). There are basically two ways a doctor will reach the conclusion that what he felt was not an enlarged lymph node due to a malignancy. If on follow up the swelling does not increase steadily with time and all your scans remain negative or by requesting a biopsy that turns out negative for malignancy. A biopsy of course is the gold standard by which all the other tests are measured. Which course the doctor will choose will depend on how risky he considers the situation (based on clinical examination). Let's wait and see what the PCP has to say, I have a feeling it will all turn out fine. Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello Morgan1313, Lymph nodes of the inguinal lymph nodes drain the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal. This means that any infection, inflammation or cancer when present in any of the above areas will drain to the inguinal lymph nodes and cause them to enlarge.  Hence his doctors would want to rule out: infections of the leg or foot, STDs, lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague. The list is extensive and an MRI will help rule out a pelvic infection (abcess) or malignancy among other things. Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello ChloeAnne, Thank you for using The Doctors Lounge.  Lymph node enlargements in the area of the throat drain the lymphatics of the head and neck any infection (cold/flu) can lead to lymph gland enlargement in that area and this would be considered normal.  In such cases, a patient is put under observation for 3 to 4 weeks. If the lymph node does not subside by then or there is an increase in size during that period, further investigation may be required.  A lymph node in the neck that is less than 1 cm in size is considered by most authorities to be normal.  In one series (Pangalis et al) of 213 adults with unexplained lymphadenopathy, no patient with a lymph node smaller than 1 cm2 (1 cm 3 1 cm) had cancer, while cancer was present in 8 percent of those with nodes from 1 cm2 to 2.25 cm2 (1 cm 3 1 cm to 1.5 cm 3 1.5 cm) in size, and in 38 percent of those with nodes larger than 2.25 cm2 (1.5 cm 3 1.5 cm).  Let me also add that the incidence of malignancy in lymph node enlargements is very low patients younger than 40 years old:  0.4 percent risk (Fijten et al).  References: --------------- Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6. Pangalis GA, Vassilakopoulos TP, Boussiotis VA, Fessas P. Clinical approach to lymphadenopathy. Semin Oncol 1993;20:570-82.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi alittleconcerned, Generally speaking, the term "shotty" is used in relationship to infection. Lymph nodes tend to decrease in size after an infection subsides even though they may not return to their pre-infectious state. The concern of your physician's is most likely due to the fact that the lymph nodes have continued enlarging. Lymph nodes 1 cm or less are usually less concerning. In the particular area that you describe, lymph nodes greater than 1 cm indicate further investigative studies which is the reason for the biopsy. It would be difficult to make a judgement on a specific cause prior to a biopsy. The biopsy would be used to identify if an underlying disorder exists. I hope this has been somewhat helpful. Our best wishes to you and good luck. I hope you will consider posting an update when your time permits. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi alittleconcerned, I appreciate your update. Sarcoidosis is not a form of cancer and is not contagious. Inflammatory granulomas (growths/lumps) may affect any organ of the body including lymph nodes. The etiology or cause of sarcoidosis is unknown. Research suggests that this is an immune response to an environmental factor or even to the own's bodies tissue. Instead of the areas of inflammation subsiding as it normally does, the inflammation remains and produces granulomas (growths or lumps). It occurs most often in people aged 20-40. Treatment is geared toward severity of symptoms present and what organs are involved. One of the medications used to treat this condition is corticosteroids such as prednisone. I hope this information has been somewhat helpful and good luck with your appointment. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi tinkerbelle, If the lymph nodes have been evaluated by her physician and have not changed over the last three years that is probably why the physician isn't overly concerned at this point. Lymph nodes may become enlarged from viral/bacterial infections among other conditions, because they are the bodies defense system. These may not return to their pre-infectious size, the key is that they don't continue enlarging despite treatment. Has she had any ear infections, sore throats, sinus infections etc.? Repeated infections (ear, upper respiratory, sore throat, etc.) may cause enlargement of lymph nodes in this area. If you remain concerned request a referral to have these further evaluated but again, since they are not continuing to enlarge and if she is not experiencing any other symptoms,  they are likely to be related to previously repeated infectious origins. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

content: Hello, Lymph gland enlargement is almost a universal finding in mononucleosis. It usually presents with a low grade fever and possibly a sore throat. This is the commonest presentation of the disease. To answer your question; yes, lymph node enlargement can be the only presenting symptom in mononucleosis. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello agobeil, Thank you for using The Doctors Lounge. In the absence of pathology, lymph nodes are not felt.   Infected lymph nodes however, tend to be:  Firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (i.e. stuck to each other), fixed (i.e. not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  These criteria do not seem to fit your description.  Following infection, however, lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty lymph nodes'. They are harmless.  As always, you are advised to confirm these findings with your doctor.  Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Wed Nov 30, 2005 12:26 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello DesperatetoConceive21, I hope you have already had a biopsy and that your results came out fine. An enlarged inguinal lymph node is considered clinically significant when it reaches 1.5cm in size. The reason being that it is commonly enlarged by benign disease.  This lymph node drains the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal and lower limbs.  It is commonly affected by infections of the leg or foot, STDs (e.g., herpes simplex virus, gonococcal infection, syphilis, chancroid, granuloma inguinale, lymphogranuloma venereum), lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague.  The fact that it recently increased in size is probably what urged them to proceed with a biopsy. Unfortunately, you do not have all the information since they didn't provide you with the lab results. Trust in your doctor's opinion, he is obviously doing what is in your best interest. Let us know how everything went. Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello seraphim, Thank you for using The Doctor's Lounge.  Assuming that this is a lymph node enlargement in the left armpit (axilla), here are a few thoughts: The axillary lymph nodes draing the arm, thoracic wall, breast. As such inflammation, infections as well as cancers from these areas would cause its growth in size. Its size in your case is significant since it seems to be quite large. This can happen with infection or cancer. Now let me address the pain and tenderness which are usually not associated with cancer but more likely are indicative of infection. Another point in your favor is your age, being younger than 40 years decreases the overall likelyhood of your lymph node being cancer. I would recommend that you seek medical attention as the only way to exclude the more serious causes would be by clinical evaluation. You would also probably need a course of antibiotics and antiinflammatory drugs that your doctor will prescribe. You will be observed for a period of 3 to 4 weeks where upon if the lymph node does not subside you will require further evaluation. Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello ucdcows, Thank you for using The Doctor's Lounge. First, the only way for me to be able to confirm that these bumps are lymph nodes I would need to examine them personally which is obviously not possible. However, assuming that they are lymph nodes given your description of their location let me give you a few thoughts.  For lymph node enlargement to be significant most authors agree that the size should be greater than 1 cm (Libman H, 1987).   Regarding, the position of the lymph node enlargement you would be describing the occipital lymph node which are located at the junction between the back of the head and neck. They are rarely malignant, often related to scalp and outer ear infections, exanthematous diseases, and toxoplasmosis.  Given the limitations of the internet in clinical evaluation, you are advised to seek medical attention. In your case the most probable outcome of your evaluation would be to put you under observation for 3 to 4 weeks and then re-evaluate these nodes. The doctor may also recommend a course of antibiotics based on his evaluation.  References: ----------------  Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Melntod,  well, lymph nodes in the neck are common...due to any inflammation in the face, in your throat, in your ears,etc.  The question is...is it a significant lymph node or not?! and by significant...i mean... its size (if bigger than 1.5 cm), it's consistency ,mobility, attachment to surrounding tissue and how many lymph nodes are they on the same side or on both sides of your neck...any lymph nodes anywhere else?. It's all a matter of judgment for the doctor who sees you.  If  your lymph node is significant....then a biopsy should be done to exclude malignancy (cancer) and to reach a diagnosis and follow the appropriate treatment.  It might be enlarged from a serious infection you had....not mono in particular,then it healed by fibrosis and left the lymph node big....and you discovered it accidentally when it was there all the time.  what concerns me is the weight loss...how much did you lose (in Kgs, please) over what period of time? days/weeks/months? P.S: did you have a CT scan done on your neck only? and did it just show this lymph node....or there have been other ones?!  Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello ukveteran2, Thank you for dropping by The Doctors Lounge. The presence of an enlarged lymph node in the neck could be due to several diseases and not only due to lymphoma. Many things are taken into consideration when attempting to reach a diagnosis. The size of a lymph node (smaller than 1 cm lymph nodes tend to be less important), the consitency, the mobility and the persistence after a course of antibiotics are all clinically significant details. Obviously the most prudent way to go about reaching a diagnosis is to eliminate the most dangerous possibilities first which in your case would mean cancer. Based on clinical evaluation, your doctor can assess how demanding the situation is. If this is the only clinically significant lymph node enlargement that you have; then usually, the next step based on clinical examination would be a CT/MRI scan of the head and neck regions to exclude cancer of the head or neck. At the same time a fine needle aspiration cytology (not a biopsy) from the lymph gland is warranted. Many lymph gland enlargments turn out to be benign (reactive); however, no caring doctor will rest his mind until he has excluded these dangerous possibilties by every means available. Your doctor may also opt to wait a little longer before referring you for investigations if he considers the situation to be less risky. Do keep us posted. Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Sun Nov 27, 2005 1:29 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi candy811, Lymph nodes may enlarge due to viral/bacterial infections, among other conditions, because the lymphatic system is the bodies defense in filtering viruses and bacteria. After a lymph node becomes enlarged and an infection has subsided it may not return to it's pre-infectious state. With that being said, since you have been evaluated by several specialists, had diagnostic  studies, are not experiencing any other symptoms, the lymph nodes are 1 cm or less, not increasing in size, in my opinion, I would have to agree that this in all probability, has an infectious rather than malignant etiology. It is essentially normal. Stop poking and squeezing at the lymph node as this will only cause irritation. The size it is should alleviate your fear and let you know that you body is responding appropriately. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi majo, Generally speaking, enlarged, "tender" lymph nodes may commonly indicate an infectious or inflammatory process. Lymph nodes may enlarge due to even seemingly decrete or unapparent viral/bacterial infections because they are the bodies filtering system. Enlarged nodes  may not return to their pre-infectious size. Even something as trivial as a cut or abrasion, may trigger this action. You may want to have the area evaluated by your physician when you go in for an appointment but again, tenderness usually indicates the previously mentioned factors. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi kate05, How large is the lymph node? Is it continuing to enlarge? Has there been any mention of additional diagnostic studies, for example, an ultrasound study of the area? Lymph nodes 1 cm or less may often be related to less concerning etiologes/ causes such as bacterial/viral infections. One reason that lymph nodes enlarge is because this is our bodies defense system to fight off infection. When lymph nodes continue to enlarge over a period of time especially if treated unsuccessfully with a course of antibiotics etc. then they are certainly more suspicious in nature. Lymph nodes containing those characteristics, larger than 1 cm is size, etc. warrants further investigative studies. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi littlebugs, Lymph nodes may become enlarged as a result of a bacterial/viral infection because the lymphatic system is the bodies defense for fighting infections. Lymph nodes may not return to the size of their pre-infectious state. The nodes in the submandibular area may be related to the chronic sinusitis. Although enlargement of nodes in the supraclavicular area may become concerning, taking into consideration that they are 1 cm or less and not continuing to enlarge is most likely the reason that a biopsy wasn't suggested. Also, the ultrasound evaluation didn't determine suspiciousness. If you would continue feeling generally unwell however, a repeat evaluation by your physician is recommended. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: I have a swollen node that has been on the right side of my neck for 1 year. I returned several times to the same doctor who said it was nothing. Finally asked to see another doctor who sent me to the surgical clinic. He felt it and said he wants to take it out as it is in a worrisome spot. He scheduled me for an ultrasound on the 18th to see how deep it is prior to surgery. My question is this, shouldn't he do a CT scan or x-rays prior to deciding to just remove it? Plus, if it was cancer wouldn't it have gotten larger? The only other symptoms I've had are hoarseness and the feeling that I need to clear my throat alot. I've had some pain in my collarbone region sometimes spreading down my arm and up my neck. I didn't mention the hoarsenes and throat clearing to him as I didn't think it applied at the time to the lump. I've also been pretty exhausted but that is the usual norm as I have fibromyalgia.
posted_time: Post  by morgana » Tue Oct 11, 2005 9:12 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi morgana, An ultrasound is an appropriate diagnostic tool in identifying characteristics of a lymph node or questionable mass in the neck. This study identifies characteristics of a mass, for example, fluid filled or solid, size, depth, any other suspicious areas which may not be palpable (felt). Sincerely, Rntdj

author: granite  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Oct 19, 2005 12:05 am Location: Canada
title: Epitrochlear & other lymphadenopathy
content: Hi there, I'm a 24 year old female in generally good health. About 3-4 weeks ago I noticed two or three palpable lymph nodes in my right axilla, which are mobile & non-tender and about 1cm.  Then I noticed one node with the same characteristics on the left side. About 1-2 weeks ago I found a palpable right epitrochlear node, which is firm, mobile, and maybe a bit less than 1 cm. Now I think I am feeling a small (~50mm) lump in my left supraclavicular area, a very small pinhead sized lump in my right supraclavicular area, and I think I may feel an epitrochlear lump on the left side. I am wondering how likely it is that this is something serious like cancer and whether I should consult a physician.  I realize that this could be caused by infection but I feel well, and I don't notice any skin infections, although I do have eczema.  I have used protopic (tacrolimus). I would really appreciate a little advice!  Thanks a bunch in advance!  Granite
posted_time: Post  by granite » Wed Oct 19, 2005 12:20 am

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hello granite, Generalized lymphadenopathy almost always indicates a systemic disease is present, meaning that you will be feeling sick. That is not the case, because you feel well. A possible cause of your lymph nodes enlargement might be a very unfrequent adverse effect of the tacrolimus ointment. I encourage you to see the doctor. Sincerely,  Dr Torax

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: First of all, I need to stress how important it is to NEVER SHARE PRESCRIPTION MEDICATION. That is dangerous. Only take medication prescribed to you, by your doctor.   As for your lump, don't be scared of surgery. You will get a biopsy, will not feel a thing, it won't hurt, and you will recovery quickly.  The purpose of a biopsy is to remove the lump, and send it to a lab for testing to see what is wrong.  Most lumps are due to an infection of some kind, which is why you were prescribed antibiostics to take for awhile to see if it goes away. If it does not go away by the time you are finished with the antibiotics, then there is something else wrong. It may be serious, and it may not be. I don't think you should worry until after you have a biopsy( which you may not even need) You didn't say how long you have been on the antibiotics. It is very possible the lump will be gone by the time you are finished.
posted_time: Post  by Shana Johnson, CNA » Sat Oct 08, 2005 6:00 am

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: A biopsy is the surgical procedure you will have done to remove and diagnose the lump on your neck.  While under anesthesia, the doctor will cut out the lymph node, and send it to a lab to be tested to see what is causing it to be enlarged.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi mom2tck, Although lymph nodes commonly enlarged in the presence of bacterial/viral infections because this is the bodies defense/filtering  mechanism, they may also enlarge for other more serious conditions. How does the lymph node feel? Is it fixed or movable? Lymph nodes related to infection are usually tender etc.  Lymph nodes that do not decrease in size despite the use of antibiotics warrants further investigation. I am strongly suggesting to you that if he has had no labwork or other diagnostic studies (ultrasound/CT scan, etc) that you inquire about these studies being done. I hope that you will consider posting an update. Sincerely, Rntdj
posted_time: Post  by Theresa Jones, RN » Wed Sep 28, 2005 5:14 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi mom2tck, I agree with the surgeon and would be suspicious of such a lymph node. Everyone has hundreds of lymph nodes in their bodies, so the loss of one would be the least concern. Your son's neck will be somewhat uncomfortable, and he may have some soreness during swallowing but these syymptoms will be relatively short lived. The tissue will be sent to a pathologist for an evaluation for identification of abnormal cells. I will hold you both in my thoughts and prayers for strength, guidance, and in the hope that all goes well and he recovers without incident. I will watch for your follow up post. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi mom2tck, It's very encouraging that the Chest xray and CBC were normal. In the event that there would possibly be an underlying malignancy then this would most likely exclude spread to these areas. Good news indeed! Generally speaking, after a surgical procedure a fever of 101 degrees or less is relatively normal. An elevated temperature of greater that 101 is not. Call the physician back, your son needs an evaluation! Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: It is possible to convince yourself of a disease, and start feeling the symptoms of it. Woman who want to become pregnant so badly, sometimes actually stop menstrating, begin lactating, and have ALL pregnancy symptoms, including a swollen belly, only to find out they are not pregnant when an ultrasound confirms. The mind can be a tricky thing. As for HIV, when contracted, it produces a flu like symptoms soon after contracting the disease, then thoes symptoms go away, and a person can have no more symptoms for years.  The lymph nodes can become swollen and tender due to infection. Have you have a cold lately?

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi veryworried1, The term "shotty" is often in reference to lymph node enlargement related to an infectious/inflammatory cause. Lymph nodes enlarge during episodes of bacterial/viral infections because the lymphatic system is the defense system of the body. Lymph nodes that decrease in size are often related to this particular cause and may not return to their pre-infectious state. Lymph nodes that continue to enlarge are more often concerning. When symptoms arise from Lymphoma they usually present with fatigue, night sweats, unexplainable fevers, weight loss, itching, etc. Even though lymph node enlargement in the supraclavicular area is concerning, taking into consideration that the nodes are decreasing in size would be more indicative of infectious/inflammatory disorders.  I hope this information was helpful. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: [no title]
content: Hi veryworried1, Lymphadenopathy is an associated side effect of Accutane. The indicator of whether this medication is associated with your particular symptoms is, did you notice the decreasing size of the enlarged lymph nodes after discontinuation of the medication? If so, that would indicate that this is the probable cause. LDH levels may be increased in certain cancers as well as many other disorders. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi ourhouse93, There are different types of Lymphoma. For example, some of the signs and symptoms of Hodgkin's Lymphoma are painless enlarged lymph nodes, weight loss, night sweats, poor appetite, generalized itching, fatigue, hair loss, enlarged spleen, etc. Again, I would inquire about an additional lymph node biopsy, bone marrow biopsy, CT Scan of the neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis. You stated that he has been being treated for an infection of the biopsy site? 5 weeks of antibiotic therapy? Was a culture sent of the wound to identify any resistent organisms? If this has not been completed then this would be another suggestion because 5 weeks of antibiotic treatment in my opinion suggests an infection of a resistent organism, for example, MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus). I would hope that Hepatits screens and HIV testing would have previously been completed to rule these illnesses out. I do not feel you are over-reacting by any means. I hope that when your time permits you will post a follow up. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: ourhouse93! Pathology is the most important diagnostic test in lymphoma. Luckily, it is quite accurate. One possibility for false negative results is if the lymph node tissue is not adequate (not likely if this is an excisional biopsy in which the whole of the lymph node is removed) or if the surgeon picked a less significant lymph node (again not very likely). This would depend on the size and appearance of these lymph nodes in relation to others.  Usually a lymph node of the neck is first assessed with a fine needle biopsy. Once the pathologist has the specimen, determining if it contains lymphoma is usually not difficult. A panel of special stains (immunohistochemistry) will allow him to conclude the nature of this disease. If that is not enough in some cases of lymphoma the diagnosis can be made at a genetic level. What exactly does the biopsy report say (other than negative for malignancy)? Whether the spleen is enlarged or not is unclear and it does not appear to show 'focal lesions' which are common in lymphomas involving the spleen. I am assuming his blood counts (white blood cells) are normal since you didn't mention them. I understand your concern but until we exclude lymphoma for the time being it seems that the main concern here is indeed the rising liver enzymes and the bilirubin. A hepatitis screen is mandatory and should be done as soon as possible. One thing to keep in mind is the size and number of the lymph nodes if they are increasing in size and number that should be a reason for concern. In such a case I would advise you to consult with a hemato-oncologist. Best regards,

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi tammyabby, Although Henoch-Schonlein Purpura, may be caused when the immune system doesn't fight an infection as it's intended I would not expect this to cause enlarged nodes. I, however, would relate the diarrhea to this disorder. The weight loss, night sweats and fatigue is disconcerting but I would not relate these findings to Henoch-Schonlein Purpura an would be inclined to consider another cause. You may feel some discomfort in your neck along with some difficulty swallowing but these symptoms should be short lived. If a diagnosis of lymphoma would be found the treatment options are based on the type, stage/grade etc. Good luck with your biopsy and I hope you will consider posting an update. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi sabrelyn, Lymph nodes that are movable, and not increasing in size despite treatment are most likely related to a previous infection because the lymph system is the bodies defense for filtering bacteria/viral infections. Since your physician has evaluated these lymph nodes and found that they are essentially benign in nature I wouldn't be too concerned. Numbness, tingling, palpitations etc. may be related to numerous conditions. I would not jump to a conclusion of anemia or cancer at this point but would look at the more obvious conditions such as alterations in blood pressure, diabetes, thyroid disorders, vitamin deficiencies, etc. Why put yourself through worrying about the "what if"? Sometimes fear of the unknown is worse than a condition or illness itself. I would suggest that you make an appointment with your physician to identify the causative factor.  Sincerely, Rntdj

He said that they didn't see anything worrysome, but that they would do the complete test and he would call me if there was anything wrong.  That was a week ago and I havent' heard, so I'm assuming they didn't find anything.  He asked to see me again in three weeks if the swelling didn't decrease, and that they would do another FNA.  I was hoping that by the time I went back to the doctor, the swelling in my neck would have gone down, but it doesn't seem to be getting any better a week later.  Sometimes I think it's actually gotten worse - and let me tell you - these lymph nodes are absolutely huge.  When I look in the mirror, the left side of my neck is very clearly sticking out further than the other side.  To touch it, it almost feels like it's swollen by INCHES, not centimeters.  It was very painful several weeks ago and flares up, but is much less painful now and at times painless.  The swelling seems to increase at night.  It seems I have a pea-sized lymph node on the right side of my neck now as well.  Though I've had tests (CBC, mono, CT of neck, FNA) and nothing has been cause for alarm, I can't shake the feeling that this is not normal.  This just suddenly appeared one day, and I know that painful, swollen lymph nodes that appear suddenly doesn't usually pont to cancer, BUT WHAT IS IT?  Doctors think infection, but can't give me any test results to back up that diagnosis.  I want explanations.    Both of my docs have said something about EBV.  I have heard that you can have Epstein-Barr Virus without testing positive for mono, and that a more expensive blood test can diagnosis this.  Should I request this test?  Also, I have had my thyroid test several times, because I appear to have a slight goiter, but they have all been normal.  My chiro says that you can have thyroid problems without conclusive blood tests.  Should I ask my doc about this?  I know that lymph nodes can stay swollen for a long time after infection, which would make me feel better if the docs could actually tell me with certainty that it IS an infection.  The clear mucous appears to be a side effect of GERD.  I sort of had that problem fixed, but I've been taking large amounts of ibuprofin, which I guess have made that pop up again.  I hate to be one of those patients that thinks the know what is wrong and throws around medical lingo and annoys the docs, (I am a nursing student and now that I know more about disease and the human body, I've become a total hypochondriac).    What else could be causing my symptoms besides infection?  Please respond.

author: nadjjaa  Guest Posts: 7 Joined: Mon Aug 29, 2005 10:24 am Location: Kansas
title: [no title]
content: This is for those researching their own symptoms.  Here's an update of what's happened with me:  Biopsy showed no malignant cells.  I went to my chiropracter still with very swollen lymph nodes.  I was also feeling fatigued, and some days, malaise.  So, all of this had been going on for a month.  I was at the end of my rope.  My chiro suspected infected salivary glands and advised me to begin taking COLLOIDAL SILVER and MEGADOSES OF VITAMIN C (5-6,000 mg a day) to help push the infection out.  This was a Friday - I went straight away to my health food store and picked up the Colloidal Silver, Vitamin C, as well as Astragalus, Cat's Claw and American Ginseng.  (If you want to try herbal/natural remedies, do your homework and make sure they will not interact with any medications or with each other.  And be aware of the symptoms of allergy)  Anyway, I started taking the Colloidal silver and Vit. C on Friday.  Saturday I didn't feel very good, and by Sunday I felt like I had the flu.    I found a resource on the internet that said that, if you're ill, don't be in a hurry to get rid of your symptoms.  If you try and push out infection, etc too quickly, your body's organs will react and you may experience flu-like symptoms.  Decrease the amount of silver for the time being.  I figured out that you kind of have to play with the dosage.  I obviously took too much, though it was well within the dosage range.  But we're talking about something that isn't regulated by the FDA, so you have to determine the dosage range based on what your body is telling you - consulting a holistic expert might also be wise.  Sunday I felt terrible, but by Sunday night, I was feeling better than I had in weeks.  it literally happened within an hour.  I was sick and then I wasn't.  Over the next two or three days, the swelling in my neck lymph nodes went away.  I went to see my MD, who was mystified.  I brought some information on colloidal silver to show her and of course, she didn't know much about it, but basically said, okay, just watch for signs of toxicity, etc.  She gave me an injection of prednasone to get rid of the rest of the swelling, and a script for prednasone tabs (which I didn't take).  Because I still didn't really know what was wrong with me, I asked her to run a few more blood tests, specifically one for Epstein-Barr Virus, even though I had tested negative for Mono.  She called yesterday - Blood test was positive for Epstein-Barr Virus.  Mystery solved.  So, though I don't have cancer, I understand that I am now at risk for certain types of cancer, including lymphomas and possibly breast cancer.  I go to my ENT today to discuss those risks with him.  If you're searching for remedies, I highly recommend the Colloidal Silver, but of course, use it with caution.  Here is a good informational website:  http://www.all-natural.com/silver-1.html

author: DeLWolcott  Guest Posts: 293 Joined: Fri Jun 24, 2005 5:47 pm Location: Texas
title: [no title]
content: I found one of those about a year ago and freaked out also.  Internet searches didn't help my fear.  The good side - this lump has disappeared on its own.  Lymph nodes can swell because of irritations, not just infections.  This is not a positive sign for cancer.  Since you do have a family history of cancer it would be in your best interest to have it checked thoroughly just in case, but there a better chance that this will resolve on its own.  The fact that you have a tightness in your throat makes me wonder if you are experiencing allergies, seasonal or food.  Post-nasal drip can cause this feeling sometimes.    Until you see your physician, keep a log of everything you notice you are feeling during this time.  Everything from itchy eyes to tooth pain.  It will help your physician during this process and could also help you narrow the possible causes down yourself.  Good luck!

author: Tinkerbell9999  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Aug 31, 2005 7:48 am Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi LMJ187,  I just read your post and hopefully by now you have received the healthcare you need.  If not, I would suggest getting tested for EBV (Epstein Barr Virus).  Just because you tested negative for Mono does not mean you do not have Mono.  Mono shows up in the blood for a small amout of time (usually 2 weeks).  If it is missed the test will be negative.  EBV (although expensive which is why most doctors do not test for it)  is another test which can show you have Mono.  EBV is the virus that causes Mono.  Your WBC count can also be normal.  You did not mention anything about your throat.  Was it ever painful?  Do you have tonsils?  I hope this helps if you have not found help yet.  Please let me know how you are doing.

title: Abnormal CT, questions about results?
content: Hi!  I found a small lump on the side of my neck, and my doctor had a CAT Scan done this past Friday.  I was expecting it to be a fatty mass, but when the results came back, my doctor called me into his office.  The scan showed:  “The patient places a radioplaque marker over the palpable abnormality.  This overlies the right plastisma and subcutaneous fat.  Just above the nodule there is shotty bilateral submandibular adenopathy with 3 to 4 nodes in both beds measuring 8 to 12 mm in diameter.  Right greater than left jugulodigastric and carotid nodes are also seen at an intermediate size of 12 to 15 mm.  “An isolated right posterior triangle node meets enlargement criteria at 15 x 12 mm size.  There are scattered bilateral posterior subcutaneous nodes measuring 8 to 10 mm.  No parotid nodes are found nor adenopathy below the level of the hyoid bone.  “The airway is patent, mucosal surfaces are intact and there are no sites of submucosal mass or infiltration.  Parapharyngeal fat planes are normal.  The salivary glands show no masses or calcifications.  Included osseous structures are intact.  The paranasal sinuses are clear.  “Impression: 1.	No mass noted at marked site.  Normal subcutaneous fat and platisma. 2.	Bilateral, right greater than left shotty submandibular, carotid, jugulodigastric and posterior triangle adenopathy. 3.	the patient relates history of frequent upper respiratory infection.  This adenopathy is nonspecific and may be due to chronic inflammation or metastasis.  Short interval follow-up urged after treatment”  My doctor is always quick in action, but very short on words, so although I’m seeing an ENT Specialist this Thursday, I do not understand what the results mean.  I tried to look up the individual words, and so much of it came back with ‘lymphoma’ attached, so I thought someone on here might be able to offer me at least a thought on what might be going on?  Thank you in advance for your time and response!

title: Update
content: Well, I went to my ENT Specialist, and I’m going to have a tonsillectomy next week.  He said it may be too early to tell anything from my tonsils but they’ve been swollen for quite a while, and I’ve had sore throats for longer than I care to think, so it’s time.  *smile*    My next question is about a pattern I’ve noticed on my blood tests.  I know it sounds like a mark of desperation, but I’ve been not feeling well now for over a year, and maybe I am getting a bit desperate.  I’ve been examining my blood tests, four all together over the past eight months, and I noticed a consistent pattern with the percent of Neutrophils and Lymphocytes.  Over the past eight months (and four blood tests), the Neutrophils have dropped 12% consistently over time, and the Lymphocytes have risen 11% consistently.  Neither is out of range yet, but they do seem to be moving steadily, and although I’m going to continue to monitor this movement, I was wondering if anyone might know what it could mean (if anything)?  Another change, though not as marked,  is that my platelet count has been rising.  It has not been as consistent, but it did make it just past normal for this past blood test, so possibly they are all tied together.  Thank you so much for any information you might have! Mary

author: Jalalali  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Feb 13, 2005 2:44 am Location: Qatar
title: [no title]
content: Lumps in the armpit have various causes. Cysts and superficial infections in the skin of the armpit may be due to shaving or use of antiperspirants (as opposed to deodorants).  Abscesses under the skin may also produce large, painful lumps in the armpit.  Lumps may be produced by lymph nodes enlarged due to bacterial infections, viral infections, vaccinations, and malignancy.  Check with your health care provider to determine the nature of the lump.

title: Long lasting lymph nodes in my armpit
content: Since I was 13 or so, I've noticed a single lump in my left armpit. The size changes once in a while, always smaller than 1 cm but never going away. Sometimes its swollen, other times its just there. I'm now 20 year old and the lump continues to exist. As far as I know, I'm in good health. i was wondering if I should be worried. I've never seen a doctor since my parents believe it is nothing to be concern about. However, I'm a little freaked because there is a history of cancer in my family. Please help.
posted_time: Post  by xxtitanxx » Wed Sep 14, 2005 2:03 am

author: Jalalali  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Feb 13, 2005 2:44 am Location: Qatar
title: [no title]
content: You should define your gender and give more details about the history of cancer in your family (which type of cancer)  Anyway,   Lumps in the armpit have various causes:  bacterial  localized infection, possibly somewhere in the arm or breast draining into the glands of the armpit, or infection within the armpit itself  cat scratch disease  ascending lymphangitis  lymphadenitis, lymphangitis   viral  infectious mononucleosis  chickenpox  herpes zoster (shingles)  HIV disease (AIDS)   malignant  Hodgkin's lymphoma  non-Hodgkin's lymphoma  leukemia   fungal   sporotrichosis   antigenic   smallpox vaccination  typhoid vaccine  measles, mumps, rubella vaccine (rare)  allergic reaction possibly caused by sulfa drugs, iodine, or penicillin   other   lipomas (harmless fatty growths)  benign (harmless) cyst  normal breast tissue (breast tissue extends into the armpit area)   Check with your health care provider to determine the nature of the lump. Do not try to diagnose lumps without professional help.

author: sara1213  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 6:38 pm Location: Georgia
title: Swelling in my right underarm
content: 6 months ago i noticed a swelling in my right underarm - i went to the doctor thinking i had pulled a muscle - he did xrays and stated i had arthritis in my neck gave me 800 mg advile every six hrs and a steroid shot - swelling went down.  i have two sisters now with breast cancer, one just finished chemo - the other diagnoised yesterday.  So i had my yearly mammogram and also a diagnostic and sonigram.  Everythign cam back good.  My underarm swelled again (its only in the curve not completely under the arm)  family physican says now its a fatty tumor - sent  me to a surgeon.  (i have a history of heavy weight lifting for about 16 years don't lift anymore) surgeon states he thinks its orthopedic - send me to an ortho surgeon.  Ortho does x rays of my neck , right shoulder, shows arthritis in neck and a small bone spur on the top of shoulder. Says he is completely baffled with the swelling, cannot find any swollen hard lymph glands.  I asked him not to send me to someone else can he help me find the answer.  He has me scheduled for MRI on next Thursday. Puts me of 800 mg Advil twice a day until MRI is done.  I am scared to death I am a single parent and just cant seem to get the answers I need.  Does lymphoma swell and recede withanti inflammatory medications.
posted_time: Post  by sara1213 » Sat Sep 03, 2005 7:08 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi sara1213, NSAID's such as Advil/Ibuprofen decrease inflammatory processes related to injury, infection, etc., and discomfort related to arthritic conditions. It would not, to my knowledge, have an effect regarding lymphoma. Diagnosis of lymphoma is done by labwork, Ct scan, excisional lymph node biopsy, etc. In my opinion, considering the location, evaluation is certainly warranted of the "fatty tumor" by excision and should be done  to rule out any underlying pathological disorder. I would certainly inquire about this with your physician. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: Hi there.  I too have had one lymph gland swollen since I was 8.  (I am 24 now)  I was told sometimes they just don't return to normal size.  Anyways, I have had a few more this year, and went to the doctor.  The first doctor said if the one in my armpit didn't go away within a month, to come back for a biopsy. Two months later it was 1/2 the size, yet not completely gone.  So I went back. Different doctor this time. He said that they are soo small, (I would guess about 1-1.5cm) and just to watch them.  He also said, (he also does naturopathic medicine as well as western) that sometimes they will swell when your digestive system isn't working that well, or your diet is not great.  (which mine isn't)  He suggested getting a homeopathic medicine called:  '"Lymphomosol"  which clears out the lymph system of the toxins they are trying to get rid of. I went to the herbal store and bought it the next day.  I am not using it until Wednesday when I quit smoking.  The doctor at the store said it flushes out the lymphatic system.  It was $16 but called "lymposot"  I hope that yours is nothing serious.  I was also told that if you have one swollen for years, it isn't really a concern.  They will go up and down, as mine does when I am sick or cut myself shaving like yesterday.

title: Why am I afraid to go to Dr again?
content: Thank You for this site...In 1995 1year after daughterborn, green discharge only one side of R nipple...never got results. In 2002(estimate) I went to Dr. for a lump on my rib above my L  breast.Ultrasound..Dr. says no shadow? I let it go, but is egg shaped and hard, still there, hasn't gotten too much larger. Stll have ugle dark camafluge green discharge one nipple when squeezed lightly from only one (HOLE) upper outer duct. This is opposite breast than chestbone lump.  2003 I notice a dime size firm irregular lump in R breast. Go to Dr.not until Jan 2005  spot mammogram=ultrasound. Dr. said Category 4 small calcifications clustered, lump is about 3.5cm/4.3cm./5cm. Noticable white area of mammogram film that I could see.  He took a lot of images. recommended incisional biopsy, I am scared, so I opted  for 2nd opinion from Breast spaecialist. She says take Danocrine, it is Fibrocystic.  Gave me info and sent me on my way to come back and monitor meds in 4 wks.  I read the papers she gave me...I don't have this.I have no pain, there is an attatched wormy feeling lump, they are not cystic, and movable. I wrote too much, but now, swollen painful when touched ankle, lumps in legs, what feels like a cobblestone road on my ribcages , and this might sound more crazy than the rest, but is it possible to see cancer from the outside of the skin?  Not with any marks or color, or open sores, it actually only looks like nicely healed scars, or dents that are just barely inverted. Some the size of a pencilhead, others the size of quarters. You actually have to look at my skin  on an angle in the light, but in all honesty, everytime I look for one of these barely noticeable mark, sure enough there is a swollen ball or lump behind it.  I am afraid of Dr, but I am a mother of three.  My amily knows that I have these things.  they think i am crazy. Im 29 I have Von Willebrand's Disease, and I have known this for a while, but since the Dr. said it's not breast cancer, I have not been back.  I know that I should, but I can't.  And the times that I get really scared, I will call and it will take me forever to get an appt, so I just put it in the back of my head, or i research it online.  I think that is why my family thinks I'm crazy because a normal person would go to the dr.  Why can't I ?Thank you for listening

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear momof three,  Why did your doctors excludebreast cancer? upon what evidence? micro calcifications in the mammogram is very serious...beside it's quite big...you have to get it biopsied....either excisional with a safety margin or at least FNAC (Fine needle aspiration Cytology). You must have the greenish discharge cultured and for cytology as well.  This is serious... and Cancer should be ruled out or ruled in ....the only thing to do that is by seeing tissues under the microscope...please have it biopsied so that you can rest your mind and have a proper diagnosis.  You can do a tumor marker as well, the CA 15-3 and the CEA.Do a Chest X-ray to see what are theses bumps in your ribs.  Tell me how it goes, best regards,

title: Lump 1cm below ear.
content: Hi there,  I have a firm lump / nodule about one centimetre below the bottom of my left ear, near to the top of my jawbone. It's directly below the ear.  It's about one centimetre in length and perhaps half a centimetre wide. I've noticed it there for about one week. It's painless, although I can make the area tender by constantly fiddling with it. I had mumps last November which resulted in swelling in that region, but I recovered from that fully. I had infectious mononucleosis as a teenager, so I should be immune to both of these illnesses now.  Otherwise, I'm fairly healthy. I'm 21, have never smoked and rarely drink. I've suffered from urticaria since January 2005, which I control with either fexofenadine or high dose loratadine. I have no other symptoms. I rarely suffer from colds and flu and don't recall having an infection recently.  I guess I've just fallen into the trap of looking things up on the internet, which is dangerous as a layman. I work full-time so it's hard for me to see a doctor: do you think I have anything to worry about at this stage? Should I wait a while?  Thanks for any help: I really appreciate it.
posted_time: Post  by Barn » Sun Jul 31, 2005 6:40 pm

author: marymalcolm  Guest Posts: 18 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 1:19 pm Location: Burleson, Texas  Contact:   Contact marymalcolm       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Barn!  It sounds like even if there is nothing to worry about - you are already worried.  From reading your post, it seems you have run the gamut of illnesses, and for that reason you may be hypersensitive to any new occurrences in your body.    This isn't a bad thing, but it can be exasperating to worry about what might be going on, and stress can be just as problematic as any other major illness.  It is for that reason that I would recommend you go ahead and try to see a physician.  I realize it may be difficult with your work schedule, but it would be much worse to continue to speculate on what might be happening.  I wish you the best! Mary

He noted that the tonsil on that side was rather red, so he put me on a course of antibiotics for a week. He told me to give it two weeks (one with antibiotics and a further one week) and then return if the swelling had not subsided.  I went back to the doctor today because the swelling had not gone down even after the antibiotics. He took another look at my throat and said "well, it's not red anymore, but it's about twice the size of the other tonsil". He says that the next step is to visit an Ear, Nose and Throat specialist.  Unfortunately I won't be able to get an appointment for a couple more weeks as I shall be moving back to my university city during this time. I'll need to get a referral from a doctor up there.  This leaves me time to worry.   A lymph node swelling that doesn't respond to antibiotics coupled with unilateral tonsillar swelling can't be good, right?

author: marymalcolm  Guest Posts: 18 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 1:19 pm Location: Burleson, Texas  Contact:   Contact marymalcolm       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Jo!  I am so sorry to read about all you have been through!  How strong you must be to have survived so much, and still be active in your life!  I want to commend you for being proactive in asking for support to your concerns, but I also want to urge you to go ahead and make that appointment with your physician.  Most physicians would not see concerns such as yours as a 'simple' problem, and with your family history it might be best to go in for a check-up anyway.  Anytime you are concerned about something going on in your body, there is a certain amount of stress that goes along with those concerns.  Unfortunately, the stress can build up and cause a myriad of health problems all on it's own.    I truly hope you find the answers you are looking for after speaking with your physician.  They are there to help, and I hate to think that you might let this go by because you think it is too small to be a problem.  That you are concerned makes it big enough to need addressing.  I wish you the best, Mary

author: annamalenna  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Wed Jan 05, 2005 11:29 pm Location: USA
title: Nondiagnostic core biopsy...What  now?
content: Hi, I have a question after a recent biopsy.   Last October I had an ultrasound of my thyroid due to autoimmune hypothyroidism.  It showed a nodule on the lower left pole and several extrathyroidal nodules thought to be nodes.  They were all 5mm or so and inferior to both lobes.  There was also one that was about 1 x .7 cm, also inferior, on the left.    A follow up ultrasound in Feb. reported stable, but did not mention the original intrathyroidal nodule.  A third  ultrasound in July also did not detect any thyroid nodules but showed the inferior nodes .  It showed that the larger nodule had increased some in size and the Endo recommended ENT appt.    ENT ordered ultrasnd guided fine needle biopsy.  The Docter who performed the biopsy decided while viewing the ultrasound that a core needle was neccessary and took two samples.  Between sticks he asked if I'd had a CT of my chest, but didn't say why.  The assistant asked him if he wanted something about a sample preparation?? for lymphoma which is why I posted in this catagory.   The labs came back as muscle and fibrous tissue.  ENT says basically nondiagnostic.  (Did it miss, I guess?  It felt like being knuckled in the trachea).   ENT says I can wait a few months, do another ultrasound in Dec. and see it's grown---or excise now.  Since it's lower than my collar bone and behind the sternocl. muscle I would love to avoid surgery (and scar).  However,  I am a bit extra concerned because in the last 2 1/2 years I have developed multiple bumps on bones.  I have some frontal bossing, a bulge at right ethmoid sinus, one on the back of my right hand, one on my right heel and a large one on the 3rd costochondral anterior right which is clearly visible.  I am beginning to get one opposite to this and the end of the right rib under my arm is thickening.  An MRI was done of my chest in Jan. for the large one and although there is enlargement of the bone there  was no other finding.  Chest x-rays show nothing.  Family Dr. said I'm just getting older and I'm going to be "lumpy-bumpy".  But this started at 36 and that's not so old.  Also no one else in my family is "lumpy-bumpy "   I am not satisfied with this diagnosis.    I have had endocrine labs for acromegaly -negative.  I have also had 24 hr cortisol due to new stretch marks on my abdomen without weight gain (besides I didn't get them with pregnancies).  It was also neg.  Sed rate and rheumatoid factor --neg.  The only abnormal labs have been thyroid related and my last WBC count done in Dec. 03 which was slightly below normal.   I also have a lump (firmish rubbery) on the edge between my hard and soft palate (newly discovered) on left side and my right tonsil has been slightly larger for over a year.  Usually my tonsils can not be seen (my family doctor asked if I'd had them out when I was her new patient).    For the last few months I am running an intermittant low grade temp 99-100, which is unusual for me as being hypo I tend to stay in the 96-97 range.   I have intermittant periods of swollen extremities and numbness/pain in fingers, hands and sometimes entire arm.   I have some memory and cognitive deficits.  I forget the names of people I know.  I cannot organize, and my formerly excellent perception of spacial distance  is gone.  I get lost in conversations but my hearing tests above average.     I have an excess of estrogen to progesterone and have begun progest. drops sublingual.  Family Dr. says this is what is causing rise in temp.  I have had headaches for over two years behind right eye/forehead/ ethmoid lump.    I have been told that I have Fibromyalgia (which I doubt).  I have shrunk almost an inch in the last  1 1/2 years but bone density is still in normal range.   I have a family history of  malignant melanoma moles.  I have recently had to have many moles removed.  All were atypical.  Two required re-excision for complete removal and one was severely displastic requiring a re-excision with  1 cm margins.  When I get my current stitches out,  I have to have yet another one removed.  I am so tired of being cut! (but recognize with my mother and uncle (twice) having melanoma and my sun-baked childhood at the beach this is what I have to do).    I also have about 1-1 1/2 inch long, narrow rubbery nodes under both arms and some on the sides of my neck (these are small bean and pea sized,  deep and firmer).  I am sorry this is so long, but I wanted to be thorough.  I suppose I should add that I'm 38 y o, female, ex-one pack/day smoker (quit Dec. 99).  Anyway, the short of this long post is that I don't know whether to wait or have this cervical node removed??  If you've read this far--thank you!  and if you have any advice it would be much appreciated.  I'm wonder if I've posting in the wrong topic.  If I have please advise me.  Thanks sincerely,  Anne L.
