title: [no title]
content: Hi katat20202, Do you notice this happening perhaps after shaving  in an awkward direction against the grain of hair growth? Sometimes trauma to the skin permits bacteria in the area and causes inflammation/infection that may include the hair follicles. If the areas re-appear have them evaluated by your physician.  Sincerely, Rntdj

author: MizB  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 4:29 am Location: California
title: Daughter of Lymphoma Survivor... Found Swollen LN Behind Ear
content: (I had accidently posted this in the wrong forum, so if it looks familiar, that is why.  I've since remedied the mistake.)  First of all, I would like to say "thank you" to anyone who takes the time to read and/or reply to this post.  Also, I'd like to point out that I am making an appointment to see my GP.  However, it can take up to two weeks to get in to see her, I need some wise words in the meantime!   My father was diagnosed with Lymphoma about five years ago (and has survived).    Yesterday while my husband, two children and I were out to dinner, I swept my hair behind my ear and felt a large, hard bump there.  I researched what this lymph node could be called and I guess it's called "postauricular".  It is about (if I had to make a 'guess-timate') about 1/4 of an inch in diameter.  It hurts a bit to push on, but I have to push with pressure to get that reaction.  I guess I should point a few things out that may or may not have a part to play in this:    ~I have a bad cavity on the back, lower part of my left jaw.  The gum is slightly swollen around it.  ~I have three small (about the size of a pea) boo-boo's (for lack of a better word at 2.48 in the morning!   ) on the left side of my head (I'm a klutz... always whacking my head on a low-hanging cabinet).I am constantly scratching them by accident.  One of them has become sore and has a bit of an infection.  ~I have severe Tendonitis that goes from my left shoulder, up the left side of my neck and all the way down my arm.    ~I had a really bad sinus infection for about three weeks that I got over about a week ago.  I'm basically falling apart!     I have checked the rest of my body and there does not seem to be any other swollen lymph nodes at the moment.  The bottom line is I'm scared to death!  My father has suffered through this and I cannot help but be freaked out!  Also, in talking with my sister today, she has a hard lump in the exact same spot.  She's had it for about five years.  I have two small children (ages four and two) and I am I very frightened!   Not just for me, but for what this could possibly mean for them some day!
posted_time: Post  by MizB » Wed Aug 10, 2005 10:35 am

author: marymalcolm  Guest Posts: 18 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 1:19 pm Location: Burleson, Texas  Contact:   Contact marymalcolm       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi MizB!  I am so sorry for what your father went through, and for what you went through as his support system!  I am glad to hear that he is doing well today, and it is understandable that you would be especially sensitive to any out-of-place lumps you may find.  It sounds like you have a strong grasp on the consequences of waiting for treatment, so I want to applaud you for reaching out to your physician so quickly.  I wish the wait weren't so long, so possibly you could start calling each morning to see if there are any cancellations that would let you be seen earlier?  Before you go to your physician, I would recommend writing down a list of what has been going on lately.  Any symptoms, any new swelling areas, anything that you have noticed that is out of place.  I would also recommend you write down a list of questions and concerns; and I would urge you to let your physician know about your father's lymphoma during this visit.  I wish you the best! Mary
posted_time: Post  by marymalcolm » Thu Aug 11, 2005 9:24 am

author: MizB  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 4:29 am Location: California
title: Thanks!
content: Hi Mary!  Thank you for your concern and understanding!   It's funny that you mention calling and inquiring about a cancellation.  That's exactly what I did yesterday and I was seen by my GP.  I saw two GP's actually.  The first (my usual GP) seemed very distracted and rushed (she was the only GP in the office and was very busy).  She said that it was not Lymphoma.   However, I felt that something was missing from the exam, so my sister recommended her GP.    I was able to get in to see him this morning (just got back as a matter of fact).  He confirmed that it was not Lymphoma.  However, unlike my GP, he sat with me and explained exactly what Lymphoma consisted of and what to look for.  He gave me a full exam and gave me a 100% bill of health.   He also told me that I was right in getting it checked early because of my father's Lymphoma and I was correct to get a second opinion (I had explained my experience the day before).  So, again, I thank you for your concern and advice.  I now hope and pray for every person on this board that they may be as lucky as I have been!!!!!!

title: Lymph nodes
content: Hi,  Thank you for hosting this very important and helpful forum!  I have a question about swollen lymph nodes. I have had swollen cervical lymph nodes for a few months now. Actually, they may have been there even longer, but I guess I just noticed them a few months ago. There are nodes on both sides of my neck, with the largest ones on the left side. An ultrasound showed the largest one to be 1.9 cm, with others between 1.4 and 1.6 cm. I even have a couple of palpable, but small, supraclavicular nodes (less than 1 cm, but clearly palpable) on the left side. The ultrasound results note that the nodes appear benign, but I understand that ultrasound is not a reliable method to evaluate lymphadenopathy.   I have been evaluated by a surgeon to consider biopsy. When the surgeon examined me he found bilateral axillary lymph nodes as well. He sent me for another ultrasound of the breasts and underarm area, which revealed a 1.4 cm node on the left side, and a 1.2cm node on the right. The surgeon did not seem particularly concerned, and said that if they do not grow he will not recommend biopsy, even if they do not get smaller and disappear. Does that sound like the right course of action? Btw - I'm a 33 year old female.

author: marymalcolm  Guest Posts: 18 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 1:19 pm Location: Burleson, Texas  Contact:   Contact marymalcolm       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  First off, CONGRATULATIONS!!!!  How exciting it is to find out that you are having a baby!  Wow, have you been trying, or was this a 'surprise' addition???  Now, I'm not a physician, so this is not professional advice, but I wanted to tell you a bit about my personal experience.  Each month, for about the past five years as my hormones begin to surge, my underarms get tender.  I'm not positive that this is what is happening to you, but when I first asked my obgyn about it, he said that many women experience a similar pain.  I would recommend keeping an eye on any further 'developments', and certainly addressing these concerns with your physician at your exam in the next couple of weeks.  Meanwhile, if things get too painful, try applying a heating pad to the area, and make sure and keep a journal of this, and all the other "Wonderful" new pregnancy developments that are taking place.  Congratulations, and I wish you the best!!! Mary

author: marymalcolm  Guest Posts: 18 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 1:19 pm Location: Burleson, Texas  Contact:   Contact marymalcolm       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Krby!  Wow!  What a positive step for you to reach out for help as you have.  Nodes often swell to help the body deal with infection, and at times they don't return to their original size.  I'm not a physician, so I could not tell you exactly what's going on, but I would recommend being a bit more insistent with your concerns.  The next time you go to the doctor, come armed with a list of symptoms and any questions you have about these swelling nodes.  Let the doctor know just how much this concern is affecting your life, and hopefully they will take the time to sit down with you and address everything you have written out.  If this does not happen, you may need to find a separate physician to bring your concerns to.  Any time something 'strange' is happening in your body, you have the right to know what's going on.  I truly hope you find the answers you are seeking.  Best Wishes, Mary

author: marymalcolm  Guest Posts: 18 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 1:19 pm Location: Burleson, Texas  Contact:   Contact marymalcolm       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Jo!  I wanted to begin by telling you that I'm sorry for what you and your daughter have gone through!  How scary it must be to have a child so sick, after already experiencing such losses in your family through cancer.    Although I am fairly certain that a diagnosis would not missing something such as lymphoma, I feel it would do you well (if for no other reason than peace of mind!) to seek a second opinion.  Since you have been instructed to follow up with your physician in ten days, I would recommend doing so, but you need to write out a list of concerns and questions to take with you.  If you feel as if your doctor is not giving enough attention to these very important concerns, than you need to seek out a new doctor.    Now, I'm not recommending you change your physician, only that for your sake (and your daughter's) it might be best to have a fresh pair of eyes.    I wish you the best, Mary  P.S. Have you or your daughter gone through any type of grief therapy for the losses you have experienced?  This is unrelated to your post, but after experiencing such devastating losses as you have, it may do you well to have help in processing your grief.  When I was a teenager, I lost several friends within a year, and had a difficult time dealing with the pain.  I never told my family how much I hurt, and became quite sick from the unrecognized ‘stress’ I was experiencing.  I’m not saying by any means that this is what is happening with your daughter; only that therapy might help both of you work though some of your pain.

title: painful lump, back of neck, near hairline, dead center

author: marymalcolm  Guest Posts: 18 Joined: Wed Aug 10, 2005 1:19 pm Location: Burleson, Texas  Contact:   Contact marymalcolm       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Brian!  I can not offer any advice on what might be going on, but since you have not responded to antibiotics, or anti inflammatory medications, I would recommend going back to your doctor and requesting further diagnosis.  Possibly your doctor could order an x-ray, or a CT Scan so that you both could have a better 'picture' of what's going on.  Nodes swell as part of your body’s natural defense against infection, and often can take time for the swelling to go back down.    If it feels as if your doctor is not giving the level of care you need for this concern, it may be necessary for you to seek a second opinion.  Possibly your doctor needs to make an effort to explain a bit more about what could be going on, and you may need to let him know that you need that explanation.  I urge you to make a list of questions, anything on your mind, to take with you to your next appointment.  Best Wishes, Mary

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Reese, Lymph nodes commonly swell as a result of an infection bcause they are the bodies filtering system for bacteria. They may not return to their pre-infectious state even after the infection subsides. If you lab work has come back normal, and lymph nodes aren't increasing in size despite antibiotic treatment, and no other symptoms are present, that's likely why they are showing little concern. An ENT would be a specialist to evaluate you and alleviate any concerns. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi MSUFanatic, Lymph nodes most commonly enlarge as a result of infection because they are the bodies filtering system for bacteria etc. They may not return to their pre-infectious state even after the infection subsides. I would be more concerned if the area would enlarge and not decrease in size despite treatment or if you had other existing symptoms. I would still however suggest that you have the area evaluated by your physician at your next physical exam to alleviate any concerns. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Enlargement of the lymph nodes occurs primarily in response to infection or inflammation. I think you should continue taking treatment for your cold and to wait a little. If in the course of two weeks new lymph nodes appear or this one enlarges or you start having new symptoms you should get it checked out. If after two weeks are over it still remains the same size and has not decreased you should also get it examined.

posted_time: Post  by goodjunk » Wed Jul 13, 2005 3:33 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Size differs according to the condition. The consistency ranges from firm to hard (stony). What helps a physician diagnose a lymph node enlargement is the location and in some cases a characteristic tugging sensation when you roll it slightly. It is not something that appears on the skin its deeper. Rather than trying to diagnose yourself I think you should have it checked out especially if you do not have history of a recent infection/wound in the same arm.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Wed Jul 13, 2005 4:22 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Lymph node enlargement is diagnosed by palpation (feeling) rather than inspection (seeing). The armpits in particular are capacious and the largest lymph node will only lead to a bulge.

author: CrimsonLegacy  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Jul 10, 2005 8:16 pm Location: AL
title: Swollen Lymph Node
content: I'll start from the begining to hopefully make it easier. I had lymph node come up on the back right side of my head a little over a year ago. It was close to my mastoid bone, according to some illustrations possibly postauricular or occipital. It was probably the size of a peanut and quite hard and painful. It would come up and go down in a matter of minutes. I went to two different doctors who said it was probably a infection and one prescribed me Doxycyclene, and the node went down about a week later and it didn't return for about six months. When it returned six months ago, I just got my prescription of Doxycyclene refilled, and the node went down about a week later. It is still larger than the one on the other side of my head. However, it is no larger than 1/2 centimeter. I had shaved my head the night before each time the node enlarged. Is it possible that had something to do with it?  Anyway, now i'll move to the present. A couple of weeks ago I went for a physcal, and the doctor said I had a swollen lymph node on the right side of my neck. I had a sore throat around a month earlier, and I have allergies so I keep alot of sinus drainage. He advised me just to keep a check on it, and come back in four weeks. Well, every since then I've constantly been feeling my neck. When I extend my head backward I can see the lymph node, but otherwise it is unnoticable. It also feels like the size of peanut or bean. It feels hard, but it insn't irregular in shape, it is extremely moveable, but it isn't sore. I also found a small node behind my left ear, that is smaller than 1/2 centimeter. My throat started to fill a little raw, so I went to another doctor about a week later. He said my throat was a little red, and the lymph in my throat was a little swollen. He gave me a shot for my allergies and some sample of Zyrtec. He said he thought the node was just viral and nothing to worry about. However, I voiced my concerns and he done a cbc and cmp for bloodwork. He also done a chest x-ray, and a E.K.G. The e.k.g was due to my high blood pressure. The tests all came back normal. Do you think I should listen to the doctor, and quit mashing on my neck every couple of minutes or go to another doctor? The node has been there for two weeks now.
posted_time: Post  by CrimsonLegacy » Sun Jul 10, 2005 8:46 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi CrimsonLegacy, I understand your concern that this maybe something more serious than your doctors are saying. However, in performing their normal function of defending against infection and inflammation, lymph nodes tend to enlarge. In that sense I think it is very probable that your shaving had something to do with it. As long as you have been examined and were cleared by a doctor I think you have nothing to worry about.  You should only seek his attention if the lymph nodes enlarge in size or new lymph nodes arise in the coming few months.

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: What i meant by the biopsy was the FNAC= fine needle aspiration Cytology....That's the first line of investigation if you want to put it this way. If the FNAC showed Cancer cells, then they make excise(remove) the node for confirmation and start doing the work up for cancer...chest -ray,Ct-scans, ultrasounds,tumor markers ,bone scan,etc.  No one can swear 100% it's cancer untill you can see cancer cells under the microscope... But your illness sounds serious...and should be investigated for seriously.  Best wishes,

author: stephanie0107  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Sun Jun 26, 2005 1:18 am Location: United States  Contact:   Contact stephanie0107       AOL
title: Lump under arm
content: Hello Friend, Based on your description, I feel confident in saying it is more than likely an ingrown hair follicle, esp w/ the rapid onset. This is nothing more than an infected follicle that will heal by itself or if too bothersome, you can pinch the area to force it to come to a head same as a facial pimple and use tweezers (dip in alcohol first) to withdraw the hair which has more than likely encircled itself in the lump. As far as prevention, get some facial scrub like Neutrogena scrub and vigorously scrub under arms and bikini line area twice a week. If you notice any ingrowns hairs, you can attempt to squeeze and pluck them out and they will then heal spontaneoulsly. If you happen to be waxing, this practice actually promotes the problem, but can be treated as above. In the event that it enlarges and does not appear to be infectious in origin, you may consider visiting your PCP or dermatologist. If you are able to move the lump and it does not seem to be securely rooted in place, it should subside on its own.  In the event that you are continuously afflicted with these complaints, may want to ask your dr about a low dose antibiotic such as tetracycline, esp if facial area is also involved. Good luck and LMK if you require addtional info.

title: Lump on head, new lump in neck.
content: About 2 months ago I noticed a small hard lump on the back of my head. It's about even with the top of my ear and about half way between my ear and the center of my head. A couple of weeks later I started getting headaches almost every day that were usually throbbing and generally radiated from the back of my head forward. I went to see my doctor who briefly felt the lump and said that it was nothing to worry about and probably a cyst. I had a skull/sinus x-ray as he suspected sinusitis as a cause for the headaches. Now that the headaches have gone away I'm not longer concerned about them but I recently (4 or 5 days ago) noticed 3 hard, small lumps on the left side of my neck (about 2 inches up from my collarbone, all seem to be on my trapezius). Two of them are on the back, one right above the other, and the other is on the front. The one in the front I am able to hold in between my fingers and is very mobile. The two on the back are identical and feel just like little bumps underneath the skin. And like I said earlier, they are all fairly hard.  How big does a lymph node need to be in this area to be considered enlarged?  The reason all this has me concerned is that from what I've read on the internet masses in that area of the neck are not very common and usually malignant. I've also read that the scalp is the area that drains to these lymph nodes. Is there a possibility that the bump on my head wasn't a cyst and is actually a hardened lymph node and that it has drained into this new spot?  Like I've read in so many other posts I'm constantly worried. It seems as though once I finally put one concern behind me another one presents itself...sometimes resurfacing some of my old concerns.

content: 5 nights ago I woke up in the middle of the night with sharp pain in my neck. i reached to feel my neck and noticed a lump under the skin on the right side of my neck, near the center at the hairline. the next morning i went to the doctor to have the lump examined. she found what appears to be a spider bite about  2 inches below the lump. she said that the lump was probably a swollen lymph node in reaction to the spider bite and put me on cephalexin antibiotics. she said it should clear up in about 5-7 days. it has been 5 days and although the pain is less severe (during the first few days I could barely turn my head and would wince if i touched the lump) the lump is still there and relatively painful (I can tough it lightly but if i press on it is is painful). the "spider bite" is also still on the back of my neck but it seems to be getting smaller every day. it is a purple raised bump with what looks like a scab in the center. i have been taking 500 mg. of cephalexin 4 times a day but it doesnt seem to be doing the trick. could the gland have reacted to some spider venom and not bacteria?  my question is what else could this lump be? it has been 5 days and it is not healed. if it is a swollen gland in reaction to the spider bite, how long will it take to not be painful? how long will it take not to be swollen anymone?  thank you so much for any help you can give me.

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: sick of this...
content: I know you all are as sick of hearing about my issues, as I am in having them...  I saw the Doctor (again) on Tuesday (May 24). The one who had my lab work done.  He said the labs looked good. We were both especially relieved to see the HIV NEGATIVE results in black and white.  He examined me again, and we discussed the mass (node?) in my neck.  I reminded him that a couple of days before the node appeared (back in early April), I had a SEVERE (like swallowing razor blades) sore throat (both me and my partner did), after talking with a man & wife from West Virginia who were visiting California despite obvious and severe cold/flu type symptoms. The sore throat that my partner and I experienced was particularly bad at night and included mild fevers, chills and seemed to resolve quickly (36 hours +/-). It was after this that I first NOTICED the swollen node/mass.  He said that was good news in favor of my node just being reactive.  I thought I had told him this before, but I guess he forgot.  I feel so flustered in Doctor's offices and I generally just blurt out all the things I've been thinking about and try to squeeze in as many questions as possible. This system we have for patient care has room for improvement.  Anyway, I told him I was sick that day too! (Tues, May 24). I had been (at that time) sick for about 5 days, with serious and unrelenting sinus pain, nasal drip, sneezing, and pronounced, unforgiving coughing (especially when trying to fall asleep), and mild fevers. (All since resolved 95% with only a postnasal drip and minor sinus congestion remaining).  He was completely disinterested in my current symptoms.  He said the next step was to have the node removed and analyzed. Then he asked if we had done any imaging and I reminded him that he hadn't ordered anything. He said, OK, that would be first.  So, now I am trying to get the insurance approvals, etc for an MRI. (w & w/out contrast) that he Rx'd.  Then, on FRI. (May 27), I kept an appt I had a few weeks ago to see a General Surgeon locally.  I half expected him to dismiss me as being absurd; especially since, to me, the node was still feeling like it was getting a little bit smaller (SLOWLY!!).  Well, he didn't. He said this is very serious. He said he is almost sure it is some sort of cancer... Said that more often than not, this type of single node is related to a head, neck or throat cancer.  He ordered a CT of the "Soft Tissue, Neck", Chest & Abdomen.  Said because of my weight (about 60 to 80 lbs heavy), that there may be dozens of nodes we can't see or feel. Said, because of my weight that I likely have had this node/mass in my neck for a long time and just didn't ever notice it.  Wrote on the work order the following:  "Enlarged LM" "Right, anterior cervical triangle" "r/o chest, abd, neck lymphodeophy"  He stated that he doubts very seriously it is Lymphoma since he can’t feel any other nodes, and since I don’t use tobacco, and I’m only 36 he said it is unlikely to be Lymphoma.  He said that a single node like this usually means that I have mouth cancer, neck cancer, esophageal cancer, larynx cancer, etc. He looked in my mouth and said one tonsil looks bigger then the other.  So, of course, now I am having a TOTAL MELTDOWN!   One day, I feel like it's getting smaller, and going to be gone in a few days and I can laugh about it...The next I am afraid I will be dead in 6 months.   QUESTION 1:  I can likely only get one of the two imaging orders preapproved from insurance. (And the hospital will ONLY book an appt if it's preauthorized!).  Based on all the facts, which one should I do..?  Also, I am so unhappy with the medical community where I live (the closest Dr is 30 minutes away), and even that is in a rural area with a population of 1,000. The hospital here is small, and always has a week plus wait for MRI or CT.  I can drive in to the city (San Francisco) but it's 4 hours each way. I have found a specialist (Head & Neck surgeon) who seems to be well respected in the city. According to his profile he specializes in diseases of the neck and cancers in particular.  But, I can't make several trips to the city, especially overnight ones, unless it is mandatory to my survival.  I have made a tentative appt with this new Dr in the city for about 2 weeks from now. He doesn't accept my PPO, but said they will help me get reimbursed (I'm guessing about 50%), but who cares about a few hundred $. Said that if I need surgery that would be in the hospital so anesthesia, room, meds, etc would be covered by insurance since the hospital of course takes my insurance. So, I don't mind paying the surgeon out of pocket his fees directly, (guessing maybe up to $ 2 or 3,000?), and trying to get up to half back.  Before I leave to see him, I would think he would want to have CT or MRI with me for best diagnosis. Which one should I do..? I can't stay in the city for more than about 24 to 36, maybe 48 hours, so I need to plan ahead and maximize my time there.  Of course, if it is cancer, etc and I need to do chemo or radiation to save my life, etc I will make drastic changes (hire extra staff etc) at whatever long term damage to my finances there is. But, I need to pace myself for time away for now, in case I do need to do these things like radiation and my life might depend on being able to be away for a day or two weekly or whatever.  QUESTION 2: Whatever it is, will waiting for 2 more weeks have any negative repercussions..?  QUESTION 3: I understand from research that lymphomas rarely show any evidence on blood work. That they typically present as one, enlarged node, especially in the neck, that is hard, non-movable, large (greater than 1.5cm x 1.5cm) and non-tender. (All of which apply to me). But, for other cancers, is this also true. In other words, is there any comfort in the lab results showing nothing abnormal when considering other cancers of the head, neck, etc..?  QUESTION 4: If it is some other type of cancer, I gather from research that the prognosis is much worse than if it is Lymphoma, with only a slight chance of long-term survival. Where can I find statistics about the chance of survival..?  I am beginning to hate my new life. I wake up every morning and pray that it was all just a bad nightmare. I am already sick of Doctors and Doctor’s offices.  There is NOTHING comforting, nurturing, calming or supportive about a Dr's visit. The offices are always drab, poorly light in fluorescent bulbs, cold unfriendly surfaces, matter-of-fact clinical feeling. And the irony is, despite all this posturing, I've been to 4 Dr's now, and still no real information.  Thank you for taking the time to read my information.  - Michael

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Michaelii,  Well, so that i wouldn't  forget anything...let me answer your questions one by one:-  Q1: get a CT for the head and neck done ... it's simple,diagnostic and less expensive... if he found an abnormality that he cannot distinguish with CT...he'll order MRI by himself.  Q2:waiting for 2 more weeks is not hazardous...you've already waited for months and nothing serious has happened to you.  I just want to add that... having chronic sinus problems....one big tonsil and all these ENT  problems are better checked out by an ENT specialist...that will save you a lot of fuss...ENT are surgeons as well... let him examine you...and if he feels that the enlarged tonsil is query...he'll remove it and have it analyzed so you can call this a biopsy as well. It'll be beneficial to have that CT scan of head and neck done.  Q3:blood results are a good negative test where some of them are indicative for the bulk of a tumor...for an example like LDH enzyme, and if all of your blood counts,chemistry  and enzymes are already normal...then it's highly suggestive that you are....or else the human body would have manifested his objection of having a tumor in one way or another.... you cannot be perfectly free and have no blood abnormality!!....but at the same time no one can promise...there are  cases which breaks the rules.  Q4:if it is ....God FOrbids ....any kind of cancer...don't look for statistics and follow your doctor's regimen for treatment.. you'll only get yourself exhausted and more stressed out...and you'll make your doctor more confused ....  you can then take our opinion here about your therapy (IF IT WAS PROVEN YOU HAVE CANCER) .... We have BRILLIANT oncology (cancer) doctors on the site....  PLEASE DON'T JUMP INTO CONCLUSIONS!   Please visit an ENT doctor (he's a surgeon at the same time) tell him about your sinus  and nose problems,the lymph node and your enlarged tonsil....show him the CT scan.   I am sure everything will get sorted out very soon...just be patient dear and we are all here for you    Best regards,

No other symptoms whatsoever and as you know all my CBC etc was normal, plus, today the node DOES feel a bit smaller (even the surgeon today said it is a tiny bit smaller and softer), so I am just taking one day at a time.  Maybe I am manic-depressive and this is just my manic phase ...But I just don't accept that this is cancer...hopeully I'll be right since I've physched myself into believeing it must be something benign, a malignancy pathology report would send me into deep shock!  Thoughts are always appreciated!!  - Michael

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: NOW WHAT?
content: Ok, so today I went to the surgeon for the FNA.  The Dr had to poke me 5 times!!  Each time he got ONLY blood (What he called "Old Blood"..??)  After the first one he mubled, "Dude, you've got a cyst"..(?)  He did some smears on the microscope slides (I don't think ANY of it took! It was smeared with my blood, and NO cells made it I'm sure!!!) Maybe I could be totally wrong, but none of the stuff he took out of neck made it to any of the 6 slides he preparred.  He said he was concerned it was vascular...(?)..So I said, Like an anyurism? I thought that's what it was all along since it was/is so pulsatile.  He said "yeah, maybe"..."I am very confused and baffled".."I am very very puzzled"...  He said, I want you to go the hospital IMMEDIATELY. I'll meet you there in the ER.  So, now myself being baffled, I did just that...  Turns out, he ordered an Ultrasound.  The technician took about 45 minutes with the ultrasound on my neck, probing and proding. She said it was a brand new one, latest and greatest. Anyway, the radiologist (A Dr) came in and said ..." looks like lymph nodeS to me"   I said NodeS, plural? He said yeah, a couple of them...  I said, well, I am concerend about it being vascular in nature and/or some type of lymphoma, or malignant neoplasm. He said, yeah, he can understand that, but based on their location and the fact that they look like they aren't on the jugular(?) he thinks they are "just nodes"..  So, now my neck is VERY sore. The mass, whatever it is, is extremely tender and feels like a bruise would feel. PLUS, it is about 25% larger, noticable by just looking at me, and much more pulsatile.  I am still having the CT for tomorrow, but the Radiologist Dr said not to bother with the abdomen, chest or head CT's and not to drink the barium contrast they gave me.  He said they will just do the neck CT now.  I called the Dr that tried the FNA today and his office closed early, I never saw him at the hospital.  I am SOOOOO CONFUSED NOW!  What, if anything, does ANY of this mean?

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Michaelii....  It's a good call for the FNAC doctor to order the Ultrasound. They excluded an aneurysm.. you can feel it's pulsatile because you were anxious...not because it's really pulsatile in nature...only a surgeon or a skilled internist can differentiate a pulsatile mass from vigorous pulsations out of anxiety.  Ofcourse your neck will be sore for a few days...you've been punctured more than 5 times...and it's tender because you are bruised from the punctures. You can feel it's getting bigger because blood has accumulated around it and clotted (from the FNAC attempts) so you can feel it bigger,tender and sore.  The Ultrasound showed multiple nodes but not on the jugular... it depends on their site ,size,consistency and shape to determine if they're malignant or inflammatory...or even significant of any other disease.   Next step is to do the CT of the neck...and preferrably a LDH enzyme level in the blood which reflects the bulk of the lymph nodes IF we are suspecting any affection.  So waiting to hear about the CT scan results, Best regards,

title: CT Scan Results
content: I just got back from the CT scan. The radiologist (Dr) said it looked like a node, or maybe 2 swollen.  I asked if he thought it was malignant, and he said he had no idea. He said he looked for other cancer (I presume looking for a "primary" in case the cytology comes back positive.)   He said he didn't see anything else that looked alarming. He said it looks like the node(s) are filled with blood/fluid and they did the CT w & w/out contrast.  I asked him if what he was thinking, and he said that "Maybe Lymphoma" ..."Since it is so abnormally large..." (I forgot to ask the exact dimensions). He said, if so, Lymphoma is very treatable (I am optimistic on this since I don't yet have any "B" type symptoms.)  He was a little somber sounding, but did offer that since I had a sore throat prior to the appearance of the node, that it lends itself more to a reactive node.  (I think I did, jeeze, it's all becoming a blur now, maybe I just remembered it that way as a form of denial or something..?).  I will ask the size tomorrow when I go to pickup the films after he's dictated the findings.  Also, the lab has no news on the pathology report from the FNA done yesterday. They "might" have a prelim tomorrow, and the surgeon promises a call if so.  The hospital lab said it looks like Tues before they have any results.  I revisited the surgeon who did the 5 poke FNA yesterday and discussed the Ultrasound and CT findings. He said again it looked like "old blood" when he tried to do the FNA.  I asked for his thoughts, and he said he hasn’t any.   I asked if he would do some more blood labs to rule out things like Mono, etc. I specifically asked him if we could do an LDH enzyme level. He said, "Let's just wait and see what happens".  I get so frustrated. On one hand, Drs order things willy-nilly with wanton abandon for the cost or financial repercussions, but when a patient wants a specific test, forget about it!  He said, the next step, if the FNA comes back inconclusive, is to do another FNA at the hospital, this time performed by the Radiologist, using CT or Ultrasound to help locate the node (site) for the FNA.  I think I am ready to just have it removed in an excisional biopsy. The FNA was VERY painful, and I am sick of all the guessing without any results, and such non-committal medical people.  I thought since all he got was "old blood" that this was good in a way. Guess I am grasping at straws. When I talked to the surgeon again today, he did say that it was "softer in there than he thought once he stuck the needle in there and felt it with the needle"..? Whatever that means?!!?  Aren't reactive nodes supposed to be filled with Lymph fluid though? Isn't it bad that it was like “old blood” on the FNA?  I am still planning a 4-hour trip on Monday with the new Dr, and ENT, and surgeon of the Head, Neck & Throat who has a sub-specialty in oncology. Hopefully he will shed some light on things, and no doubt will want to see the lab results, film, etc to date.   Symptomatically, all I have is a very slight (barely perceptible sore throat), and minor postnasal drip, with occasional (2 to 3 per day) sneezing fits (5 to 6 sneezes), and NO OTHER symptoms.  NO abdominal pains, no ear aches, no hip pain, no fevers, no night sweats, no itching, no eczema, no other pain (except for the site where he did the FNA, which is still HUGE very pulsatile (visably from the front) and tender)  Thoughts, as always, appreciated!

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: FNA Preliminary Results
content: Regrettably, I received the results from the 5 pass FNA from last week.  Here is what it reads:  "A": Is two smears. One is fixed and is Pap stained. Other is unfixed and quik stained.  "B" : is also two smears. One fixed & Pap stained, other unfixed and quik stained.  "C" is also two smears. One fixes & Pap stained, other unfixed and quik stained.  MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION: (06-03-05)  "A" : Shows mostly blood & debris  "B"  : Present is blood and necrotic debris. No definite tumor is identified. There are some rare degenerating cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.  "C" : Shows some foamy macrophages & some necrotic debris and degenerating cells.  MICROSCOPIC DIAGNOSIS: (06-06-05)  A, B & C, Fine Needle Aspiration of Neck Mass  Blood, Necrotic Debris and Degenerating Cells.  COMMENT: There are few degenerating cells with hyperchromatic nuclei but not enough viable material is persent to make a disgnosis of malignancy.  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Can someone help me understand??? It sounds awful to me. Like if they found "SOME" necrotic debris, along with HYPERCHROMATIC NUCLEI that these are typical of cancerous cells, especially knowing how little the surgeon actually got from the samples (FNA) after 5 attempts.  PLEASE give me advice!!!

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: are you sick of hearing about this yet..?
content: Later on Monday I visited the ENT.  He did a laryngoscope & said everything looked "normal"   He said the ulcer on my tongue was not alarming.  Ears looked fine.  Sore throat not alarming.  He said the node IS alarming.  (Or NodeS as per the radiologist's reports)  When forced to "guess" he said he best guess would be lymphoma.  I asked him (the ENT) if I should have an excisional biopsy done of the node and/or tongue lesion. He said not at this point. He said the node (or nodes) may "have to come out eventually" but it would not be necessary at this point.  I asked what stage (I, II, III, IV, etc) he would guess my Lymphoma being in, if he had to guess, and IF it turns out to be Lymphoma. I asked this based on the fact that the first 5 pass FNA was so inconclusive would this point to a less aggressive or less invasive Lymphoma if that's what it is, and he said not necessarily. He said staging is a complicated process, done with an Oncologist and not something he could guess about.  I asked him about the pathology report for the FNA done a few days earlier and he said it means NOTHING. (Is that true?)  He said that the next step would be to have another FNA. I protested saying that they are inconclusive and unreliable.   He agreed, BUT, said that around the corner was the BEST FNA clinic in the world. They almost never ever miss a diagnosis. The UCSF FNA medical center. An entire center dedicated to the art and science of FNA!  So, we hurriedly wrapped up our session and scooted off to the UCSF FNA clinic.  There, the staff was amazing! Professional. Competent. Thorough.  Clean, relaxing offices. Tranquil decor. Pleasant and hygienic procedure rooms.  A Dr did two "pulls" and studied them under the scope, RIGHT THERE!  He said it didn't look like lymphoma at first glance (using the fairly inaccurate "quik stain" method), and that it "...looked maybe cystic in nature.."  He said that they wanted to pull enough sample to be sure he had enough cells for cytology Or flow symmetry or something), and pulled another sample. He studied this also, RIGHT THERE!  Extra slides were setup for distribution to a more detailed lab (flow symmetry, cytology?,  etc?)  The FNA Dr said he wanted to be sure to get enough before I left, so he called the head of his dept in. She was amazing also!  She made one more pull, this time from the front angle to get a different sample. As she pulled, he commented to her...."..Looks cystic..", she said, "..no, I think infection...I see some puss.."  (Of course, that sounds good to me!! But, then again the puss could be a by-product of the previous 5 stabs FNA the local surgeon tried on me 4 days earlier)  They both agreed that they had enough cells to get a clear diagnosis.  After, I asked the Dr what he thought. He said:  - Infection - Lymphoma (Hodgkin’s or Non-Hodgkins) - Squamous Cell Carcinoma  In that order.  My question (as if I only have ONE!)  is about the later. I have only briefly heard about it. I thought it was associated more with tobacco use?  It is not as treatable as Lymphoma from what I understand.  Could it be related to the lesion on my tongue that the ENT dismissed as not being cause for concern..?  Finally, on another, hopefully unrelated note; I have had back pain in the same general area (under my left shoulder blade (scapula?) ) for about 2 weeks now. It is intermittent, and maybe a 3 or 4 on a 1 to 10 scale at it's worse. The node in question is on the right side of my neck. Does this sound related? Or could it just be stress/obesity/not sleeping right, etc? It only bothers me for a cumulative total of about 3 to 4 hours each day, sometimes I go an entire afternoon without noticing any pain or even remembering about it.  When I rub it, it does seem to help and my posture seems to make a difference (ie: slouching, or sitting in the car, etc seem to aggravate it more).  Well...That's it for now...as always, feedback is appreciated!!!!!!!!!!

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hello!  Pain in your shoulder blade...can be from ANYTHING! don't relate everything to your lymph node, please...!!  Let's wait and see what the new FNAC will say...don't jump into conclusions!! you are really stressing out yourself for nothing... wait till you have evident data in your hands and we can start treatment from there...  Don't just make hypothesis and build up things on no ground basis...this is really very tiring for you.  I'm a little bit worried though about your tongue lesion....how long has it been there? and did he check the lymph node circle of your pharynx...it's called Waldeyer's circle ...u cannot see it yourself because it's an imaginary circle rather than a drawn one  ... but a good ENT would have checked it...I am sure he did but never told ya?  tell me the FNAC results when they're out.  Best wishes,

content: I am in total shock.  The FNA lab just called and said the samples were positive for Squamous Cell Carcinoma in the node.  So, now I'm guessing we don't know the primary...   Also, the sore on my toungue is more concerning now too.  If it is, and or somewhere else is the primary, I don't know what to do?!?!?  My scapula is killing me too, lot's of pain, (about a 3 or 4) intermittantly. I hope and pray it's not in my lungs, that would mean VERY LOW chance of long term survival as far as I can tell!  I've never used tobacco, but what is going on?  PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE give me any advice...  The Dr's up here are horrible, distant, uncareing and just plain stupid.  They all dismissed me as being nuts for months while I could have been agressively treating this!  I don't want to die!!!!! PLEASE HELP!!!!!!!

title: final news
content: looks like the primary is most likely in one of my tonsils, and they found a 2nd swollen lymph on the 1st ct.  That means T2N4 Stage 4!  Plus, I saw the chest X-ray. It had a whte dot on the right side, kinda star shaped with white feathery lines branching out to the edge.  Pretty sure that means it has already spead to my lungs.  Which would be a lot worse than Stage 4, but I don't even know what comes after that.  From what I can fiind, I have a less than 1% chance of 5 year survival.  I had chest pain last night which kept me up all night long, so I am terribly sleep deprived.  I feel exhausted and lost and I haven't even started any treatments yet.  IF there is any chance of any survival my quality of life will never been close to the same, assuming I beat all the odds by 99% .  We're talking Radical Neck Disectomy. Serious radiation and chemo, and I don't even KNOW what they might do (if there's anything they can do) about the possible invasion into my lung(s)...Can a person live with one lung?   I've read about Toma imaging / radiation therapy which pinpoints the radiation but I'm guessing it's more marketing gimmicks than true advances in tx.  Also, I've read about gene therapies, but again, I'm just grasping at straws.

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: CT/PET  | Update
content: I had a CT/PET scan and a chest Xray both showing no other metastisis besides the 2 lymph nodes on my right neck AND determining that the RIGHT tonsillar pillar is the most likely "Primary".  So, now I have seen 6 speacialists: 2 ENT Oncology Surgeons, 2 Medical Oncologists, 1  Oncological Surgeon, and 1 Radiation Oncologist.  EACH ONE has told me different things!  The surgeons say to cut out the tonsil and surrounding tissues (radical tonsilectomy) and a modified radical neck dissection.  The medical oncologists say Chemo/Radiation is the best first line.  The Radiation Oncologist say's radiation first only, then chemo & surgery as a 2nd line if needed.  I am hearing everything from 1% chance, 10%, 50-50 and 70% chance of 5 year survival.!  I don't know WHO or WHAT to believe!!  PLEASE HELP ME DECIDE!!!!!!!!!

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Michaelii,  FIrst of all...I am very proud of you for your determination to exclude malignancy when all your doctors said it was nothing.   You are a very strong woman and i am sure you can go through this with a little help from friends and great doctors and by choosing the appropriate management which you are having a hard time choosing one as i can see.  It is great that you have had a PET Scan to determine that there are no further metastasis going on. It is a very sensitive and very expensive investigation.  All what the doctors say make sense...BUT....let's try to see what suits you as well.  You should definately remove the tonsils...that's for sure...both of them not only one.... then Radiation and chemotherapy.  I don't think Radical neck dissection in your condition would be of benefit if not the same to radio and chemo therapy's outcome.  you can try chemo and radio without tonsillectiomy but it's always preferrable to remove the primary if you know what i mean.   So tell me how things go...we are here for you .....and I want to tell you something... I know what books write about chances for survival ,etc....but miracles always happen to whom have faith in God and believing in his mighty powers.   Best regards,

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: i have a plan...
content: I know a positive attitude is essential in every study I read and everyone I talk to so maybe the Dr's telling me 50 to 70% survival chance are using inflated odds to improve the odds?  Here's why I am concerned:  I've read that people under 40, in no other risk groups who get this (ie: "me"), usually have a much more agressive neoplasm. This is what I've heard from a couple of sources...So, maybe the Dr with the 70% odds he's using, for his outlook; has demographics of generally older patients who smoke, etc who don't have such an agressive version.  4 ENT's & 1 Oncological Surgeon have said 50-50 chance of 5 year survival.  There's tremendous consistency in that number...It's also a "safe" bet, meaning whatever happends, they are right..   But, maybe there's some code out there that say's "if the patient has less than 50% chance, tell them 50-50 just to keep them sane..", or maybe that's what they say when they don't really know.  That is the bottom line after all. They DON'T really know. No one does, and that's the problem with statistics.  I have this mental block about all the 50-50 projections, I feel like I would be measurably more resolved if they would have all said 55 or 60% chance...Crazy huh?  But, again, that's what following statistics is..."CRAZY". None of us is a statistic.  SO...I've decided.  I'm 36 DAMNIT! I'm a healthy male (other than the whole "cancer thing"  )  I'm not going to fall into the crowd on the failing side of the 50%.   I've got way too much life left in me and too much to live for.  Just do me a favor everyone, on those days in the future when I forget this, please give me a gentle reminder    Now for my plan:  1) Radical Tonsilectomy  & Modified Radical Neck Dissection  next week 5 hour surgery! (Please keep me in your prayers that day)   Top ENT Surgeon @ Stanford  2) 2 weeks of recovery at our resort my partner and I own on the North Coast. We'll work on getting computers setup, phones forwarded, systems in place, people trained, hired etc for our absense.  3) Right after our busy July 4th weekend, we'll leave for So Cal where we have a home and all our familes and lots of friends live, to start Radiation/Chemo, maybe using one of two new drugs in combination, Motexafin Gadolinium &/or Proxinium, and possibly Erbitux. This will likely be a six week cycle. This will be supervised by the Stanford team and administered by a great local oncologist (the 70% guy!!). Friends and family will help my parter and I run our resort remotely (as much as possible), and help me with trips to radiation and chemo, and meals, chores, etc. Every weekend or two, my parter (me too when I'm feeling up to it), will run up there and check things out in person (9 hour drive each way!  ) Returning to be back in time for the next radiation treatment. Family will stay at the place occassionally to check on the employees, releave people, etc.  The radiation I plan to use is the new TomoTherapy. I've read a ton about it. It's not available up North, and my charts are being reviewed by the chief of radiology at one of the installations now. He said it is brand new and they plan to use it on a lot of H&N cancers.  Okay, so that's the plan. There's a chance they won't get it all on surgery. There's a chance they won't get it all with radiation/chemo, and there's an ugly chance it will return with a vengence! But, I'll be ready..!!  I have several other things up my sleeve, like Gendicine, Avenox and more ideas.  Plus, I'm radically changing my diet to be "cancer resistent".  I've gone 8 days now with ZERO coffee or caffeine! (Unbelieveable I was a total espresso junkie 2 weeks ago)  I am going to be more active, exercise and be overall healthy.  Plus, everyday I am going to visualize my body eating up all the cancer cells (my Dr (from Stanford!!) actually suggested this!!!!)    That's the plan...! Help me stick with it!  I feel so connected to all of you. Thank you for all the inspiration, prayers and good wishes.  Hopefully, my surgery will go smooth, and they will find good results in the biopsies (ie: Little tissue involvement, no spreading, clean small margins, and no other nodes.)  Sorry for the LONG post   PS: I am going to move my discussion to the HEAD AND NECK category, with a copy of the above since we know now that it didn't turn out to be Lymphoma.

title: 25 year old female with swollen lymph nodes in neck
content: I'm a 25 year old female with swollen lymph nodes in neck. I noticed them about 6 months ago but just figured they were normal. I recently went to my GP and she was unconcerned. I had severe allergies in my ear canals and on my eyelids and she figured the ears were what was causing my lymph nodes to swell. They seem really big to me but she said that they were not that large. I have some  intermittent teeth pain but the dentist said that there was nothing wrong with my teeth. It only occurs very rarely. I have no other symptoms except for allergies. I occasionally smoke and drink and didn't konw if this caused that. I have a complete blood test done and everything is totally normal. My doctor put me on antibiotics and nothing has changed. my ears are a little better but still very itchy and red. I just moved so I am not in the same place as my doctor and was wondering what i should do. I am scared to go back to the doctor because i don't want bad news. I can't really tell but they do not appear to be growing at all and I touch them a lot which  I know can make them bigger. what do you think?

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: Lymph nodes often stay enlarged after an infection is gone, chronically.  You probably had an infection some time back that caused them to swell.  I am sure your doctor tested you for serious problems.  About your ears itching, it could possibly be excema.  Try some cortsone cream (you can get it over the counter) and use that a couple times a day.  It will probably get rid of the problem, although it can come back. Antibiotics won't help skin allergies; only the ear infection itself.  The teeth pain if the upper teeth, could possibly be a maxillary sinus involvement.  It feels like the teeth hurt, but it's the sinus below the cheek.  Have you had anymore of that pain since you finished your antibiotics?

When should I go back to the doctor if my nodes havent gotten smaller? Also I had a blood test and a thyroid test and everything was normal.  Thanks

author: ms_barnacle  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Jun 01, 2005 11:53 pm Location: Portland, OR
title: frustrated with my doctor
content: I'm 26. I've had generalized lymph node swelling in my head and neck for a year and a half.  I had a bad case of mono when I was 18, and the cervical lymph nodes along the back/side of my neck had been palpable ever since.  A year and a half ago these nodes, in addition to the nodes behind both ears and on the back of my head, swelled noticably and painfully.  I went to the doctor freaked out that I had lymphoma.  The doctor noticed some sores on my scalp, cultured them, found bacterial infection, put me on antibiotics and sleeping pills, and sent me home.  The node swelling went down, but not completely. Two months later the nodes came back fully swollen.  I went to a new doctor who put me back on antibiotics and also put me on meds for anxiety.  That was about a year ago.  Since then, my lymph nodes on the back/sides of my neck have always been palpable and swell noticeably when I have a cold/flu.    This spring the nodes swelled up huge again.  Yet another doctor checked my scalp, cultured a sore, and found an infection.  She put me on antibiotics.  To see if the lymph node swelling my have another underlying cause, she also did a CBC, some kind of liver-related blood test (?), a TB test, a chest x-ray, and checked for Epstin Barr.  All these tests came back normal.  After two weeks on antibiotics, the scalp infection was gone.  Two months later, my lymph nodes are still swollen.  I'm worried about lymphoma, so she did a fine-needle biopsy on one of my swollen neck nodes.  The lab results came back normal.  I know fine-needle biopsies aren't 100% accurate in diagnosiing lymphoma.  Yet my doc refuses to fully remove a node, saying the fine-needle biopsy is fine, that none of my other symptoms point to malignancy so she doesn't think my anxieties justify a more invasive procedure, but she can't explain the 18 months of swollen nodes.    I feel like if I have lymphoma, it's getting late in the game to be playing dare with my doctor.  should I switch doctors, or demand a full biopsy of a node?  I'm scared to death and frustrated that I've spent so much time and money at the doc office with no answers.
posted_time: Post  by ms_barnacle » Thu Jun 02, 2005 12:07 am

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear ms_barnacle,  Well, first of all...Thank you for your lymph nodes consiced  medical history  . So you are not worried about your neck nodes because they've been there ever since your mono infection. But you are worried from your flactuant nodes on the back of your head and behind your ears.  Your doctor has done  a very good approach to a case of lymphoma, when he did a Chest X-ray,blood tests,TB and EBV test,....and these nodes (back of head and behind the ears) are not common to be malignant. That is why your doctor is excluding malignancy....he's just missed an abdominal ultrasound  ,for nodes in your abdomen....and he should check nodes underneath your armpit (axillary lymph nodes).....and that would complete his investigations to exclude a case of lymphoma.  You have noticed that each time he gives you an antibiotic according to culture they go away....malignant nodes wouldn't behave like that.  If the Fine needle biopsy(FNAB) was inconvenient to him...he would have ordered an excisional biopsy (removal of the largest lymph node) ...but it seems that he's content with the FNAB.  I also want to inform you that infections in the scalp sometimes become chronic... you should look for  the cause of that infection and  consider a better hygiene and management to your scalp...frequent washing of your hair with therapeutic shampoos may be as directed by a dermatologist.  Don't worry, I cannot be 100% sure that it's not malignant...but i highly doubt after your history and the investigations that you've had.  You just make sure that you don't have other lymph nodes anywhere else...axilla,groin,etc...and ask for an abdominal ultrasonography...those would be the last investigations you can make to exclude lymphoma.   I am sure if he had felt that your lymph nodes consistency was wired...he would have investigated more.  Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi » Thu Jun 02, 2005 4:33 am

author: ms_barnacle  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Jun 01, 2005 11:53 pm Location: Portland, OR
title: thanks--a few more questions...
content: Thank you so much for your reply.    Are fine needle biopsies relatively accurate? I also wonder weather it would matter which node she biopsied. The one thing I didn't explain clearly: the lymph node swelling never goes away completely.  All of those nodes, even the "new" ones, will shrink and get big again, etc. but they're always palpable, they never go away, now for a year and a half.  And the scalp infection does go away... then comes back within a few months. I've also wondered if the scalp infection could signal something else wrong... I shower twice a day because I go to the gym after work, I use dandruff shampoo, but I still get these infections.  I do have allergies, and I've wondered if that could have anythin to do with it.    And is it normal for my lymph nodes on the back of my neck to be palpable ever since having mono?  It's never given me much anxiety until now, but now I can't seem to find anyone who has experienced the same chronic enlargement.      Lastly, may I ask approximately how much an abdominal ultrasound would cost?  I only have catastrophic health insurance so I pay for everything out of pocket.  That's a lot of questions.  Sorry!

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hello, always a pleasure:-)  Well, FNAC are relatively accurate....but when it's inconvenient and we feel query about it....we just excise the node.  I just have to say that it's very common for nodes after severe infections...like mono,TB or even minor but very prolonged infections ....to stay big...forming something called granuloma which means...infection trapped inside the node that has healed by fibrosis and reactive tissues...so the nodes never go back to their normal size!   Although you have plenty of nodes... but the way they behave and react to antibiotics just makes me doubt that it could be lymphoma.  What type of infection do you have in your scalp...what does the culture say?  Scalp infection doesn't signal something that i am aware of...? You told me your CBC was fine? what was the WBCs count (white blood cells)!?,  because if your scalp infection was due to something systemic(in your body) and not local(confined to your scalp)... the white blood counts would have been elevated!  I don't know how much does an abdominal ultrasound costs in your country...you can  ask the hospital or the center by phone,sorry.  Well, you can do the ultrasound whenever you can...but your doctor is doing a good job...I'd just ask you to go to a good dermatologist and ask for a proper treatment to your scalp condition,please.  Best regards,

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi tadeems, Lymph nodes commonly enlarge as a result of an infection because they are the bodies filter system for bacteria. They may not return to their preinfectious state. If you have not experienced a recent illness or the lump (which sounds like it may be a node) continues to enlarge I would suggest an evaluation to identify the causative factor. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: MAIDIE  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Thu May 19, 2005 12:04 pm Location: U.K.
title: Advice needed please.....
content: Hello, I am female and am 37 years old.  I am having a few problems at the moment.  Firstly I found a lump in my neck last August 2004. The doctor said it was an enlarged lymph node.  Two weeks before I noticed the lump I had had my hair permed and also had treated my hair with a headlice treatment twice as I caught headlice from my son.  The lump decreased over a few months and now it has shrunk but is not completely flat- It is on the right side of the back of my neck, about  2 inches away from my earlobe and one inch down from the base of my skull.  If I turn my neck and head to the left, and keep my finger placed on the lump I can no longer feel the lump as well as if my head is facing towards the front direction looking ahead. It feels as if the lump is part of a muscle.  Then I had a blood test.  The blood test results in November 2004 showed a raised ESR level in the 30's, my last blood test in April 2005 this year showed that the ESR level is now 44. I am having another blood test in 3 months time. I am really worried about the ESR levels.  This is my medical history- I suffer from kidney stones and gum disease which the doctor said could cause raised ESR. I am recieving lithortripsy for the Kidney stones. I am Vitamin D deficient but taking a supplement prescribed by the doctor.  I have lipomas on my left side on my ribs also. I went to the doctors and he said it was lipoma-as I have Obsessive Compulsive disorder I find I am constantly getting these lumps checked. I think I found another one-a bigger one above the original one, but I am afraid that I have cancer spreading rather thatn lipomas. How can they tell the difference between lipomas and cancer by feeling a lump?  Please could you advise me.   Thank you. Maidie.

author: Dr. S. Adhikari  Medical Doctor Posts: 68 Joined: Sat May 14, 2005 1:49 pm Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi Maidie, Come out of this OCD!! Your enlarged lymph node on the back of your neck is due to some minor scalp infection: do you suffer from dandruff? Or else you might be having a sebaceous cyst which is totally a harmless condition. Lipomas and cancer can be easily differentiated on clinical examination. We do that thing so often that we don't need to go in for a FNAC also! If you are really in doubt go in for a FNAC which will provide you with the diagnosis. Finally, forget about cancer as lipomas are totally harmless tumors.

content: Hello, Thanks for your reply. I wish I could come out of the OCD-it drives me crazy every day of my life.  No I haven't got dandruff. What is FNAC ?  Also what do you think about the raised ESR levels? They are at 44 now.  Thanks. Maidie.

author: Dr. S. Adhikari  Medical Doctor Posts: 68 Joined: Sat May 14, 2005 1:49 pm Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  FNAC stands for Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology in which a fine needle is inserted in the lump and a little bit of material is aspirated and examined under the microscope; it is fairly accurate in a large number of cases. Of course, the confirmation is by biopsy. Your ESR is a bit elevated and your doctor is right: it might be due to those infections. For OCD, go in for psychotherapy, it's really wonderful and will help u relax a lot! Best wishes.....
posted_time: Post  by Dr. S. Adhikari » Thu May 19, 2005 2:20 pm

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: Hi, maidie - Have you been formally diagnosed as OCD?  The main treatment for that is Prozac (or any SSRI antidepressant), but Prozac is the drug of choice - it does an incredible job!  Mental diseases and disorders aren't something you can just snap out of without professional help and usually some medication.  OCD can disrupt and eventually destroy your life.   I highly recommend that you learn all you can about it and get help.

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: Mass in my neck...has me freaked out!
content: DAY ONE: | 04.12.05 I have a nodule on the left side of my throat, and it is about 3cm x 3cm. It is not tender or painful. Just noticed it a day or two ago.I don't feel like it is a lymph node (no pain etc)it doesn't move much when pressed, and it feels rather hard to the touch.Also, this may be completely unrelated, but I have had itchy patches (like eczema) on my eyelids.   DAY TWO: My Dr thinks it must a swollen lymph gland, but I am afraid it's cancer...I return in a week to see it's progress...   DAY THREE: I am scheduled to revisit my Dr. tomorrow. I've noticed that my voice is changing, more of a strained, deep voice...tired sounding...Also my vision seems worse..?Also, I am having involuntary facial twitches, not horrible, but they seem to be getting progressively worse, first my upper lip, then cheek and now tonight forehead...I've noticed I am tired a lot, and have less appetite.I also have a sore in my nose that's new. Could just be a pimple or something..? Am I driving myself nuts, or what?! The mass in my neck is painless and hasn't’t grown in the week or so since I've first noticed it. Its about 3 x 3 cm   DAY FOUR: Saw my Dr, who basically had no good advice. The good news is that the reported size is now 2.5 cm x 2.5 cm. At least I guess that's good news, the Dr didn't seem to care one way or the other. Nose is fine and I think the twitches have stopped for now. Did feel pain in chest area, left side, near rib cage, under breast, along the side, had the same pain a few weeks ago, was sure it was an imminent heart attack   DAY FIVE: Had a TOTAL meltdown last night at 3:30 AM. Started balling uncontrollably. Feel alone and scared. Totally freaked out. Went to ER, Doc there waived me right in, and after 2 seconds said I was being nuts for no reason, said he'd seen tons of lymphoma and that this wasn't cancer, he personally "guaranteed" me that it would go away in a while, and said to quit thinking about it.He checked for other lymphs and said not to worry. Went home and felt like I had a new lease on life.   DAY SIX: Still worried, and now my voice seems to still be changing and I feel overall "off" like I'm sick, or almost sick with the flu, etc...   DAY SEVEN: Been two weeks since I first noticed the lump. Family swears it seems smaller still, but I feel fatigued. I've been breaking out in tears frequently. Also, the lump seems more spread out maybe. I also have hot flashes and feel like maybe there are swollen lymphs in my arm pits, chin area and groin, and I think I have a fever occasionally. Have a slight discomfort on my left rear flank, below my ribcage, kind of like a muscle pain, might be from recent work I've been doing physical. Some tingling in my extremities and occasional headaches.   DAY EIGHT: Have appt next week for follow-up with the GP Doc. Have slight (weird feeling) sore throat, and maybe a slight ear ache (in same side as lump, right side). Then, I also have pain on the side (almost like when you walk too fast too much), on my right side.Also, noticed white stuff on my lips that look to me like thrush.   DAY ELEVEN: I saw the Doc again today and he agreed that it is either unchanged, or ::slightly:: smaller, maybe a little more spread out and not so 'pointed'....   His bedside manner is not too great...He records the exam into a tape recorder which I think amplifies any anxiety.   He referred me to another Doc that specializes in blood diseases, and said it is OK to wait about 10 days (until my insurance kicks in).   Said 10 days or so won't make any difference even if it's an aggressive malignancy.   I told him I had swollen glands a couple of days ago, in my arm pits and my groin. He used a bunch of fancy terms as if to mock me, and that was it.   I asked him if he thought this was going to kill me, and he actually said..."well who knows you could get hit by a bus too"...Talk about not being any comfort.   Wouldn't give me any probabilities, expectations, etc. I couldn't get any likeliness of this being cancer, etc etc.   Today I have a slight sore throat, and even a very slight ear ache in the ear on the same side as the mass.   I also have a slight nasal drip, and non-productive cough only about 2 or 3 times a day, or so.   And my voice still seems to be changing a little.   DAY THIRTEEN: For the last 36 hours or so, my lower back has been in extreme pain...   It seems to change from the left to the right occasionally.   Right now there is a tender knot and it seems to be raised a bit on the surface. When I twist a certain way or sit for a long period it bothers me.   It is below the rib cage and seems to be radiating...   Could this be related to the swollen lymph node and does this indicate cancer?   DAY FOURTEEN: Back pain seems better today, not gone, but better.   Ok, so last night I felt like my face was slipping off my skull.   It was tingly and numb!   What in the @#&@*$!% is going on with me??!?!?   I finally had to pop an Ambien just to get to sleep.   Woke up this morning and my face is still on, thank God    But, the node on my neck is still there too!   It's been almost a month since I noticed it. I think it changes a bit in size, but know I can't be sure I'm not just fooling myself.   Tiny, tiny irritation in my wisdom tooth closest to the node, like an infection, which seems to be going away quickly...was hoping this was somehow related. But seems to be unrelated since it only lasted 36 hours and never got more than just barely noticeable.   Slight sore throat overnight, no night sweats or fevers.   Going to Dr next week...can't wait, but am scared to death!   DAY SIXTEEN:  Sorry to say, this marks about 3 weeks since I first noticed the swollen mass in my neck and this morning I noticed there is a small smaller (and tender) swollen node that is sort of anchovy shaped below the large hard mass.   I know this can't be good.   No fever, night sweats or fatigue. Feel ok, except for the stress of worry. (Plus my best friend is near death in a hospital about 500 miles away and non-responsive, on breathing tube, etc).   My neck feels “tight” like I slept on it wrong (could have actually). Muscles feel tight and a bit sore, nothing major. Feel like my muscles are pulled along my shoulders surrounding my neck.   No tooth pain or sore throat at all. No nasal or sinus problems today. No noticeable facial ‘twitches’ or any other symptoms except for the itchy eyelids.   Slight itching on my back too, but have used the hot tub a few times this week so could be from the chlorine / bromamine in the water maybe? Speaking of which, we are in the forest and there are TONS of wild birds all around. Every day when I get into the outdoor hot tub there is always some bird droppings on the cover which drops into the water a bit. Is there something (like toxoplasmosis, or cat scratch etc) that could be in the water and contributing to this??? (Just wishful thinking I guess)   Actually feel pretty good overall, except for the depression about my best friend and the stress over possibly having cancer.  My voice seems raspy and deeper, and my nose has been stuffed up with some pain in my sinus cavities today.  The Dr I saw said my thyroid seemed fine. I did have a complete blood work up about 6 months ago. My Thyroid panel was all normal.   I guess a lot can happen in 6 months. In-fact, my CBC & Differential, Metabolic function and cholesterol were all basically fine (within normal range) back in September.   I also have never smoked or chewed tobacco. I'm am overweight but otherwise healthy, and only 35 years old.   A quick background issue: About 6 or 7 months ago I noticed a 'weird' "sensation", best described as a rapid heartbeat.   The best way to explain this is as follows. It ONLY happen(s) (ed) when I put my head down to rest.   I could feel my heart beat in my skull. I felt sort of flush and almost like a panic attack but not really (I've never had one to my knowledge anyway).   Basically, I could feel my pulse in my head and feel a tiny bit dizzy. It's VERY hard to explain. Anyway, it was VERY prevalent for a few weeks, and seemed to get worse every night, so much so that I went to a Dr and tried to explain my symptoms.   It was so severe that it would actually arrest my falling asleep since it only occurred JUST BEFORE I would specifically drift asleep.   So my Dr prescribed Valium and Atenolol (Tenorman). I never took the Tenorman figuring I didn't want to open that whole pandora's box. The valium helped when I used it occasionally. He did an EKG on me at the time and it was all normal.   The reason I mention this is because the symptoms seemed to subside for a few months, but lately, coinciding with the neck mass these symptoms have returned.   The neck mass is VERY PULSATILE and the Dr I visited last week said it is right on a corotiid artery.

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Michaelii,    Well, let me answer your questions one by one...   * Well, you should be concerned ofcourse from your neck mass...It's on the carotid artery lymph node chain....hard and BIG!....you have voice changes...and this can be related to the larynx (voice box),rather than the thyroid...when the thyroid is normal on examination, blood tests and you don't have its symptoms.   * at first i thought it was infectious mononucleosis (mono),but then its symptoms should be more severe, more lymph nodes involvements,sore throat and fever with a special character....but u said you felt lymph nodes under your armpit,chin and groin with hot flushes and occasional fever....u should check your blood for mono as well.   * This weird sensation of rapid heart beat and that you could feel it in your skull,etc, this is simply called "Palpitations" which means awareness of heart beats...it's from anxiety and stress, also if you drink alot of coffee and tea ... but anxiety can cause it very easily and it's very common to normal people, so don't worry about that.   * The answer to all your questions would be in a lymph node biopsy. just ask for needle biopsy of it, where they give you local anaesthesia, and prick you with a needle, take a core of tissue and examine it under the microscope to know its nature...if it's cancer or not and from where did it come.   * Second thing to do is a laryngoscope.... to check on your larynx and vocal cords... that can explain the change in voice which is something also that you shouldn't let go easily ,especially with the presence of that big hard lymph node in your neck... and the appearance of a new one as well,ok?   I think those were the most alarming symptoms that you mentioned , if i skipped something that's important to you, don't hesitate to remind me ,ok?   and by the way, that out door hot tub with birds in the forest,etc!! well, i dunno what kind of wild birds,squerrils or any other animals swim in your tub before you get in,but as long as you don't drink it, then it's fine i guess?! ask your doctors about that as well,ok?   * So to sum it up...here is what you should ask for:-  1-Lymph node node biopsy.  2-Laryngoscope...preferrably direct laryngoscope , NOT indirect,ok?! where they can see your larynx properly, you'll be sedated,or even asleep,don't worry.  3- screen for Infectious mononucleosis in your blood and do a complete blood count as well.   Best regards,   Keep me updated,   Thanks for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope this infromation has helped you.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi » Fri Apr 29, 2005 3:11 am
