author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Michaelli,  well, i cannot tell you or predict how it's going to be ...because if it is malignant (God forbids) ,then the prognosis(outlook) will depend on its stage,cell differentiation under the microscope and how aggressive is its behaviour, but not all malignant tumors means the end..according to the stage and other criterias varies the response of each one of them to certain chemotherapy /radiotherapy/surgery or a combination of them.  don't jump into conclusions please,that is very distressing for you.  Just Have faith and take each step, one at a time,ok? we are all here for you. May be it's a simple inflammation and we're making a fuss out of nothing...so relax....but at the same time...don't sit down and do nothing ....as i told ya...with a hard,big lymph node in the neck,around the carotid artery and changes in voice...we have to make sure it's nothing serious.... then celebrate when it turns out to be fine,ok?Best regards:-)

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Wow....slow down...!!   The new very small lymph node under your armpit shouldn't worry you, especially when it's painful...because that indicates inflammation.   I don't think you'll be dying soon  .....I just can't believe your reply...take it easy ...there is no rush.  your symptoms of sorethroat,ear ache,cough ,nasal and sinus stuff,runny nose... might be a simple flu... if you are worried...seek an ENT(ear,nose and throat) doctor...he might give you an anti-histaminic/decongestant to relieve those symptoms.  back pain...most probably because of the serious activity you've been having towards your sick friend. ...God bless you.  Listen,Michaelii..please take it easy....I think most of the symptoms  you're having are pshycological.....and because you are having a stressful time these days, you are just imagining the smallest things as catastrophe! have faith...wait for your doctor's appointment....it won't hurt waiting for a week or two...and it's always good news when the lymoh nodes get smaller....  take good care, Best regards,

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: new leg pain...?
content: Just  a quick update, and to thank you again for being so kind and supportive.  Okay, so I haven't had ANY other swollen lymph nodes in days.  ONLY the one semingly HUGE one in my neck, maybe 2cm x 1.5cm..?  But I think it is VERY VERY VERY SLOWLY getting smaller and not as pronounced. It still doesn't seem to have much to any pain, is sort of fixed and kinda hard.  I check it several times a day, but am trying to do it less. It usually seems smaller in the mornings when I first wake up.  So, my hip pain is 85% gone, but still there occassionally. I treat it with asparin (2 once or twice a day). It might be related somehow to my plantars facioitis. I changed shoes recently (about 3 days ago) and the old shoes were worn out pretty bad. The new shoes (boots actually) seem to really help the pantars faciietis. It is 70% better.  Yesterday, I spent several hours sitting in the car on a trip, and now today my lower leg is kiilling me...My shin area, near the bone, doesn't feel especially muscular, but the asparin helps it a little too...  Also, I noitced a sore inside my mouth where it looks like I bit my inside of my cheek, infact it looks like my teeth are rubbing against the inside and today it is getting better.  As far as ALL the other things I mentioned, red eyes (stye, pink eye, etc), ezcema, everything is 100% better, except that I wake up with a slight to mild sore throat and occassionally a slight ear ache. Other wise I feel fine. Also my friend who the Drs said was dying is slowly improving.  I still have my Dr's apointment next week, but I am still scared it is something serious like cancer!  I haven't had any fevers, night sweats, etc.  Yesterday, my friend and I were cleaning my room and noticed TONS of dark black MOLD under my pillows and against the headboar of my bed.  We cleaned the area with Lysol a lot, and bleach too.  I don't know if we got it all.  Could this realted you think???  Finally, I wanted to tell you that I live in an area with a LOT of ticks, and I may have been bitten by one in the past.  Please let me know any thoughts you might have!

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: latest news...or not...
content: Hello.  I'm back again. After being silent for several days, I wanted to post an update here.  Overall, I’d say that the node (mass) in my neck is definitely smaller. If I had to guess, and I could just be fooling myself here, I’d say it’s maybe one half the size that it was when first noticed about 6 weeks ago. Not as “deep/tall” and not as big. But, since I rub it 20 times a day, who knows..?  I finally got to see my new Dr at the end of last week.  He said he feels NO OTHER swollen lymphs.  Said he thinks it is one of 4 possible things:  1) Lymphoma (Hodgkin’s or Non-Hodgkin’s) 2) Some HIV/AIDS related reaction (?) 3) Melanoma of some kind (??) 4) Infection of some kind (i.e.: abscessed tooth, etc)  So, I said, basically, your saying it's most likely either "cancer, AIDS, or both"...and he said "..well. Yes, I guess so"...  Said possibly melanoma since my Mom had it about 10 years ago. (it was a mole on her back and was 100% removed with ZERO reoccurrence, no radiation, chemo or anything), and since I’m from Southern California and fair skinned (I HATE the sun and spend as little time in it as possible).  Not exactly comforting or what I wanted to hear, but I guess that's why Dr's are so respected in our culture.  So, he ordered blood work, (CBC, (w/Man. Diff), Syphilis, HIV and a couple of other's I don't recall. Naturally, I am TOTALLY FREAKING OUT!! My follow-up appt with him was set for 10 days!!!! (I can't believe a Dr (knowing how anxious I am), would ask me to schedule the return visit in 10 days!!!!!!) Anyway, I've got 8 days left and each one is feeling like an eternity!  AND, to top it all off, I can't imagine what the blood work is really going to tell us. Assuming I'm HIV+ then what??? That doesn't tell us what the swollen node is, just makes a couple (BAD!) things more likely! And then what, another week to get a biopsy scheduled, and then what, another few days for the pathology report!!!. Or, (god willing!!) I'm HIV -. Then what?? Still do a biopsy? It could still be (maybe even more likely is) cancer!  AND, I don't think he even had a T-cell count done, so I'll have to go through that HELL later, If (hopefully NOT!) I test positive. I'll be scared to death later waiting the few days (after the new blood draw again!) to find out what stage of HIV infection I am in.  In the meantime, I'm praying it's #4! I do have a VERY SLIGHT irritation on my lower right wisdom tooth (in fact I've had trouble with all of my wisdom teeth over the years and have had 3 of them removed as impacted wisdom teeth), don't know if this one (bottom right) was one that was removed yet or not, but I think so, and the pain is very slight, but reminiscent of the pain I used to get from the impacted wisdom teeth. In any case, I'll see a dentist this week, while I wait for the lab results.   The stress alone is killing me!!  The good news (I guess) is, despite all this tremendous SCARY STRESS I feel 100% fine.  Maybe everyone (even end stage AIDS, or Stage IV Lymphoma patients) say that, but I really do physically feel fine.  No fevers, no night sweats, no itching, no fatigue, no thrush, no KS, no voice changes, no vision changes, no stomach problems, no headaches, nothing...(except a minor clearing case of planter’s-facietis (sp?), which is getting better every day).  I'm eating healthy foods only. Drinking LOTS of clean water, and walking now everyday.  I still DON’T WANT TO DIE! But, for some reason, I feel like I’m not going to from this...Maybe this is some sort of denial, or self-preservation mechanism..?  I have no other swollen nodes, no heat flashes, etc.   ONLY, a VERY slight sore throat on waking and tiny tiny ear ache, (feels like a traveling tiny pain that radiates from the behind my ear lobe (on the same side as the swollen node), and travels down toward my throat, kind of in my jaw too, pressing around in there makes a "good pain" if that makes sense, kind of makes it feel better. It's almost like a taste-bud feels when you suck on a lemon, etc. In fact, I'd swear there's something in there to do with a taste-bud. (These can be malignant too right?)  Finally (I'll bet you are saying Jeesh!!! thank God he is wrapping up!), I have a question:  I can't find any online information to corroborate this, but is it possible that a first time dose of TADALAFIL could have caused this lymph node/mass in my neck??  It seems to correspond with a 20mg dose I took for the first time of this drug (and then once again about a week ago). I found some data indicating that doses in mice equivalent to human dose of 40mg have caused lymph node necrosis.  Here's the actual text: "Animal studies showed vascular inflammation in tadalafil-treated mice, rats, and dogs. In mice and rats, lymphoid necrosis and hemorrhage were seen in the spleen, thymus, and mesenteric lymph nodes at unbound tadalafil exposure of 2-to 33-fold above the human exposure (AUCs) at the MRHD of 20 mg."  Next time, I'll only have one 'double-espresso' before writing my post   Ok, that's it for now, as usual, EVERYONE'S comments, feedback, support and questions are deeply appreciated!!!

content: Hi.  Bout 5 weeks ago I noticed a bump under my arm that I assumed was a swollen lymph node.  It was not very big.  about the size of a pea if probably even smaller.  It went away after about 2 or 3 days.  Just the other day, I noticed another swelling under the same arm.  It was a little bit smaller than the first swelling 5 weeks earlier. Also, the lymph node swellings I have had were not very big did not really hurt, and went away after a few days..  I have always been under the impression that cancerous lymph node swellings would last for a much longer time than just a few days and are much larger than what I have noticed. posted_time: Post  by pargolfer4 » Tue May 10, 2005 2:28 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi pargolfer4, A recent infection would cause lymph nodes to enlarge/swell. It is quite a normal occurence because lymph nodes are the bodies filtering system for bacteria. After a lymph node enlarges it may not return to it's preinfectious state but does generally reduce in size. When lymph nodes continue to enlarge even despite treatment for example, with a cycle of antibiotics, this would raise concern. In my opinion what you have experienced, is the normal functionality of the body to fight off bacteria. I hope this is helpful. Sincerely, Rntdj
posted_time: Post  by Theresa Jones, RN » Tue May 10, 2005 5:37 am

title: High Lymph count
content: Hello, My job offered a blood screening that I accepted and just got the results back on. Everything is within the normal range except for my lymph reading was elevated (44.2%).  What does this mean? I am worried please respond.  Thank you,   Joe
posted_time: Post  by r8rmojoe » Mon May 02, 2005 1:44 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi r8rmojoe, I wouldn't worry about it. Lymphocytes fluctuate out of range to combat foreign organisms in the blood such as a viral infection. In the absence of lymph node enlargement or an increase in total leucocyte counts there is probably not much happening. A follow up blood count after a month will help lesson your worries. Please refer to your physician with your results.

He put me on Amoxicillin ran some blood work which he said was all good he also checked me for mono which thats not back yet.  He made me an appointment for an Xray but my concern is will it show what kind of mass it is?  He said because my white count was good I am worrying about nothing. title: Chemo for NHL
content: I am a physician and my question is: When is the most appropriate time to discontinue treatment for Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma? Thank you for your assistance as I do not have access to an Oncologist where I work.
posted_time: Post  by DrYRK » Sun Apr 24, 2005 9:28 pm

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear DrYRK,  Chemotherapy for NHL, can be discontinued if the patient got complete remission after 6 cycles of his planned regimen and 2 more cycles after remission. And  remission here means, total regression of his pathological lymph nodes using comparable recent and previous CT scans, clinical examination and serial LDH.  but he should always be kept under follow up to watch out for relapses.  Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi » Mon Apr 25, 2005 3:22 pm

posted_time: Post  by jmannina » Mon Apr 11, 2005 12:09 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: jmannina, The long duration of your symptoms, the size of the lymph nodes and the pain are all more against the diagnosis of cancer than for it. Where exactly is it located in the neck? The general procedure is to avoid a neck biopsy as much as possible even when the diagnosis of cancer is a possibility as this distorts the anatomical planes in the neck and may affect prognosis of an occult head and neck cancer should it turn out to be so. I would recommend follow up preferably with an oncologist.

author: Rosemary  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Mar 27, 2005 4:21 pm Location: England
title: Can a tumor shrink without treatment?
content: Hello,  I was diagnosed with non-hodgkins follicular stage 4 lymphoma this year. I started with a tumour and very large nodes in my right neck and symptoms of night sweats, hot flushes, temperature etc. I have had a needle biopsy, a nodal biopsy under general anaesthetic, a bone marrow biopsy, ultra sound and ct scan as well as blood tests. I was found to have it in my bone marrow and spleen as well as neck. I I am due to start chemotherapy this Wednesday, but for some unknown reason the tumour in my neck, plus the enlarged nodes have shrunk almost to nothing of thier own accord!!! and the discomfort and sharp stabbing pains in the spleen area have stopped, also I have felt better than I have in the past year and have renewed energy. I am totally perplexed and need to speak to my team this week about this as I feel so good. Does anyone know of this? And if so what does it mean. Does this happen often, I need to know if it is a common occurance, or if it is just a fluke and it is still growing somewhere else.
posted_time: Post  by Rosemary » Sun Mar 27, 2005 4:33 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello Rosemary, No, it is not normal for low grade lymphoma to decrease on its own. This can happen if you are taking steroid medication though. An important point should be made here: If you are not taking steroids then the pathology needs to be reviewed. The bone marrow and the pathology needs to be stained to test for monoclonality. Some cases of reactive, inflammatory or immune lymph gland enlargement are very difficult to differentiate from lymphoma. Another confirmatory test would be Bcl-2 staining. I would have recommended an excisional biopsy (where the whole gland is removed) as opposed to a needle biopsy. Please let me know how it all turns out. Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Mon Apr 18, 2005 1:19 am

title: Swollen axillary node for 6 months
content: Hello, I am a 19 year old female.  Back in october I was having trouble sleeping on my right side because my underarm kept hurting when I would lay on it.  I started to feel in the armpit area and I noticed that I had two lumps in my armpit.  My underarm was really puffy and it was really sore around the lumps.  I went to see my doctor a couple days later and he put me on an antiobiotic and told me that they were just swollen lymph nodes. One was  1 cm and the other was really small.   I took the antiobiotic and it made the puffiness go away and the pain, but the lymph nodes were still there.  I went back to the doctor and they sent me to have an ultrasound done. I went and had the ultrasound done and the radiologist told me that they were just swollen lymph nodes and he wanted me to come back in 3 months and have another ultrasound done to see if they changed in size.  So after 3 months I went and had another ultrasound done, and they told me that they might have gotten slightly smaller and that they didn't get any bigger so He said I didn't need to come back. It has been over 6 months and they are still there. They haven't got any bigger. Should I look into it any further, or should I just let it go?
posted_time: Post  by sunflower » Thu Apr 07, 2005 2:08 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi sunflower, Lymph nodes may commonly enlarge as a result of an infection becuse they are the bodies filtering system for bacteria. Keep in mind that even after an infection resolves lymph nodes may not return to their pre-infectious state. I would be more concerned if the lymph nodes became larger in size despite antibiotic treatment but since they have decreased in size over this period of time I would be less concerned and consider this to be a relatively normal outcome. However, at the time that your lymph nodes were evaluated did you also have a physical breast exam as well as diagnostic studies of the breast? If you did not, I would suggest that you contact your health care provider for an opinion about an evaluation to include a breast exam just to exclude any other possibilities unrelated to an infection. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Heba Ismail  Medical Doctor Posts: 328 Joined: Tue Sep 21, 2004 4:08 am
title: [no title]
content: Dearest jakeeler, As Theresa explained that lymph nodes are the bodies filtering system, that become swollen in response to any infection. The fact that your child has swollen lymph nodes doesn't mean that she has an illness. Rather, it's a sign that her immune system is at work. With acutely swollen glands, it is more important to diagnose and treat the infection causing the glands to swell, but the glands themselves need no treatment. Chronically enlarged lymph nodes, as in your daughter's case, are considered 'non-specific' and usually no focus of infection could be found. Again as Theresa explained, they sometimes just don't return to their pre-infectious state. If the lymph node becomes red and painful, larger than 2 inches or not mobile, then you should worry and should immediately seek medical advice.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Lymph nodes
content: Thanks for posting your question here at The Lounge.  First, let me state that it is somehwat difficult to talk about specifics of your situation without the benefit of seeing and feeling what is going on behind your ear.  Nevertheless, it would be a good idea to see a doctor for evaluation.  Sometimes if there may be an infection or fluid-filled cyst, then either a course of antibiotics is tried or a needle aspiration is done to remove any fluid.  If the swollen areas are to be removed, then It would be a reasonable idea to consider obtaining CAT scan of the affected area first to see if anything is going on deeper in the area.  A general surgeon or an ENT specialist can be involved to remove the affected areas.  Sometimes a Plastic Surgeon is asked to be of help if there are any cosmetic concerns with regard to a biopsy.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

posted_time: Post  by krazynesa1 » Sun Jan 30, 2005 5:25 pm

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Lymph nodes
content: Thanks for posting your question here at The Lounge.  I am happy to hear that both lymph nodes removed did not show any cancer.  If one of the areas was a "benign growth of fatty tissue", then sometimes those areas can grow back.  I am not certain how often such fatty tissue collections (sometimes referred to as lipomas) grow back or how fast they can do so.   Sometimes enlarged lymph nodes occur due to infections or other non-cancerous etiologies..  It would not be unreasonable to talk with your doctor about whether or not to remove the myph node and fatty tumor again to verify that no cancer is seen..  Are you haveing any fevers or infectious symptoms?  Have any scans been done of the area to see if any other areas deeper in the neck are enlarged?  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Jeffrey Gordon » Sun Mar 06, 2005 6:26 pm

He said it was a lymph node, but this is located on the front of my chin, towards the right side.  Anyway, the needle biopsy came back & said everything was normal (no indication that they did not have enough cells to make that determination), but then the original dermatologist said a needle biopsy still might not take enough cells to be sure.  I'm trying to get an appointment for a second opinion, but in the meantime this is driving me crazy.  The lump is definitely not fluid-filled (cyst).  There was no definite diagnosis that came back from the needle biopsy (or the ENT doctor).  What else could it be, if it isn't cancer?  Thank you, Strum
posted_time: Post  by Strum » Fri Jan 21, 2005 8:30 pm

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Lymph node
content: Thanks for posting your question here at The Lounge.  First, I would verify that the needle aspiration obtained enough material.  An aspiration and a biopsy are not the same thing.  The former has a higher likelihood of not being diagnostic (i.e.- not having enough tissue or cells for analysis) compared to the former.  However, a biopsy on the face can leave a scar.  Usually an ENT doctor or a Plastic Surgeon would be involed with a biopsy about the face if cosmetic issues are a concern.  Second, I would talk with your doctor if the area about the chin is a lymph node or something else, such a subcutaneous (under the skin) nodule not associated with a lymph node.  There can be many reasons for lymph nodes to enlarge.  Fortunately, most of those reasons are not due to a cancer.  If the nodule or lymph node has been enlarged for some time and has not changed or has not been associated with other areas appearing, then that can be reassuring that a cancer is not involved.  Cancers do not tend to remain static; they grow and spread over time.   There can be two approaches to a situation such as yours: 1.) watchful waiting, looking to see if anything changes over time; and 2.) proceed with a biopsy for a more definitive tissue analysis and diagnosis.  If you would feel comforted by a second opinion, then it would not be unreasonable to do so.  After all, you are the one at the center of this issue.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

content: I am curious if there are lymph nodes that are located above the lips, below the nose and about one to one and a half inche from the center of the face?
posted_time: Post  by wadesworth » Wed Jan 05, 2005 11:37 pm

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Facial lymph nodes
content: Thanks for posting your question here at The Lounge.  There a re lymph nodes, countless of them, all through out the body.  Some are easy to feel if they become enlarged, whereas others are deep in the body and can only be seen on scans (e.g.- CAT scans).  Some areas of the body do not have any regional lymph nodes associated with hem, but those are not many in number.  I cannot speak to the specific locations you describe.  Most of the lymph nodes about the mouth, nose and eyes are deep in the head, not on the surface, so to speak, and thus usually are not easy to feel.  Some lymph node areas in the mouth region can be seen by looking into the mouth if those lymph nodes are swollen.  Some areas of the head have lymph node drainage basins located in the neck.  I would suggest taking a look at an anatomy text book to learn more about this subject.  There may be some anatomy texts on line, although they may require a subscription to access.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

title: Lymphoma in a person with HIV/AIDS
content: Hello, My husband was diagnosed w/ HIV over 2 years ago. We moved to Honduras Central America a year ago. He was having severe pain in his abdomen and he ended up having surgery to find out what was wrong with his kidney. When they opened him up, they found a tumor over half the size of his kidney attached. The biopsey concluded it was lymphoma. He had his Tcell count an viral load tests after surgery and his T-cell dropped from 330 to 246, his viral load went from 331 to 10,000. He has started his anti-virals for HIV about 1 week. Since he had his kidney surgery on December 28th, he has not had any symptoms of lymphoma untill about 3 weeks ago. He now has B symptoms, (itchiness, night, sweats, weight loss, fever). The Dr.s want hhim to be on his HIV meds for 1 month before starting chemo. I'm worried his cancer is progressing rapidly. In the United States do the Dr's. start chemo right after diagnosis of cancer?? We don't get much information from the Dr's here. We aren't sure what stage he has. He has had CT scans, they show nothing except for a small mark in the lungs. They say that could be from TB? Any info you could give would be great. Such as what therapy is recommended for HIV positive patients with lymphoma. Also was the lymphoma caused by the HIV. Please help.
posted_time: Post  by aguirremommy » Sun Feb 20, 2005 3:37 pm

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Lymphoma and HIV
content: Thanks for posting your question here at The Lounge.  Unfortunately, peolple with HIV/AIDS are at risk to get various lymphomas, including some typs of aggressive lymphomas.  You did not give any information about the type of lymphoma diagnosed.  Do you have that informaton?  The treatment of a lymphoma in a person with HIV/AIDS can be complicated by the HIV/AIDS itself.  The HIV/AIDS predisposes to various infections and the lymphoma treatment can further put a person at risk for infecions.  Also, if the person is debilitated from the HIV/AIDS, then that can make it difficult to tolerate chemotherapy to treat the lymphoma.  Sometimes antiretroviral medications are given to better control the HIV/AIDS before starting lymphoma treatment.  Other times, if the lymphoma is aggressive and fast-paced, there is no time to wait before starting chemotherapy.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

title: Swollen lymph nodes
content: Thanks for posting your question here at The Lounge.  An elevated sedimentation rate (ESR) can be caused by countless things.  It is a nonspecific test in that many things can cause it be elevated but when it is elevtaed it does not specifically tell us why.  Perhaps you may need to have one of enlarged lymph nodes removed to see what it is.  I am assuming that if you have been evaluated by an Infectious Disease doctor, then you would have had a lot of tests done looking for various infections.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi mp213, Generally speaking, swollen, painful lymph nodes may be a sign of infection. Your lymph nodes sometimes swell because lymph nodes are the bodies filter system, so to speak, for bacteria etc. I would suggest an evaluation by your physician who will likely prescribe a course of antibiotic therapy to see if they decrease in size. If the swelling is due to an infection this should resolve the problem. Keep in mind however, that lymph nodes may not return to their preinfectious size but they should not continue to increase in size either. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: lynne1  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Feb 18, 2005 2:58 pm Location: Ohio
title: When to biopsy a lymph node?
content: In August 2004 I was massaging my neck when I discovered a lymph node on the side of my neck. I had my GP look at it in October and was referred to an ENT in Nov. The ENT said it was less than a cm and not concerning, but put me on antibiotics and Allegra (for allergies and itchy throat) to see if the node would go down. I followed up with that doctor twice and he concluded that this node shouldn't be biopsied due to its size and location and the fact that it hasn't changed over all these months.  He said to follow up with him if the node enlarged.  I sought a second opinion in January and this ENT said that the node was about the size of a pea, but that nodes should not be felt in an adult. He said they were ok to be felt in children and that it should be biopsied in a month if it does not go away.... I asked him to describe the node and he said it is rubbery and mobile and less than a cm.  My question is: Which doctor's advice should I take? The only thing they have agreed on is the size and character of the node. The first ENT said the node can be felt because my neck is thin.  I can feel the node at times just by lightly rubbing my hand down my neck. At other times, I can only feel it if I gently press on my neck. It is felt most easily when my neck is turned to the side. What is your advice as far as biopsying this node?
posted_time: Post  by lynne1 » Fri Feb 18, 2005 3:20 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi lynne1, Lymph nodes may enlarge as a result of an infection. They sometimes do not return to normal size after the infection subsides. They are palpable in adults as well as children. I would be much more concerned if the lymph node continued to enlarge after treatment for the infection and if it were fixed or stationary. If the physician suggested biopsy, I would not personally disagree, just to be on the "safe side". I would expect the results to be benign due to the description. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi Pudgey, From your description of the location of these bumps this appears to be a case of generalized lymph node enlargement. There are many causes for this of which lymphoproliferative diseases (lymphoma, chronic leukemia) are among the causes. Other causes include viral infections and immunological disorders. Please have a look at our generalized lymphadenopathy page for an extensive list of possible causes.  This is always a condition that should be taken seriously. You should report to your doctor immediately. Depending on the examination a biopsy from one of these bumps may be requested to establish the diagnosis. Please let us know how it turns out. Good luck and best regards.

posted_time: Post  by jashar » Tue Jan 11, 2005 2:33 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi jashar, Generally speaking a person with mumps has swelling on both sides. This is probably why mumps was ruled out. In my opinion as well, it's not likely to be mumps. If applying heat makes you feel better, it's fine to do so. Lymph nodes swell as a result of an infection or recent infection since they are your bodies filter so to speak. If you have had a recent infection then that would explain why your white blood cell counts are now normal. Take the full amount of your antibiotic treatment and if the lymph node swelling is a result of an infection it should reduce in size. However, keep in mind, if it does not reduce in size and you continue to have pain, follow up with your family physician. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: Dear gb,  What did your doctor say he/she thought this lump was when he/she first examined you before the ct scan? Lumps are mostly diagnosed clinically.  If the ent specialist and the ct scan of the neck did not find an abnormality in the neck, then most probably, there is nothing to worry about. title: [no title]
content: Hi nick, Generally speaking, swollen, tender lymph nodes is the bodies response to fighting infection since they are the bodies filtering system. They usually decrease in size (not always returning to normal) after the infection has subsided. Now to my concern, the result on the MRI that stated "Reproductive lymph node problems" isn't very specific as far as determining the actual problem. Did it happen to state on the report "abnormality attention needed' ? Has she had a recent examination by a gynecologist to rule out any anomolies? content: Dear Jill,  These could lymph nodes. Please, visit your doctor so that you be evaluated for the possibility of having enlarged lymph nodes.  There are lymph nodes normally in the places where you referred to but whether or not they are enlarged has to be decided by a physical exam in addition to taking a look at all other places where there are other lymph nodes normally.  Do you have other lumps like those ones anywhere else in your body?  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

One other thing, that could be related, or unrelated... Few weeks back, began feeling some pangs under right armpit, back near my shoulder blade and on down the arm a bit. Now today, sharp pain between the shoulder blades- causing me to have to take 4 motrin!   Any professional opinions would be greatly appreciated! I have a young daughter (16 mos old) and I know she would want her mommy to be in the best health possible! ;-)

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi BAMABOYBLG, Lymph nodes that enlarge, generally speaking, are the bodies response to infection. However, they generally decrease in size over time, not always returning to normal size. What concerns me is that the lymph node has increased in size despite antibiotic therapy. Has there been no mention of a repeat exam, lab work, biopsy etc.? If these tests have not been done I would suggest that they be completed. Sincerely, Rntdj

posted_time: Post  by DSALERNO » Mon Dec 20, 2004 8:17 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Hard lumps in neck area
content: Dear dsalerno,  i don't think that there was any correlation between the lump that your dad had and the prostate cancer that he developed.  The hard lump on your husband's neck is most probably either a lipoma (a fat growth) or a sebaceous cyst (cyst filled with oily material that the skin produces to lubricate the hair). Both very commonly arise in this area and both are benign. If you or your husband have any worries about any lump, the best thing to do is to have it removed and analysed.  Regarding your granddaughter, this might be an enlarged lymph node or an abscess or an infected cyst, as the pain usually points to either inflammation or infection.  She needs to be seen by her doctor as soon as possible.  Thank you very much for using our website http://www.doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi magirl, CFIDS is a mystery illness that is very difficult to treat. There is an exceptionally wide range of symptoms. Chills, night sweats, or a low body temperature are some of the symptoms. If diet changes have not helped you pain or flu like symptoms, you may want to ask you doctor what medications can benefit you. There is a very informative website on this illness called CFIDS Association of America. I hope this helps. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi booter, Is is hard or a firm lump? Softer/firm lumps are sometimes lipomas (benign fatty tumors) Harder lumps are sometimes forms of calcium deposits. If it has not changed in size and it's not causing you any other problems, I wouldn't be overly concerned. You should, however, bring it to your doctors attention when you have your appointment. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: Arm pit pain
content: I have a long story here and wondering if someone can help me.  I have had a swollen arm pit and breast in Aug. I went to a doctor right away to get some advice and was sent to a small hospital where I had an ultrasound done. Nothing was found. So, I was still dealing with pain but the swelling went down for a week or 2 then came back with pain in the left breast as well. So, I went back to the doctor and was told it would be good to have a mammogram. Had that done and all was clear. Now, in all this time, no one had mentioned to me what to do about the pain and so on. I decided to go to my GYN again and have some blood work done. Now while waiting for the results to come back in a week, My armpit blew up again and I went to my local GP and asked if it could be an infection. He gave me  a low dose antibotic. 2 days later I go back for the results of the blood test, and was told I had an infection. So again, I go and show the results to my local GP.  Now, I have been taking this antibotic and it seemed to be working at day 5 . I had little pain to nothing at all. But day 7 , today, in the evening the pain started again. We are having bad weather and I caught a slight cold on top of everything and I am taking medicine for that.       Now, since the pain has returned tonight , it also goes around to my back.  I don't know if it is just from sitting the wrong way or from an infection or something else.  I just don't know what to do , where to go to or what kind of treatment I should be having but am not getting. Can someone help me or advise me! I am getting desperate!!!!
posted_time: Post  by Maureenjp » Wed Oct 20, 2004 7:37 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Arm pit pain
content: Dear Maureen,  What you are suffering from sounds to me like an infection but it lacks some of the characteristics of infection like having a fever, redness of the area and the intermittent course without treatment (usually infections are either progressive or self limited). This sounds like a skin infection as the antibiotic improved it.   At this time, i would recommend going to the doctor once more for renewal of the antibiotic or prescription for a stronger one.  If you are worried about what is going on in the breast are and whether or not this might might be something malignant, i think that mri now is being used by some to search for malignancy in the breast.  There is another remote possibility, that this could be shingles in an atypical presentation.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Yasser Mokhtar » Wed Oct 20, 2004 9:08 am

author: wish  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Sep 22, 2004 2:15 pm Location: USA
title: Enlarged lymph node in back of neck
content: Ok, this is it.  Around 13-15 months ago I had a swollen lymph node in the back of my neck. I can't remember if it hurt or not but think it did.. It wasn't all that hard if I remember correctly. Sorry didn't pay that much attn.. I figured it was just an infection and went to the dr. and he did agree and gave me some antibiotics and said if it didn't go away to go to the surgeon. Well, it didn't go away, however, it did go down alot. So I ignored it. It has since been getting big again and oh yes a few months ago I went to give blood and almost wasn't able because they said i had a slight fever but i felt fine and they waited and it went down low enough for me to give like .1 down below.  I do freeze almost constantly to the point where my husband and kids are hot. I am young I am 28 and have heard lymphoma is usually much older.  My sister had bone cancer and it did spread to her lymph nodes and she was 16 at the time, my other sister had mylenoma(sp) and she was around 21 I do come from a very strong back ground of cancer. One cousin was 24 with breast cancer she is the only one in my family who had that. We have a variety of different cancers. I do have pcos, I am not overweight anymore and within normal weight (textbook) at the higher end. I did have cervical cancer as well. It was aggressive and the gyn was surprised at how much so. within like a span of 4 months it went from mild dysplasia to cancer. and how it was shaped she couldn't get it all but burned around it to prevent spreading. the biopsy before leap was at severe dysplasia and day of leap she said she saw cancer cells and was amazed at the rate it went and the shape of it. I don't know what all that means.. I went to the dr. last week today. It was bigger then 2 cm he said. It is hard, painless, but it will move side to side not up and down but still movable. He wouldn't do blood work of any kind. he said i get the biopsy done and come back and we will do blood work then. Everyone in my family who has had cancer had bloodwork,x-rays or of the like. He was the only dr. there and was already an hr. behind and he sat there for additional 20-30 mins. discussing lymphomas with me and telling me this needs to be biopsied asap. He was acting as if it is lymphoma but everything in me is saying it isn't. It went down before and it feels like it is going down again. If it is cancer wouldn't it not go down but get bigger. He knew that before it went down i told him so. He jsut said since on how long I have had it he really wanted to get it checked out further. He did and i am not exaggerating this either. He was without saying it telling me it is lymphoma. I just don't think it is. I have had low fever (I guess) 99.7 usually.. I think it was just an infection and scarred tissue and that is why it won't go all the way down. My point is I don't have insurance and have alot going on right now. My husband and I are bying a new home and starting a small business and all the money is going to that.  I am not saying I am not getting the biopsy I just think he was being to cautious. I asked him is this something that could wait a few more weeks when things start to settle and he went on saying how my life is worth more then a million dollars and what good is all of this if I am not around. So, I feel like I am obsessing over this but I can't get his words out of my mind. I was feeling like I had the flu mainly this yr almost everyday but for the past few days feel better. I do think I may be anemic or thyroid I don't know I do have extreme fatigue but that is even feeling better for the past three days. I just need another opinion. My husband says it isn't going down but it is. I think he thinks I won't go if he tells me it is going down but that isn't the case. I can see it in the mirror still from a side view but it definately is going down.  I have been on amox for exactly one week, today. I go for consult on the 28th. but haven't heard good things aobut her. but have heard the dr. i went to is very conservative and doesn't make you take unnessary test. but i think he may be.. I would've like or felt better if atleast we had some blood work and soemthing fishy came out of that. He wouldn't though, I asked..  what do you think about all of this.. Sorry, this is long but i tried to be very descriptive so you would have a better picture of it.  P.S I do have two lymphnodes next to the big one which is still small but are growing but it is different then my others it is like two hooked together?? I don't know what is up with that. I didn't even bring it up to the dr. he had already scared me enough and just wanted toleave. One on the other side is normal but can feel which i know is common. Not worried aobut that. Last pap./breast the dr felt lumps and wanted em to go to surgeon but didn't she did say she didn't think it was cancer. I am not one of those who freaks out over everything. However, this dr. scared me and this is the first dr to have done that.  Thanks, wish

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Dear Wish: Your name suits the problem.  You are wishing the lump would go away.  In fact you are wishing it so hard that you actually see it getting smaller when someone objective, like your husband says differently. I am sure your husband wants this new house and new business to succeed.  But he doesnt want it at the cost of risking your life.  With your history of cancer and your family history of cancer you know you are at a much higher risk than norm.  The fact that the doctors words keep haunting you is your own conscience telling you what you should do.  Do you really think that any doctor online can diagnose cancer from afar without seeing you? This doctor, you saw, has much experience and wisdom and you should not think so lightly of that.  Let his haunting words motivate you to take action and have this thing biopsied before its at the point where you have less of a chance for a good outcome.  The fact you say its getting smaller but you have two more lumps shows that if its infection its not going away.  If it was going away the lump would subside, not two more develop.  If not for yourself, for the sake of your husband and your future get it biopsied.  Heres wishing for a good outcome. Thanks for using The Doctor's Lounge, Carolyn

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Kink in neck causing large lump
content: Dear MyBabe,  i can not tell you what the nature of this lump is because i have not examined you myself. This lump could have been there for a long time and you noticed it only when you woke up with your neck kinked and turning and you might have felt your neck and accidentally stumbled on this lump and this is the way most lumps are discovered, accidentally.  Concluding from the area where the lump is, it might be a lymph node, a sebaceous cyst (collection of the oily lubricating fluid of the skin), a lipoma (benign fatty tumour) or other lumps orignintaing from the skin itslef.  Since it is not causing a major discomfort, i would suggest that you follow it for any change such as sudden increase in size, new onset pain or redness. Any change should prompt a visit to the clinic.  i don't think there is any thing to worry about now.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Lump in neck
content: Dear Kirsty,  Newly discovered lumps should be seen by doctors to decide whether or not they merit further investigation and/or treatment.  In many instances, newly discovered lumps prove not to be of major importance.  If you are planing on not seeing your doctor in the near future like within 3-6 months, you have to pay attention to the lump and whether it is growing fast or not, painful or not, any change should prompt a visit to your doctor.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

I don't check it every day obviously, but several times during a year I did.  At the present time we are getting ready for the biopsy, but should we have some other tests done first? No visible signs of any other infections are present, mostly he has scratches and bruises from his activities. (he uses oil paints) or anything else?

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Enlarged lymphnode in armpit for 1.5 years in 16 y old
content: Dear Karu,  An enlarged solitary lymph node for 1.5 years most probably does not represent much, in the case of groin and armpit lymph nodes, drainage areas are not the cleanest areas in the body, so sometimes, there is just chronic non-specific lymph node enlargement in these areas.  Are there any other symptom of chronic disease such as fatigue, weight loss, low grade fever or night sweats? If no, then most probably there is nothing to worry about.  A biopsy is a good step for diagnosis, it is usually a simple procedure but you will have to discuss the potential complications with the surgeon who is going to perform the biopsy.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: judy york  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Jul 31, 2004 11:16 am
title: Lymph node biopsy
content: My 33 yr old daughter discovered swollen (not painful) lymph nodes at the base of her skull, armpits, neck, groin, on clavicle 5 weeks ago. She went to family doctor and he did a CBC and mono test, which were both normal.  He ordered a biopsy and she had that done the next week. The surgeon was very suspicious of lymphoma, but it was benign. The nodes are still swollen and she has an intermittent low grade fever and is extremely fatigued.  The path report comments:  The histological findings are nonspecific but consistent with a reactive process.  Multiple infectious diseases including infection with Epstein-Barr virus, toxoplasmosis, HIV infection and syphilis can result in similar histological findings.  Also included in differential diagnosis is reactive lymph nodes due to systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, dermatopathic lymphadenitis and early sarcoid.  Clinica correlation is recommended.  She does have an appt Monday with family doctor to begin the necessary tests to rule these things out.  My question is, do cancer cells always show up in the biopsy, if lymphoma is present?  Her symptoms fit lymphoma more than any of these other things. [/quote]
posted_time: Post  by judy york » Sat Jul 31, 2004 2:56 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, Actually her clinical picture doesn't fit lymphoma more than any of the other causes. Take a look at our lymph enlargement page. An excision biopsy is the most definitive diagnosis for lymphoma. Certain criteria inlcuding monoclonality would easily differentiate between lymphoma and reactive lymph node enlargement. However, there are times when the diagnosis is not so straight forward and in this case follow up is advised. Its good that the other causes will be excluded soon. If it turns out that she has any one of these things that would clearly exclude lymphoma.  Best of luck.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: [no title]
content: Thanks for your post to The Doctor's Lounge.  I cannot tell you any specific info about the lymph node since I have not examined your husband or seen his films.  Given the neurologic symptoms being experienced, it seems reasonable to me to have further evaluation done.  The question is what is the next step.  If you do not agree with the recommendations from the surgeon or have confidence in him, then getting a second opinion woul dbe in order.  Not everything found is a cancer and not everyhting found is biopsied.  However, it would be helpful to get another opinion about whether to biopsy the lymph node.  One can do such even while seeing a Neurologist.  I would condider getting an MRI (unless it has been done already) to see more the anatomy ehre this lymph node is sitting and to see if it is affecting any nearby nerve structures.  The ulnar nerve starts high in the arm, as do all nerves in the arms, and thus something high up in the arm can be affecting it and such is felt lower down the pathway of the nerve.   This could be one possibility as to the pain or nerve feeling being experienced.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Lymphoma
content: Thanks for your question to The Doctor's Lounge.  Please note that I am limited in what I can do to give you information since I am not privy to your husband's case and I have not seen any of his tests results or examined him in person.  Any information that I provide does not replace the expert advice of your husband's doctors.  PET scans can look at the lymphoma in a different way than can the CAT scans.  The PET scans do not replace the CAT scans, but can add to the information.  The PET scans are not always done, but more and more PET scans are being used along with CAT scans.  Sometimes lymph nodes may look normal in size on CAT scan but can "light up" on PET indicating residual disease.  Regarding the finding in the breast, it either can be monitored closely for changes and if such changes do occur, then proceeding with a biopsy or it can be biopsied now to make certain that it is benign.  My best to your husband.

title: Lump in arm pit and swelling in breast...
content: I'm a 39 yo male, and I recently (3 weeks) had a cyst removed from my right underarm.  I've had trouble in this area for about 3-4 years now, but never to the extent of this last time.    The day after the cyst was removed, I noticed a hard lump below the incision.  The lump isn't painful, and hasn't grown a whole lot in that time frame.  There is also no drainage at all.  I've also noticed swelling in my right breast for about the past 3-4 months.  Is there any connection between the two, and should either concern me?  And are there any specific questions I should ask my primary care physician about these problems?  Any help will be greatly appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by MikeB » Thu Apr 22, 2004 12:49 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Lump in arm pit and swelling in breast...
content: Dear Mike,  The swelling at the incision site could be either a small hematoma (blood collection) or a small seroma (serous fluid collection) either of which is not an unexpected minor complication of any incision. It also could be another smaller cyst that the larger cyst that was removed was covering and got exposed once the bigger cyst was removed.  Regarding the swelling in your right breast, if you have had quite a few surgeries in your arm pit (and you don't mention what kind of trouble you had), this is where the lymphatics of the breast usually drain and they can get interrupted by the multiple surgeries you had and so the lymphatics vessels were cut and the lymphatic fluid is not being drained properly and hence the swelling in your breast (assuming that the swelling is not a localized mass like a tumour).  i guess you should the doctor who took the cyst out and see whether he could like to start you on antibiotics as some of the surgeons would do to prevent this mass (whether it is a hematoma or seroma) from getting infected. In the same time, draw your doctor's attention to your breast swelling.  All this of course assuming that the cysts that were removed have always been benign without any signs of malignancy.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Lymph nodes
content: Tylerand,  Thanks for posting a question here at The Doctor's Lounge.  First, enlarged lymph nodes do not imply a cancer or a lymphoma.  Most enlarged lymph nodes are not such and are due to "reaqctive" reasons, such as infections.  Second, if an enalrged lymph nodes becomes even bigger or if other enlarged lymph nodes appear, then a doctor should do an evaluation and an examination.  Sometimes blood tests and/or imaging scans are done, depending upon what is going on in a particular case.  Third, there can be enlarged areas of fat under the skin that appear as lumps.  These are almost always benign findings and are called lipomas.  They are usually small to moderate in size.  They tend to soft and rubbery, a bit firmer than the surrounding skin and fat.  If an enalrged area is firm or hard like a rock, then it should be evaluated.  Not all of these findings are cancerous, however.  Fourth, it is always a good rule of thumb to have something of cancer checked out.  In my medical practice caring for patients with cancer and blood disorders, I tell my patients that I would rather see 100 patients with "problems" and find out that 99 of them are not anything of concern then to have have that 1 patient with a serious problem not be evaluated and that serious problem missed.  In your case, it is difficult for me to give you any sepcific diagnoses to your enlarged lymph node since I am unable to examine you.  What was the infection that you had recently?  Where was the infection?  Where were the other enlarged lymph nodes that you noted when you had the infection?  If the enlarged lymph node is in the groin area, are the genitalia O.K.?  Are you having any fevers or sweats?  These are some questions that come to mind.

author: memorylane4ever  Guest Posts: 15 Joined: Fri Jan 30, 2004 5:03 pm Location: Alaska  Contact:   Contact memorylane4ever       Yahoo Messenger
title: Quick question about ferritin levels and cancer
content: My question is short. Why are ferritin levels high in someone who has cancer. Is this a sign in blood work that indicates further evaluation? And Why?
posted_time: Post  by memorylane4ever » Sun Feb 29, 2004 12:45 pm

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: [no title]
content: Thanks for your question posted here at The Doctor's Lounge.  Ferritin is one of many different proteins in the body that can act as "acute phase reactants".  What this means is that they can be increased, sometimes high, when some other process or illness occurs.  It is a general, nonspecific sign of an illness and in and of itself does not imply anything specific.  There are some cases when a high ferritin is specific to a disease, such as in body iron overload (i.e.- hemochromatosis).  In the case of cancer, a high ferritin is a nonspecific result of the cancer affects on the bosy and is not a cause of the cancer.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

title: Re: Lumps in the lymph nodes
content: Dear Jimswife,  With your previous history of both breast and thyroid cancer (and especially the thyroid) i would be really vigilant about getting a fast and reliable answer about the nature of these lymph nodes as they may represent recurrence of the thyroid cancer. Most probably you had a thyroidectomy, taking synthroid and following with an endocrinologist. Recurrence or extension of the thyroid cancer to the lymph nodes of the neck depends on the type of thyroid cancer. Your tsh test should be followed by an endocrinologist to be able to adjust your synthroid dose (to decrease tsh to inhibit the growth of any thyroid tissue). My advice is to schedule an appointment with your doctor who is following your thyroid cancer as a first step. author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Nodule
content: Dear JoAnn,  Thyroid nodules are benign most of the time and the usual plan of action is a biopsy to make sure it is not malignant if it is of a certain size and characteristics.  Your doctor is doing the right thing by following the thyroid nodule by ultrasound to see whether it is getting larger or if it is changing its characteristics.  If you start to have any new symptom such as pain in your neck at the site of the nodule, difficulty breathing, difficulty swallowing, new masses in your neck or if the nodule is getting larger faster, these are considered alarming symptoms and you will have to call your doctor about them.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dr. Sekhar,  Thank you for posting such an interesting case on The Doctor's Lounge.  It appears that the conjugated bilirubinemia developed before any of the ABVD chemotherapy was administered.  How large was the liver biopsy?  What else was seen or not seen on the liver biopsy?  Have the liver tests improved once the chemotherapy treatment was started?  Has the patient responded to the ABVD chemotherapy?  The predominat elevation of conugated bilirubion appears to rule out hemolysis causing the anemia.  In significant hemolytic anemias, more unconjugated than conjugated bilirubin is released.  In addition, the anemia is usually macrocytic if there is an increased number of reticulocytes.  I have two initial thoughts based upon my experience with patients with Hodgkin's lymphomas.  First, there may be lymphoma in the liver not seen on the intitial liver biopsy.  I would consider obtaining a second liver biopsy from a different part of the liver.  Second, there may be a loss of bile ducts in the liver.  There is a syndrome, albeit it rare, of "vanishing bile ducts".  A thorough review of the liver biopsy would be in order.  I would consider a second liver biopsy.  If the former problem is causing the bilirubinemia, then it should improve if the lymphoma is responding to the chemotherapy.  If the latter problem is the cause, then it does not improve with treatment of the lymphoma.  I do not know the incidence of Hodgkin's lymphoma with various congenital disorders.  Perhaps someone else can comment about such a relationship.  Please post more information about how the patient is doing and if anything further has been found to explain the high bilirubin level.  Jeff Gordon, M.D.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Jennifer, It could be a lymph node or it could be nothing at all. I cannot judge from here obviously. An enlarged lymph node does not necessarily implicate cancer. It could be a normal reaction to an infection in the area of the ear, scalp, face.. Usually however, they are not stone hard. Clinically significant lymph nodes are those that are larger than 1 cm.  From what you've described it could also be the normal bony prominence behind the ear (called the mastoid process) and that you are just worrying too much. In such a case you should be able to feel another one on the opposite side.  Best regards.

author: Guest
title: Lymph canal cancer
content: What are the survival rate with a person with lymph canal cancer?
posted_time: Post  by Guest » Fri Mar 21, 2003 8:24 am

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Lymph canal cancer
content: Betty,  Sorry for the delay in your receiving a response to your question.  Do you mean "lymphoma" when you asked about "lymph canal cancer"?  Your question is not a simple one to answer given that there are many variables involved in formulating a prognosis for lymphoma.  First, lymphoma is a large disease entity, encompassing numerous different types of lymphomas, each with their own specific issues relative to treatment and survival.  Second, there is a standardized staging system for lymphomas that does have prognostic information relative to survival (generally, survival decreases as the stage increases).  Third, there is an International Prognostic Index used for different lymphomas that combines various variables into defined categories that carry prognostic information relative to the successfullness of treatment and long-term survival.  Fourth, there are other characteristics of specific lymphomas, the presence or absence of which do carry important prognostic information (for example, in the common diffuse large cell lymphoma, the presence of bcl-2 may imply a worse prognosis than if the bcl-2 were absent, but this may be overcome with the use of a specific monoclonal antibody (rituxamab) incorporated into the treatment).  Fifth, a person's overall medical condition and general health status are very important because someone who is medically unfit is not expected to tolerate  chemotherapy whereas someone who is medically fit could withstand the effects of such treatment.  In sum, each type of lymphoma has various variables that need to be taken into account when talking about prognosis.  Like any cancer, a discussion of survival issues in a lyphoma situation must be individualized to the clinical presentaion and the person affected by it.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Jeffrey Gordon » Fri May 09, 2003 10:42 am
